HEADLINE: Third-Quarter Profit Fell 16% at DuPont

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 21

 BODY:
The DuPont Company, the largest chemical company in the United States, said third-quarter profit fell 16 percent on weakening global demand and the strong dollar before charges resulted in a quarterly loss.
The company, based in Wilmington, which also owns the Conoco energy company, said profit from continuing operations fell to $610 million, or 53 cents a diluted share, from $725 million, or 63 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. 
 Including profit from Conoco, which DuPont plans to sell, the company had results of 67 cents a share, in line with the 66-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation.
The company, which derived almost half of its $45.1 billion in 1997 sales from overseas, said that global economic weakness and the strong dollar eroded prices for polyester and other products. In addition, falling oil prices, DuPont said, reduced profit at Conoco. Excluding acquisitions, shipments fell during the quarter and productivity gains did not match analysts' expectations.
Even so, sales rose 4.3 percent, to $6.04 billion from $5.79 billion, as recently acquired businesses added to revenue.
Shares of DuPont fell $2.1875, to $62, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Kmart to Open 45 Stores

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TROY, Mich., Oct. 21

 BODY:
The Kmart Corporation said today that it would open 45 of its Big Kmart stores next month, ending a long period of store closings and depressed earnings. The retailer's chairman, Floyd Hall, said the opening of the remodeled stores, which are the same size as other Kmarts but include food sections, would help it compete against Wal-Mart Stores Inc. Wal-Mart plans a big push into Michigan in the coming months. Mr. Hall said Kmart, based in Troy, had finally emerged from its troubles. While sales were down in September, he said third-quarter earnings would be up, though still short of potential.

SECTION: Section C; Page 20; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 305 words

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Construction of new homes and apartments slipped in September for the second consecutive month as the brisk pace of building cooled along with the rest of the nation's economy.
Builders started work on new housing units at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.58 million last month, down 2.5 percent from August, the Commerce Department said today. Starts had hit a rate of 1.70 million in July, an 11-year high. 
 In September, housing starts in the South dropped 8.6 percent, the largest decline since May 1997, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 709,000 -- a consequence, analysts said, of Hurricane Georges.
Starts also fell in the Northeast, down 3.6 percent, to a rate of 135,000. But they rose 5.6 percent in the West, to 414,000, and 3.2 percent in the Midwest, to 318,000.
Nationally, the decline was steeper for apartments, down 9.1 percent, to a rate of 330,000, than for single-family homes, down six-tenths of a percent, to 1.25 million.
Separately, according to a National Association of Home Builders survey, the number of shoppers viewing model homes fell sharply this month, though sales remained quite good.
Sales of both new and existing homes have soared this year, supported by a plunge in mortgage rates and by low unemployment and solid income growth. The big gains in the stock market through midsummer also allowed some buyers to make down-payments on larger homes.
But financial turmoil overseas has begun to slow United States economic growth, and the stock market is still well off its July peaks.
"Given the drop-off of prospective buyers visiting model homes and the recent erosion of consumer confidence, the indication is that the housing market will be slowing a bit in the months ahead," said Kent W. Colton, executive vice president of the home builders' group.

HEADLINE: U.S., Pushing Its Route For Pipeline, Aids Turkey

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, increasing the pressure on oil companies to build a pipeline for Caspian Sea oil that suits American interests, said today that it would give Turkey $823,000 to help plan its part of the line.
As oil company executives appear close to making a recommendation on a pipeline route, the United States is making a major push for a plan that would send oil across Turkey to the Mediterranean port of Ceyhan. Administration officials say a pipeline along this route would help stabilize the region and serve long-term United States interests. 
 "Over all, Baku-Ceyhan offers the best option from environmental, economic and strategic standpoints," said Under Secretary of State Stuart E. Eizenstat. "No one should underestimate our determination to make Baku-Ceyhan a reality."
Oil companies favor the American-backed pipeline route but believe that its projected cost of $2.8 billion makes it too costly to build anytime soon. Indeed, some executives believe that the project could cost $4 billion or more. Mr. Eizenstat's announcements were apparently part of a last-minute campaign to make it more economical.
"The idea is to give Turkey financial help to lay the groundwork for this project," said an official in Ankara who was briefed on this week's meetings. "It's to help Turkey prepare a financial package, figure out how to line up financing and firm up details of the route."
Executives of oil companies active in the Caspian region said today that they still favor a shorter pipeline route running from Baku, the capital of oil-rich Azerbaijan, to the Georgian port of Supsa on the Black Sea.
Mr. Eizenstat concluded three days of meetings with Turkish officials today. He said that the Trade and Development Agency, which supports American business projects abroad, would provide the money to Turkey.
He is one of several top Administration officials who are traveling to push for the Baku-Ceyhan route. Jan Kalicki, a senior Commerce Department envoy, was in Azerbaijan last weekend. President Clinton's special envoy to the Caspian region, Richard Morningstar, and the head of the Trade and Development Agency are due in Istanbul next week.
The discovery of large amounts of oil and gas under and around the Caspian has attracted dozens of energy companies to what may be the century's last big bonanza. Because the new nations in the region are unstable and wedged into a strategic region between Russia and Iran, they have also become an arena for big-power competition. The decision on where to build an oil export pipeline could have profound geopolitical as well as economic effects.
Oil companies active in the Caspian, among them Exxon, Pennzoil and BP Amoco, are expected to announce soon which pipeline route they favor. Officially they are making only a recommendation to the Government of Azerbaijan. Since they will pay for the pipeline, however, their recommendation is likely to be decisive.
A spokeswoman for the oil consortium, Pamela Mounter, said executives hoped to recommend a pipeline route next week. "Our contract calls for us to make a draft recommendation to the Azerbaijani Government," Ms. Mounter said in a telephone interview from Baku. "The deadline is the end of this month, and we hope to meet that deadline."
Asked if the recommendation would be made public, she replied, "Yes, to the right people."
An executive close to the consortium, however, said intense international interest would probably force the companies to make their recommendation fully public.
"The recommendation is being made to Socar," the executive said, referring to Azerbaijan's state-owned oil company. "They've asked for a delay of a week or two because they're still working on next year's budget and some other matters that have to be discussed at the meeting. It's a legitimate delay, nothing horribly nefarious."
Published reports suggesting that the companies will not recommend immediate construction of a pipeline across Turkey have set off waves of protest and denial in several countries.
"Baku-Ceyhan will definitely be constructed," President Suleyman Demirel of Turkey assured anxious Turks. "It is the safest route and has the backing of the United States."
The date originally set for the companies' announcement, Oct. 29, is also the 75th anniversary of the founding of the Turkish Republic. The Presidents of Azerbaijan and Georgia will be in Turkey for the celebrations, and they are expected to join President Demirel in a statement committing themselves to the Baku-Ceyhan route. Since their Governments will not be putting up the money for the pipeline, however, the statement will be largely symbolic.

HEADLINE: For Congress From New York

 BODY:
There are more members of Congress from New York City and its suburbs running uncontested this year than facing serious opposition. But an election still presents an opportunity to evaluate the incumbents. Here are our endorsements in some of the more interesting local races: 
 Fourth District (Nassau County): Carolyn McCarthy's transformation from nurse-housewife to gun control advocate to member of Congress was one of the most dramatic stories of the 1996 political year. Now Mrs. McCarthy, a Democrat, is running for re-election and she has the right to boast that she has become more than a one-issue lawmaker. Mrs. McCarthy has worked hard on constituent services and broadened her concerns in Congress to education and health issues, while compiling an impressive record of support for the environment. Her opponent, Gregory Becker, is a longtime State Assemblyman whose main rationale for running seems simply to be that the district ought to be under the control of the Republican Party. We are impressed by the degree to which Mrs. McCarthy has grown in office, and we give her our enthusiastic endorsement.
Sixth District (parts of Queens and the Bronx): Voters who feel that political power brokers are elbowing them out of the decision-making process have no farther to look than this district, where the veteran incumbent Thomas Manton engineered a transfer of power to his chosen successor in the middle of the night, at a time when it was too late for other Democrats to file for a primary or for Republicans to nominate a serious opponent. The beneficiary of Mr. Manton's scheme, Joseph Crowley, is a 36-year-old member of the State Assembly whose main exertion seems to have been promoting the racing industry. Mr. Crowley, a personable Democrat with deep roots in Queens politics, will almost certainly be elected to Congress, since the Republican Party is giving no support to its nominee, James Dillon, a maverick. Mr. Dillon should be commended for his effort to give voters more of an option than the local political machines seem to have intended. But his positions on tax policy are extreme and his platform on foreign policy seems to call for American isolationism, except in regard to countries whose ethnic groups are represented in the district. Despite our reservations about the illegitimate way in which he obtained the nomination, we reluctantly endorse Mr. Crowley and hope Queens voters will get more respectful treatment in the future.
Thirteenth District (part of Brooklyn and Staten Island): The freshman Republican Vito Fossella quickly established himself as a loyal foot soldier for Speaker Newt Gingrich. We have disagreed with Mr. Fossella on a number of fronts, including his extreme opposition to abortion rights and family planning. He also opposes requiring Federal employee health plans to cover contraceptives for women, just as they cover other prescriptive drugs. But Mr. Fossella's most unforgivable failure was his persistent attempts to sabotage bipartisan efforts to pass a campaign finance reform bill. Eugene Prisco, a Democrat and Staten Island schoolteacher, is a long shot at best in this race. But he has been a lifelong fighter for reform and has a sensible list of priorities including school construction aid and environmental protection. He gets our strong endorsement.
Twenty-Sixth District (Lower Hudson Valley to Ulster County, the Catskills and north to Ithaca): The incumbent Democrat Maurice Hinchey's district is larger than Connecticut, and includes both troubled industrial cities and tourist resorts. During his three terms in Congress, Mr. Hinchey has represented this diverse territory well with an agenda that combines economic development and a staunch support for the environment. Along with Sherwood Boehlert of Utica, a Republican, Mr. Hinchey has set the pace for environmentalism in the New York Congressional delegation. His Republican opponent, William Walker, an apple farmer who owns several upstate radio stations, has no real experience in government. Mr. Hinchey has served his district well and should be returned to Congress.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Big Cash Infusion Aims to Rebuild Anemic C.I.A.

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Heeding warnings from the Director of Central Intelligence that the C.I.A. "will no longer be relevant" without an infusion of money and talent, Congress and the White House today approved the largest spending increase for intelligence in 15 years.
The Director, George J. Tenet, has been telling members of Congress that the machine of United States intelligence might rust and falter in the coming decade without an injection of billions of dollars. He received secret "emergency assistance" from Congress in April, and today, officials said, he received a supplemental appropriation of about $1.8 billion. In budget requests for coming years he will seek billions more. 
 "I will not allow the C.I.A. to become a second-rate organization," he told its employees recently.
In recent months, American intelligence has failed to foresee India's nuclear tests, to quickly and accurately assess a North Korean missile launch, to come up with a workable plan to undermine the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, and to provide sharp analysis of global financial crises. The C.I.A.'s evidence to justify a cruise missile attack on the Sudan in August has been questioned by Administration officials and within the agency itself.
These problems illustrate shortcomings in the intelligence agencies' abilities to analyze world events and to undertake secret operations, say supporters and critics alike.
But intelligence officials and Congressional overseers caution that some of those abilities will take years to build and cannot be created by money alone. They say -- and C.I.A. officials acknowledge -- that the agency must attract a new generation of talented people: not just spies, but computer wizards, scientists, engineers, economists, and experts in foreign languages, cultures and other subjects.
Mr. Tenet has warned his employees and members of Congress that the agency, which celebrated its 50th anniversary last year, would not see its 60th year without the money to become smarter, faster and sharper. This year he undertook a campaign to restore the agency to its cold-war strength.
In a May 5 speech at the agency, which has not previously been made public, he said the C.I.A. had to "rebuild our field strength" in order "to stay in the espionage business."
He pledged "to mount increasingly complex and expensive operations" to steal secrets. He vowed to build up the agency's clandestine service of spies, open more overseas stations, undertake more covert operations, hire more in-house experts, buy faster and better computers, and bring in a new generation of recruits.
"Obviously, moving ahead without more money would be difficult," he said in the speech, which became a basis for his requests for the billions he says are needed to create a skilled and agile intelligence service.
"How are we going to pay for it all?" he asked. "I will work with the Administration and Congress to obtain more funding."
In recent weeks, Mr. Tenet has done just that, buttonholing President Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich and key lawmakers. He convinced them that American intelligence was "seriously eroding" and needed rebuilding, said Representative Porter J. Goss, Republican of Florida, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee.
"Intelligence isn't just something for the cold war," Mr. Goss, a former C.I.A. operations officer, said in an interview. "When you think back to Pearl Harbor, you can understand why. Unpleasant surprises are out there, like embassies being blown up. We finally have a very clear manifestation of a commitment that we are going to invest in intelligence. This is going to be a long-term rebuild."
The retirement of several thousand employees since 1991 has cost the C.I.A. a great deal of talent and experience. Past and present agency officials say those people left because the cold war ended and lesser missions did not interest them, because they did not like the Clinton Administration, because morale sagged as five different Directors led the C.I.A. over six years, and because of a lack of spirit, which Mr. Tenet is trying to revive.
"Does the agency have enough people on board to deal with the challenges it's facing? Not enough," said Fred Hitz, who retired after a long C.I.A. career, including eight years as inspector general. "Our stocks have been severely depleted. Trying to replace these individuals, the knowledge they took out the door, the elan and the sense of mission that they had is a very difficult problem."
An intelligence official outside the agency said that "the brain drain can be remedied," but "it's going to take five, six, seven years of steady rebuilding."
Several intelligence officials said that money was not the sole solution, but that the C.I.A. and the other intelligence services were assured of more in coming years.
"You don't want to throw money at them," one said. "But this is not a binge. This is not a one-time huge shot of money. This is an upward glide" that Congress intends to continue for years.
The overall budget for intelligence, will rise by about 7 percent, to about $29 billion, close to the figure at which it peaked during the cold war, without accounting for inflation. The money finances the C.I.A. and a dozen other intelligence services; the C.I.A. spends about a tenth of the sum.
The spending figures have traditionally been kept secret. But the increase approved today appears to be the largest since 1984, the last of four years when President Reagan's Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, presided over multibillion-dollar annual spending increases, undertook scores of covert operations and hired several thousand new C.I.A. officers, "stacking people like cordwood in the corridors," in the words of another former Director, Robert M. Gates.
When Mr. Tenet became Director last year, "the C.I.A. was a place on the verge of absolute disaster," said an intelligence official outside the agency. "There was not enough money to to keep things going. Many elements of C.I.A.'s operating budget were unfunded. They had to rob other activities to run the agency."
"A great deal of the money that is going into the C.I.A. is going into the hiring and placement of good new people," this official said. "About a year ago the door into the agency was almost shut. A whole new class of people was almost put off because there wasn't money to bring them in."

GRAPHIC: Photo: George J. Tenet says he won't let the C.I.A. become second rate. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The timid Japanese banking bailout just might do the job.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
THE law the Japanese Parliament recently passed to rescue broken-down banks commits several blunders. It does not require insolvent banks to close. It does not require banks to disclose losses. It does not require wobbly banks that accept taxpayer money to lend to credit-worthy borrowers -- the primary purpose of a bailout. The obvious prediction is that Japan will remain credit-starved, dragging down other economies in Asia and beyond.
But the obvious may be wrong. The law takes the important step of injecting public money into failing banks. Despite its flaws, the measure might pry open clogged credit lines and channel money to companies in need of a fresh start. As Adam Posen of the Institute for International Economics, author of a new book on the Japanese economy, says, "The bill will succeed despite itself." 
 Japan's banks are buried in bad loans and confront an economy that has slipped into recession. Thus they are loath to lend even to reliable customers. But if banks do not lend, companies cannot invest, and the economy cannot grow.
The crisis has been worsened by an accounting system that lets banks mask losses. Fanciful financial reports have scared away investors and creditors. Worse, the phantom bookkeeping pretends that borrowers can repay impossibly big loans.
Japan needs to have its banks wipe bad loans from their books so borrowers can start fresh. To that end, the law creates three pots of public money totaling about $500 billion, more than 10 percent of Japan's annual output. America's bailout of savings and loans in the 1980's cost about 2 or 3 percent of output.
The first pot, about $150 billion, will pay off depositors at banks that close. Their assets will be transferred to a Government agency for resale to private investors, much the way the Resolution Trust Corporation worked in the United States.
The second pot, also around $150 billion, will be used to nationalize insolvent banks the Government decides to keep open. The Government will run these banks until private owners take over, mirroring the way the Roosevelt Administration handled the 1930's banking crisis.
The third, most-controversial pot has no American parallel. It will pump about $200 billion into private banks the Government deems shaky but solvent. In return, the Government will get stock. The idea is that the taxpayer money will build up the banks' capital so they can resume lending.
Daniel K. Tarullo, formerly President Clinton's top adviser on international economic policy, is unconvinced the plan will work. "There is no clear mechanism for moving the $500 billion out the door of Government and into banks," he says. "Banks have to ask for assistance. But by asking for assistance, the bank managers identify themselves as incompetent, invoke intrusive Government monitoring and put their jobs in jeopardy. That is hardly an incentive to play along."
Critics ask why the Government should bail out supposedly solvent banks. Besides, nothing in the law forces banks that take public money to write down loans to feasible levels. Mr. Tarullo points out that the ruling party has a history of letting banks serving agriculture and construction -- its core supporters -- do as they want.
The legislation is vague, critics point out, relying on bureaucrats to fill in the blanks. That might have worked fine when the finance and other ministries were all powerful. But now they are largely discredited, and the ability of the bureaucrats to discipline private markets is dubious.
The threat is that insolvent banks, operating under the cover of a bogus accounting system and a compliant Government, will limp along, draining resources from productive parts of the economy. Mr. Tarullo paints a picture of continued drift.
Perhaps, Mr. Posen says, Japan's recent past is not prologue. Yes, Parliament should have forced banks that take public money to write down old loans and use the cash to issue new loans. But, he says, there are good reasons to believe all this will happen anyway.
He argues that the discipline of international capital markets, which have largely shut off Japan's banks, will force banks to take the Government bailout. Yesterday, three major Japanese banks were reported to be preparing applications.
Mr. Posen also predicts that these banks will be forced by public pressure and new political forces to pass along cash to worthy borrowers.
He points out that the law was not written according to Japanese custom by bureaucrats in the Finance Ministry but was drafted, at the request of Cabinet officials, by a younger generation of Parliament leaders.
American officials have been clamoring for the Japanese to clean up their bank mess -- no matter how. The bailout passed by the Parliament will waste lots of taxpayer money. It will not dispense justice. It will not by itself turn the Japanese economy around -- fiscal measures will also be needed. But by throwing serious money into blocked credit lines, the law takes an essential step toward ending Japan's immediate crisis.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL BRIEFING

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:

Democrat Is Gaining In Massachusetts Race
Democrats don't always win in Massachusetts. But mostly they do. So with less than two weeks to go to Election Day, can the Democratic candidate for governor, Attorney General Scott Harshbarger, overtake his Republican opponent, Acting Gov. Argeo Paul Cellucci?
He is closing in. 
 A month ago, Mr. Harshbarger was down 10 points or so in the polls. But now, according to the latest Boston Herald poll, he has cut that deficit in half.
Mr. Harshbarger has been hammering Mr. Cellucci hard recently, asserting in campaign advertising that the Acting Governor has yet to adequately explain how he could be some $700,000 in personal debt. Independent voters in particular appear to have responded favorably to the advertisement.
But Mr. Harshbarger still has a steep hill to climb. His voter base is shaky, with many Democrats lukewarm about his candidacy because they remember that he once politically challenged a Kennedy, and on another occasion aggressively investigated possible wrongdoing by some party members.
Equally difficult for Mr. Harshbarger, he must overcome the built-in advantage that Mr. Cellucci has as an incumbent running in economic good times. That advantage is enhanced considerably by the fact that the Acting Governor is a liberal Republican, and thus not all that ideologically different from Mr. Harshbarger.
 
Money and Message In Washington State
Going into this year's Washington State race for a United States Senate seat, many state and national Republican leaders insisted that their candidate, Representative Linda Smith of Vancouver, had a real shot at unseating the Democratic incumbent, Patty Murray. But would they put their money where their mouth is?
Not wholeheartedly, it turns out.
Ms. Smith has good conservative credentials -- strong enough, political analysts say, to guarantee her a hefty Republican vote. She also has a strong populist streak, which analysts believe will stand her well with independent voters.
But Ms. Smith is having trouble getting her message out.
Her outspoken support for campaign finance reform has come back to haunt her. Because she refuses to take many types of campaign contributions, she is running low on money and is unable to match her opponent's big television advertising campaign. The latest polls have Ms. Smith trailing by nearly 15 points.
Appeals for money to the Republican Senate Campaign Committee, run by Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, an outspoken opponent of campaign finance reform, have mostly been ignored. The committee could legally give Ms. Smith up to $540,000 but has sent only $17,500, without explaining why.
Frustrated Washington State party officials last week sent word to the national party, and to Mr. McConnell, that if they were not going to help the Smith campaign they should stop all money solicitations in the state.
On Monday, Ms. Smith announced that she had just been sent $100,000 by the Republican National Committee, a gift that she gladly accepted. The national committee can accept gifts from sources that Ms. Smith will not accept gifts from. How, then, could she accept such money?
Ms. Smith said it was not an issue for her because she did not know who gave the money to the committee, and thus there could be no quid pro quo on her part.
"The ultimate hypocrisy," Senator Murray shot back.
 
G.O.P. Candidate Is Adrift in Alaska
The Alaska governor's race has taken another topsy-turvy turn, one that very well might doom whatever slim chance the Republican nominee, John Lindauer, had.
A month ago, Republican leaders in the state questioned whether the party should continue to support Mr. Lindauer, given that there were so many confusing and unanswered questions about the source of his $2 million in campaign funds. He insisted that everything was above board, and the party leaders backed off.
But questions continued to arise, with a least one Alaskan filing suit in an effort to get a more detailed answer -- or, in the absence of one, to have Mr. Lindauer thrown off the ballot. Was there or wasn't there a secret financial source, something not permitted under Alaska law?
Mr. Lindauer, a retired newspaper publisher, insisted initially that he was spending his own money. Then he said it was his wealthy wife's money. Then he said he was broke. And so on.
On Tuesday, the Republican leaders announced that the party was withdrawing its support of Mr. Lindauer because of all the confusion and contradiction.
The party chairman, Tom McKay, said Mr. Lindauer would, of course, remain on the ballot, pending any court action on the citizen's suit. But he added that the party would "rally around in a big way" should a prominent Alaska Republican step forward to start a write-in campaign.
"This is not something we're having fun doing," Mr. McKay said. "But it's necessary to preserve the Republican Party as a viable institution in Alaska politics."
If past results in Alaskan elections for governor are any indication, there is not much viability to preserve. The last time a Republican won the office was 20 years ago, and political analysts say this year's Democratic incumbent, Tony Knowles, a moderate, has few re-election concerns, particularly in light of Tuesday's decision by Republican leaders.
Mr. Lindauer, a conservative, vowed to push on.
"I didn't lie about the source of my income," he said. "The party lied that I lied."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Global Distress Takes a Toll On the Results at Citigroup

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Citigroup Inc., the world's largest financial services company, reported a 65 percent drop in third-quarter earnings yesterday, reflecting the impact of trading losses in volatile global markets this summer that offset strength in its domestic consumer businesses.
The company, created by the merger of Citicorp and Travelers Inc. at the end of last month, reported profit of $729 million, or 30 cents a diluted share, for the three months ended Sept. 30. The results were close to analysts' expectations of 29 cents a share. Comparable combined earnings from the year earlier were $2.1 billion, or 96 cents a share, excluding a restructuring charge for job cuts at Citicorp. Including the charge, combined profits fell 51 percent. 
 On Oct. 8, Citigroup estimated that it would report earnings of $700 million for the quarter after it suffered hundreds of millions of dollars of trading losses from the slump in financial markets, particularly in Russia and developing counties.
"The real message here is the global consumer business seems to be doing quite well," even as the company "absorbs the body blows on the capital markets side of the business," said Judah Kraushaar, a banking analyst at Merrill Lynch.
John Keefe, president of Keefe Worldwide, a financial services consulting firm in New York, said, "It looks like putting all this Russia, emerging markets aside, the underlying businesses are either O.K. or have yet to deteriorate."
"Behind some of these dramatic losses -- these events of biblical proportions -- are some strong businesses," Mr. Keefe said.
The leaders of Citigroup tried to take the earnings slump in stride.
"Obviously, we're disappointed with the results," Sanford I. Weill, co-chairman and co-chief executive of Citigroup, said in an interview yesterday. But, Mr. Weill added, he and his colleagues are encouraged by the continuing strong performance in their consumer businesses and by the helpful steps taken by governments in recent weeks to stabilize international markets.
Mr. Weill cited Congress's agreement to provide further financing to the International Monetary Fund; the Federal Reserve's second interest rate cut, which he said showed clear understanding of the liquidity problems in markets, and Japan's plan to inject more than $500 billion to help revive its banking system.
He said, however, "I think we're still going to have lingering problems in the fourth quarter, but they won't be of the same kind of degree as the third quarter."
Not all of the turmoil has been bad for the company, Mr. Weill added, saying that it had caused some depositors to turn to larger institutions, like Citibank, the company's bank subsidiary.
Mr. Weill also said that the combined company was well positioned to take advantage of more difficult markets. The combined firm's equity strength, he said, would "prove very useful" as Citigroup came across opportunities to expand its own businesses or acquire other companies in those markets.
At a meeting with analysts yesterday, he and his co-chairman and co-chief executive, John S. Reed, set out how they were cutting costs to reposition Citigroup for the changes in financial markets, according to some who attended. In reply to analysts' questions, the two played up the potential for revenue growth and the benefits from cross-marketing of insurance, banking and brokerage products.
The two men also told analysts that results for 1999 should look good compared with those for 1997, according to Joan S. Solotar, a banking analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, who said that the leaders had projected a 15 percent average growth rate for the next five years.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE SOUTH;
3 G.O.P. Candidates for Governor Face Trouble

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 21

 BODY:
Part of the political legend of Fob James Jr., the pugnacious Republican Governor of Alabama, is that he likes to play from behind.
"Fob is a strong finisher," said Roger McConnell, the state Republican chairman. 
"He's just a fourth-quarter player," said Tom Blackerby, chairman of Conservative Christians of Alabama.
So as the clock ticks down in Mr. James's campaign for re-election, his allies are trying to convince voters -- and themselves -- that his predicament simply reflects the natural order of things. But even as the James camp brushes off poll after poll showing him trailing Lieut. Gov. Don Siegelman, other Republicans are getting nervous, and some sound downright defeatist.
"I'd be real surprised if he can pull this one out," said a prominent Republican strategist in Alabama, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Less than two weeks before the Nov. 3 election, Mr. James is not alone. In one of the surprises of this fluid election year, Republican candidates for governor are in tight races in three conservative Southern states that have voted increasingly Republican in recent years.
In South Carolina, polls have shown that the incumbent Republican, Gov. David M. Beasley, holds the thinnest of leads over his Democratic challenger, Jim Hodges, the former minority leader of the state House. And in Georgia, where Republican leaders have asserted that this will be the year they break the Democrats' 126-year lock on the Governor's office, Guy W. Millner, a Republican businessman, is running just ahead of Roy E. Barnes, a longtime Democratic legislator.
To some extent, the races hinge on local issues and dynamics, including the quality of the candidates. And the Republicans could win in all three states. But several authorities on Southern politics said today that the closeness of the races demonstrated that Southern Democrats were learning the lessons taught by their two most successful mentors, Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia and Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina.
The message, said Wayne Flynt, a historian at Auburn University in Alabama, is that there may still be enough core Democrats and swing voters in the South, including blacks and working-class whites, to reward Democrats who focus on issues like education, jobs and the economy.
"If the issues are all about social concerns, like abortion and school prayer and vouchers, Republicans win," Mr. Flynt said. "But Democrats can still succeed if they can make the case that they are the party of the common people, and that the Republicans are the party of big business and the wealthy."
Nowhere is that theory being tested more than in the Alabama race. In the last two years, Mr. James has earned a national reputation for his fervent support of school prayer and state autonomy from Federal control. But even diehard Republicans acknowledge that he has allowed Mr. Siegelman, a Democrat, to control the discourse of this campaign with a proposal for a lottery to finance education.
Four public polls taken in the first two weeks of October showed Mr. James behind by 5 to 13 percentage points. He has raised significantly less money than Mr. Siegelman and started his advertising campaign more than a month later. And Governor James has barely nicked Mr. Siegelman on what Republicans have perceived to be his most glaring liabilities, that he is too liberal for Alabama and too beholden to trial lawyers. National Republican officials consider Mr. James the most vulnerable of the 18 Republican governors seeking re-election.
In Alabama, Republican strategists are grumbling that Mr. James seems to not want his job that much, and that his seeming dispassion could hurt fellow Republicans in important races for the legislature and state Supreme Court. "There's a feeling that he's a drag on the ticket," the strategist said.
There is enough of an impression of inertia in the James campaign that its chairman, Mayor Emory Folmar of Montgomery, felt the need to energize the troops with a tough speech at a rally on Sunday.
"I haven't seen the fight in this campaign I'd like to see," Mr. Folmar was quoted in news accounts. He urged James supporters to resort to "some scratching, biting and clawing" in depicting Mr. Siegelman as a liberal.
But Mr. James has a history of making late dashes to victory, often with help from Christian conservatives whose enthusiasm does not always register in polls. In 1994, Mr. James trailed Gov. Jim Folsom by 10 percentage points in the polls with less than a week to go and came back to win by 1 percentage point. In the Republican primary this summer, he was forced into a runoff and was thought to be in peril but won by a convincing 12 percentage points.
In his race against Mr. Siegelman, Mr. James's most significant problem is the Democrat's popular lottery proposal, which would provide an estimated $150 million a year for merit-based college scholarships, pre-kindergarten programs and computers. A disciplined, if scripted, campaigner with an experienced staff, Mr. Siegelman has promoted the lottery relentlessly on the trail, in his advertising and in debates like the one here on Tuesday.
"I have proposed an education plan that will change education in this state forever," he said in that debate. "I say yes to a lottery. Fob James says no."
With the lottery a big success in two of Alabama's neighboring states, the Siegelman plan has placed Mr. James on the defensive. The Governor has responded with a three-pronged rebuttal. He has proposed a far less ambitious plan for college scholarships that would be financed with existing state money. He has argued that Mr. Siegelman will need to raise taxes to pay for his proposals, even with the lottery. And he has warned that the lottery would lead to other forms of legalized gambling.
In the last two weeks, Mr. James has run television advertisements that question Mr. Siegelman's integrity by showing his nose growing like an animated Pinocchio. One depicts a cockfight as the narrator asks, "Why should we believe Siegelman when he says that later he won't let his gambling friends sneak other games of chance into Alabama behind his lottery?"
James aides said that the campaign's polling suggests that the advertisements have narrowed the gap significantly in recent days. But it may be too late to reach swing voters like Brenda J. Crain, of Mobile, who owns a used car lot with her husband. Although she voted for Mr. James four years ago, Ms. Crain, 49, said she would vote for Mr. Siegelman this year because she agreed that Alabama should have a lottery to pay for education and because she had been embarrassed by some of Mr. James's pronouncements, like his contention that the Bill of Rights does not apply to the states.
"I'm normally a Republican so this is a hard choice," she said while shopping at the Bel Air Mall on Tuesday. "I don't think Fob James is a bad person but he's just a little more of a backwards type, and Alabama could use a better image. And with the lottery, people are going to gamble whether it's here or in Florida or Mississippi. The tax money should stay here in Alabama."
Natalie M. Davis, a political scientist at Birmingham Southern College, said that the lottery had become a wedge issue for Democrats. "We often think of wedge issues as abortion, prayer, that kind of thing," said Ms. Davis, a Democrat. "But what has happened here is that Siegelman has used the lottery to pull apart a predictable Republican constituency."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Technology Shares Help Nasdaq Market Advance Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Technology shares led the Nasdaq stock market sharply higher yesterday, while blue-chip companies saw a far more mild rise.
Paced by Microsoft, which rose 6 3/16 a share, to 106 7/16, the Nasdaq composite index climbed 2.17 percent, or 35.56 points, to 1,674.75. The Nasdaq index has surged 18 percent in the last two weeks. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 13.38 points, to 8,519.23, posting its sixth consecutive advance. More of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow were down than up and the average, which spent much of the day in negative territory, would have ended lower without the contribution of I.B.M.
Big Blue rose 4 13/16 a share, to 142 11/16, after reporting a 10 percent increase in third-quarter profits late Tuesday.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.99 points, to 1,069.92.
Several mergers announced recently -- the latest being the Newell Company's $5.8 billion deal yesterday for Rubbermaid -- have helped improve the climate on Wall Street lately, as has the re-emergence of credit for some borrowers.
"We're beginning to see some thawing out," said Peter J. Canelo, a domestic investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "I think we've turned the corner on the panic."
Mr. Canelo added that the options volatility index has registered distress in 23 of the latest 34 sessions, but none in the last week.
Alan Ackerman, chief strategist at Fahnestock, said that "mood, momentum and money-flow seem to be coming together" in the markets, particularly for Nasdaq stocks. In many cases, he said, those still sell for "a pittance" relative to earnings.
Some analysts suggested that the traditional year-end selling of battered stocks to establish losses for tax purposes seems to be occurring early this year, with bargain hunters already moving in to scoop up shares at their lowest prices.
Stocks are also getting a lift from generally favorable third-quarter corporate earnings, which have slightly surpassed expectations.
"We're seeing some pretty good numbers coming in," said Mary Farrell, senior strategist at Paine Webber. "The important thing is that the market continues in positive territory -- it's holding."
Treasury bond prices, which have been volatile for months as investors sought a safe haven from equities, were little changed yesterday.
Conoco's stock, being spun off by DuPont, was priced at $23 a share to raise $4.4 billion, the biggest new American issue ever in terms of dollar value. Those shares are scheduled to begin trading today.
Technology stocks, which dominate the Nasdaq index, were once again the standout performers among equities. Dell Computer rose 3 5/8, to 56 15/16; Cisco Systems climbed 3 1/2, to 57 5/8, and Intel jumped 2 1/2, to 87 1/16. Peoplesoft, though, dropped 6, to 19 3/4, following the company's projection of slower sales next year.
Among blue chips, drug stocks were strong, with shares of Merck, Eli Lilly, Schering-Plough, Warner-Lambert, and American Home Products gaining more than 2 points each.
But airline shares, prominently those in United Airlines, were lower. UAL, the parent of United, fell 3 7/16, to 62 15/16.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 745.18 million shares, with advancing issues barely outpacing decliners, 1,595 to 1,498.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Slow Session for Bonds
By Bloomberg News
 Bond prices were little changed yesterday as investors found few incentives to buy Treasury securities, with yields near three-decade lows and world markets stabilizing.
With yields already so low, "it makes it hard to believe we'll have a significant rally here," said Steve Guterman, who helps oversee $68 billion at American General Investment Management L.P.
Since the Federal Reserve surprised investors with an interest-rate cut six days ago, stocks have gained and investors have begun scouting for bargains in corporate bonds.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 10619/32 . The yield held steady at 5.07 percent.
Since August, when Russia devalued its currency, many investors shunned all bonds except Government-backed securities. Sales of risky securities by loss-ridden hedge funds and speculation the economy might tip into recession next year added demand for Treasury debt.
"Investors are now saying that maybe the economy isn't in such bad shape," said David Horner, a senior fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company.

HEADLINE: Outlook for Political Dynamics: More of the Same

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
As the 105th Congress cast its final legislative vote today, it stood identified less with any signature bill than with the paralysis of American politics near century's end.
For it was a year in which much of the partisan energies went into blocking initiatives, not passing them. 
 The Republicans stymied the Democrats' drive for regulation of health maintenance organizations, overhaul of campaign finance laws, and anti-tobacco legislation. And President Clinton took such a strong stand against tax cuts in the first year of a new government surplus that even Senate Republicans refused to embrace the tax-cutting fervor of their more ideological brethren in the House.
In part this represents the trade-offs of a government divided between a Democratic President and a Republican-controlled Congress. But in many ways the stalemate runs far deeper.
With the cold war gone, and the surplus changing the deficit politics that had defined the two parties for decades, Republicans and Democrats alike have been left with grappling for an agenda for the new millennium. And it is a quest that fractures both parties.
"There are all these books and articles that have been written about the end of things," said Bill Curry, a former domestic policy adviser to President Clinton, "the end of history, the end of ideology, the end of the business cycle. We're not at the end of ideology but we are at the end of the ideology of these two parties."
From the other side of the spectrum, in remarkably similar tones, Representative David M. McIntosh of Indiana, one of the conservative Republican firebrands of the House, said, "The leaders who took us into the majority, you get the sense they're coming up with stale ideas and are not focused on bringing the next agenda forward."
Both parties have been thrown off course not just by the changing times but also by the nation's antipathy to sweeping change in a period of prosperity. Mr. Clinton tried, and failed, to carry out a major overhaul of the nation's system of health care coverage early in his first term, only to see the voters turn over control of Congress to the Republicans.
Then Speaker Newt Gingrich and his fervent conservatives took their turn and tried to use a Government shutdown in 1995 to make Mr. Clinton accede to the Republican call for sweeping tax cuts and a scaling back of the Great Society programs. But a year later, their standard bearer was unable to capture the Presidency and Mr. Gingrich's House majority fell to 11 seats, one of the most precarious for either party this century.
"It's a time at which big ideas failed," said Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press. "Given those failures and given the fact that this is a time of relative tranquillity, it's hard to get people going on big ideas."
The response of the two parties has been a fallback to look-alike agendas and a politics of small gestures that gives neither a broad mandate.
"The ideal political place to be at the end of this millennium is to have Republican policy and Democratic language," said Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster. "That is the perfect place for the American people."
So in 1996 Mr. Clinton embraced the Republican idea of a balanced budget and then added grace notes on education and health care and the environment.
Going into this election, the Republicans have put forward no new Contract With America but instead are mostly running on the welfare overhaul and a balanced budget pact with a tax cut, which were the achievements of 1996 and 1997. Learning from Mr. Clinton's strategy of co-opting Republican issues, they agreed in the final spending bill of this session to $1.1 billion for new teachers in hopes of neutralizing the traditional Democratic advantage on the education issue.
Beyond that, sending his majority home to campaign with a final balloon-festooned rally, Mr. Gingrich also took credit for stopping Federal financing of needle-exchange programs for drug addicts. And in almost nostalgic tones, he said Congress had included some money for Ronald Reagan's cold-war-era dream of a Star Wars missile defense system.
But the final hours of the session put in sharp relief the fractures in the Republican Party that had haunted Congress all year, causing the House and Senate to fail to pass a budget for the first time since 1974 and costing Republicans the large $700 billion tax cut that House leaders proposed in early summer.
Conservatives took turns denouncing the Republican leadership in the final hours of the session while Mr. Gingrich fired back at his critics on the right, calling them a "perfectionist caucus" who lacked maturity. And today, he said the Republican Congress had failed to pass a major election-year tax cut "because the Senate blinked."
Of the issues looming for the next Congress, chief among them is insuring the solvency of the Social Security system for the baby boom generation. Mr. Gingrich and other House Republicans are vowing to push earlier and harder for a large tax cut. Mr. Gingrich said today that "you can be much bolder" in the year after an election.
The Democrats want to try again to regulate health maintenance organizations and overhaul campaign finance laws. And the economic turmoil in Asia and Russia could yet cause serious tremors in the American economy.
But there is little sign that the political stalemate will change. Most strategists are predicting that the November election will only reinforce the status quo and produce no large shift in the balance of power.
"People are more or less both content with national conditions and disgusted with national politics," Mr. Kohut said. "So there ain't much going on."
The struggle over whether to impeach Mr. Clinton is likely to distract him and consume much of the energy in Congress. It will also tie the President closely to the liberal Democrats who have been his strongest defenders, keeping him from being free to side with the Republican majority.
Adding to the likely polarization, Republicans may have to find other ways to placate conservative activists if they do not ultimately have the votes to remove Mr. Clinton from office.
In both parties the true battle for a new agenda is likely to come in the next Presidential race.
"The big serious political agendas are Presidential agendas," said William Kristol, the editor of The Weekly Standard, a conservative journal. "Clinton's not going to have one in 1999 and the Republican Congress isn't either. The interesting action will be in both parties in 2000."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Profits Strong at 3 Airlines, But T.W.A. Reports a Loss
Three of the country's largest airlines reported record third-quarter earnings from strong passenger traffic, the low cost of fuel and a strike at Northwest Airlines.
Earnings at American Airlines and U S Airways surpassed the expectations of Wall Street analysts, while earnings at United Airlines were slightly weaker than expected. Trans World Airlines, however, posted a surprising loss. Page C3. 

Three Oil Companies Report Losses
Shares of Texaco, the third-largest oil company, fell $2.75, or 4.48 percent, to $58.625, after it announced that earnings dropped 58 percent. Exxon, the nation's biggest oil company, said its profits declined 23 percent, and Amoco, the fifth-largest, reported its fourth consecutive quarterly loss, a reflection of the slump in oil prices that began a year ago. C8.
 
Wall Street Continues its Rally
A strong earnings report from Microsoft fueled a rally on the Nasdaq stock market, which climbed 2.17 percent, or 35.56 points, to 1,674.75. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 13.38 points, to 8,519.23, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.98 points, to 1,069.92. C9.
 
Brazil Grapples With Cash Squeeze
The economic crisis in Sao Paulo, the industrial nerve center of Brazil, has caused companies to consider paying workers the mandated extra month's pay in products, not cash. C4.
 
Judge to Rule Nov. 4 in AMP Suit
A Federal judge said he would settle the main legal dispute in Allied Signal's $9.7 billion takeover bid for AMP on Nov. 4. C3.
 
Americans Forget the Oil Embargo
Twenty-five years after an oil embargo proved that fuel supplies were neither reliable nor endlessly cheap, the United States has relinquished most gains made in conserving energy. Americans have returned to consuming nearly as much energy as ever. A1.
 
Several Surprises in Federal Budget
New details of surprises hidden in the $500 billion Federal budget deal emerged as the Senate passed the bill and President Clinton signed it into law. These included $750,000 for grasshopper research in Alaska, $250,000 for a lettuce geneticist in Salinas, Calif., and $1.1 million for manure handling and disposal in Starkville, Miss. A24.
 
Citigroup Disappointed With Profits
Sanford I. Weill, co-chairman and co-chief executive of Citigroup, admitted that he was disappointed with the 65 percent drop in third-quarter earnings. The decline was attributed to trading losses in global markets that offset strength in the financial services giant's domestic consumer businesses. Citigroup was created by the merger of Citicorp and Travelers, completed last month. C2.
 
Pollution Penalty Expected
The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to impose its biggest civil penalty ever in a likely settlement with manufacturers of heavy-duty diesel truck engines for violating clean air standards. A1.
 
Profits Increased 13% at Eli Lilly
Steadily rising sales of the antidepressant Prozac and the anti-schizophrenia drug Zyprexa created a 13 percent increase in profits at Eli Lilly in the third quarter. C8.
 
New Home Construction Fell 2.5%
Construction of new homes and apartments slipped 2.5 percent in September as the brisk pace of building cooled. C20.
 
Coca-Cola Buying 6 Bottlers
Coca-Cola Enterprises agreed to buy six domestic bottlers that had 1997 revenue of $365 million. The deals are worth a total of $770 million, including assumption of debt. C4.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: CONNECTICUT;
Kennelly Regrets Calling Party Support Weak

BYLINE: By JULIAN E. BARNES 

DATELINE: DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 21

 BODY:
Repesentative Barbara B. Kennelly, who told newspaper editors yesterday that she was disappointed with the support she had received from her party during her campaign for governor, backed away from those comments today, saying that she regretted her criticism but had no regrets about entering the race.
The state Democratic Party chairman said that Mrs. Kennelly's original remarks were driven by frustration with her own fund-raising efforts. As Mrs. Kennelly's position in the polls has tumbled, her campaign has had trouble raising money. And those poll numbers fell further today as Quinnipiac College released a poll showing Mrs. Kennelly trailing Governor John G. Rowland of Connecticut by 48 points. 
 In an interview on Tuesday with the editorial boards of The Advocate of Stamford and The Greenwich Time, Mrs. Kennelly said she had been "naive" and should have been more realistic about her chances to defeat Mr. Rowland. She also criticized the Democratic State Central Committee and its chairman, Edward L. Marcus, saying they had failed to raise money for herself and other Democratic candidates.
At a news conference here, Mrs. Kennelly said she regretted "criticizing anyone" during her meeting with the editorial boards. But in an interview earlier in the day her campaign manager, Jonathan W. Pelto, said the party needed to do more to help its nominees. "Whatever the outcome on Nov. 3, it's clear the Democratic Party needs to do more to rebuild its infrastructure and support its candidates," Mr. Pelto said.
According to the most recent financial disclosure statements, filed three weeks before the election, Mr. Rowland has $2.17 million on hand and Mrs. Kennelly has $348,000. Mr. Marcus said he had personally raised and donated $40,000 to Mrs. Kennelly's campaign.
But he added that the party's central committee, which organizes get-out-the-vote drives, could barely pay its bills, much less give money to candidates. Mr. Marcus said the party had not given money to an individual candidate since 1966. "It's a miracle we have been able to stay out of debt," Mr. Marcus said. Mrs. Kennelly's father, John M. Bailey, ran the state Democratic Party from 1946 to 1975, when the parties had a bigger role in getting their candidates elected.
The new poll, conducted from Oct. 13 to Oct. 19, showed Mr. Rowland leading Mrs. Kennelly 72 percent to 24 percent among likely voters. The survey had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.8 percent for likely voters, according to the poll's director, Douglas Schwartz.
Mr. Rowland, in an interview with the Connecticut Radio Network, said his strong showing in the polls reflected the strength of the economy, support for his administration's policies, and problems with Mrs. Kennelly's campaign.
"I think people are generally happy with the direction of the state, happy with their leadership and that is reflected in the polls," he said. The Quinnipiac College poll found that 83 percent of registered voters were satisfied with general conditions in Connecticut.
Mrs. Kennelly was in Danbury to criticize Mr. Rowland's proposal last year to cut rail service along the Danbury, Waterbury and Shoreline East lines. The candidate, who has said in the past that polls are important, said she was ignoring the new poll and concentrating on the election.
She said she did not regret entering the race. "I ran for the right reasons," she said, "to make sure Connecticut was first again in educating all its children, in having a good environment, and first in having a good transportation system."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
To Aid Players, Agents Ponder Forming League

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Fed up with unfruitful negotiations with owners and fearing a work stoppage that could last into 1999, agents for National Basketball Association players are looking into economic alternatives, including exhibition games and even creating their own league.
The discussion came during a meeting of the agents' advisory council in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday, where more than 20 player agents and 11 N.B.A. players gathered for nearly four hours. Billy Hunter, the union's executive director, also announced that it planned to organize exhibition games until the lockout is settled. 
 Patrick Ewing, the union president, will lead a meeting today that will be open to all players at Caesars Palace. From superstars like Michael Jordan, Scottie Pippen and Karl Malone to the journeymen Marty Conlon and Muggsy Bogues, about 200 players were expected to attend as the union tries to show a united front during the lockout.
Several agents predicted yesterday that there would be a dispute among the players over whether the players should decertify the union and risk a prolonged court battle with the N.B.A. Although decertification came up in the meeting, neither the players nor the owners gave it much credence at this point.
"I thought we'd be fighting, but it was the most harmonious agents meeting I've ever been to," said Bill Duffy, one of the 19 members of the union's agents advisory committee. "The deal the league has offered us is so bad there wasn't even a need to discuss it."
The meeting came two days after the union lost a ruling on its guaranteed contracts before John D. Feerick, the arbitrator who determined that the owners need not pay any players during the lockout. The decision affects 226 players with guaranteed contracts, which together total nearly $800 million in value.
Because of the ruling, the agents discussed alternative sources of income for players who may struggle financially.
All players are due to receive $25,000 checks Nov. 15 as part of the league's group licensing agreement, and Ewing said many of the wealthiest players would pass on those checks for one year, with lower-salaried players getting an extra $25,000.
"We plan to announce to the players that we're going to be in a position to provide financial support to those ballplayers who need it," Hunter said. "We intend to, with the assistance of many of the agents, put on games. So as long as the lockout continues, we intend to put on some games to help raise funds."
Hunter said an exhibition game tomorrow in Houston had already sold out a 10,000-seat arena at the University of Houston. Another game with many high-profile players was being planned for Las Vegas, perhaps to be televised on pay-per-view, and a third game was being planned for Japan.
Lines of credit have been obtained from two banks, Hunter said, and other professional sports unions have pledged loans.
The league has approved players' earning a living outside the N.B.A. until the lockout is settled.
"Of course, they're doing so entirely at their own risk," said Jeff Mishkin, the league's chief legal counsel. "If they injured themselves and were not able to play basketball, they're at risk of having their contracts terminated."
The players and the agents are also looking at an even more ambitious idea, the formation of a new league. A four- or five-person committee has scheduled a meeting for this morning to discuss economic alternatives for the players, said Marc Fleisher, an agent.
"It's in the very early stages," he said, "but we're ready to start talking to potential owners, broadcasters, investors, anybody out there that might make sense."
The possibility of an alternative to the N.B.A. for this season is remote, but several player agents did not discount the potential for next season. The idea was contingent on the league canceling the entire season.
"For the first time, there was serious discussion about the possibility that the whole season could be lost," said Steve Kauffman, an agent. "I don't think many of us believed that before. But with the way the owners have been behaving, it's now something we have to discuss and prepare for."
According to two agents, David Falk, the agent for Jordan and several other superstars, said he would approach Jordan to see whether he would be interested in such a venture as a new league.
"Well, Michael's going to be here tomorrow, so let's ask him about it," Falk said in the meeting, according to the agents.
"If Michael is involved, I'd bet it would work," one agent said.
Meanwhile, owners and players are not scheduled to meet for their next bargaining session until next week. Because representatives from all 29 teams' owners will be in New York next Wednesday for the league's board of governors meeting, the next talks could come as early as Tuesday.
At yesterday's agents' meeting, the subject of the owners' resolve was brought up often. Several players' agents, on condition of anonymity, said that NBC's relationship with the league was discussed at length. Along with TNT, the network signed a $2.6 billion deal with the N.B.A. in the fall of 1997, an agreement that guaranteed the owners $500 million in rights fees for this season.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Nomura May Trim Up to 2,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Japan's Nomura Securities Company plans a major job cut worldwide because of a substantial net loss for the six months ended Sept. 30, Kyodo news service quoted company sources as saying.
About 1,000 to 2,000 employees are expected to be dismissed, including workers at its United States and British units, which have suffered huge losses from the Russian financial crisis and real estate-linked securities. 
 Nomura, Japan's biggest brokerage house, is expected to make an official announcement of the job cuts along with its audited financial results for the second and third quarters on Thursday.
The United States and British subsidiaries are estimated to have suffered some $350 million in losses on their Russian Government portfolios. The American unit is also believed to have posted around $1 billion in losses related to loans to real estate companies.
Nomura Securities is expected to report a net loss of 200 billion yen ($1.5 billion) because of its overseas losses as well as 33.7 billion yen in evaluation losses on its Japanese securities holdings, which have been hurt by slumping Japanese share prices.
Nomura Securities is expected to lay off a large number of employees at the United States and British subsidiaries, which employ 3,000 workers. In Japan, where it employs 10,000 workers, Nomura will curb new recruitment and urge early retirement.

HEADLINE: Teachers in Miami Are to To Be Offered Edison Project Stock

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Stock options are usually reserved for high-paid executives or employees of high-tech start-up companies. But teachers in the for-profit Edison Project school in Miami will begin receiving them under a program believed to be the first of its kind.
The move was announced yesterday by the Miami Dade Public Schools, the teachers' union there and the Edison Project, the private company that runs one of Miami's public elementary schools and four dozen others around the country. 
 The move comes at a time of growing interest nationwide in finding new ways to reward teachers. Edison, a privately held start-up company that expects to go public in the next few years, provides a way for teachers and other school employees to benefit in the company's potential success. It gives them the right to buy stock at a relatively low price, no matter how high it might go.
"The basic idea is to give teachers a broader sense of ownership in the enterprise in which they are the key professionals," said Benno C. Schmidt Jr., Edison's chairman. "They are not giving up anything, but we want them to participate if Edison does well."
Pat Tornillo, executive vice president of the United Teachers of Dade, local 1974 of the American Federation of Teachers, applauded the new plan, calling it "the first time in the history of American education that teachers have become direct economic stakeholders in the public schools where they work."
"It's about time," Mr. Tornillo added.
Allan Odden, an expert in teacher compensation at the University of Wisconsin, said performance awards for teachers had begun to be offered in school districts around the country, including ones in Kentucky and North Carolina.
"This is a 90's phenomenon," Mr. Odden said.
But while he applauded such incentives, he said it was too early to say whether they would improve education.
Under Edison's Miami program, full-time staff members will have the right, though not the obligation, to buy Edison shares at a set "exercise" price during a 10-year period. Edison's board has said the stock price under the options would be no more than $6.15 a share.
If the stock price rises above that amount, the value of the options will rise, giving school employees a profit. If the stock price remains below the exercise price, the options will be worthless, but employees would not need to use them. Generally, companies set their stock option prices at levels that are expected to generate profits for those who hold them.

Computer Associates Plans L.I. Expansion

 BODY:

HEADLINE: METRO BUSINESS;
More Connecticut Jobless

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Unemployment in Connecticut rose to 3.9 percent in September, an increase of four-tenths of a percentage point from August, and the state lost 10,600 jobs, the State Department of Labor reported.
Salvatore DiPillo, the state's labor statistics supervisor, said on Tuesday that two-thirds of the job loss was a temporary result of the strike by Southern New England Telephone workers. 
 The largest job losses were reported in transportation, communications and utilities (6,500), services (2,500) and manufacturing (1,800).
Nonfarm jobs totaled 1,639,300 in September, up 17,600 from a year ago. The employment rate was down one percentage point from September 1997.
In September, average hourly wages were up 28 cents from August's figure to $15, not seasonally adjusted, and up 38 cents over the year.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk
