HEADLINE: POWER HUNGRY: A special report.;
U.S. Splurging on Energy After Falling Off Its Diet

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

DATELINE: ARVADA, Colo.

 BODY:
Twenty-five years after an oil embargo proved that fuel supplies were neither reliable nor endlessly cheap, the United States has given up almost all the gains it made in conserving energy. On average, Americans have returned to consuming nearly as much energy as ever before.
From 1973, when Arab oil producers choked off their shipments to the United States, through 1983, the nation reduced its energy consumption even as the population and economy expanded. Prodded by higher costs and led on conservation crusades by Presidents Richard M. Nixon, Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter, Americans learned to do more with less. 
 That effort is still yielding great benefits. Owners of older buildings and homes installed thicker insulation and tighter windows. As technology improved, every new home, factory and car came with far more efficient appliances, machines and engines than in the 1970's. But energy demand has risen so much since the mid-1980's that, next year, the Energy Department predicts, consumption per person will come to within 2 percent of the peak in 1973, before any of these energy-saving advances had begun.
Declining energy prices -- now lower in real terms than before the first embargo -- have made the difference. In the dollar-a-gallon era, why spend much time or money saving a gallon or a watt?
Evidence of the more energy-intensive life style is everywhere. Since the early 1970's, as the average household has shrunk by a sixth, the average new home has grown by a third. Even moderately priced homes are now stuffed with energy-hungry features, from central air-conditioning to Jacuzzis and security systems.
Look at families like T. C. and Michael McCracken and their year-old daughter, Lydia. The McCrackens, avid hikers, are far more willing than most Americans to shop for energy-saving appliances or ride the bus to work. But here in Arvada, outside Denver, standard features of their nearly completed tract home include ceilings so high that overhead fans, finding a new season and purpose, are required in winter to blow rising heat back down. With 2,600 square feet to fill, Mr. McCracken plans to install a home office, a home theater and a home brewery fed by its own gas line. What Mrs. McCracken calls a "killer kitchen" has all the standard appliances and the electrical capacity for more than a dozen others, plus room to seat a family of 10.
Energy use is rising even faster on the roads. Next year, Americans are expected to burn more fuel per person than in 1973, before the Government set mileage standards. More families have two earners, and the suburbs continue to sprawl, so Americans are driving more than ever. As for fuel economy, the growing popularity of light trucks -- minivans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks -- has begun to reverse two decades of gains.
The daily hour to hour and a half that Mrs. McCracken, a personnel manager, has spent commuting and running errands in her Dodge Caravan minivan will stretch by another half-hour once she moves. And Mr. McCracken will put more miles on his sport utility vehicle, an Isuzu Rodeo.
Corporate habits are going the same way. Businesses saved more energy than individuals did through the mid-1980's but have used the most extra energy ever since. Chemical producers, among the heaviest energy users, say that in the 1990's they have all but quit making improvements solely to save energy. Electric utilities are cutting reimbursements for installing more efficient heating, cooling, lighting and other equipment at work and at home.
Cheap, abundant energy has in fact produced great benefits, fueling an era of rising standards of living and dormant inflation. Lower demand from Asia has pushed oil prices down even further lately, with shortages unlikely for years.
Growing energy demand is a natural result. But it conflicts with the nation's declared goals of reducing dependence on imported oil and lowering carbon dioxide emissions, thought to cause global warming. It also requires the nation and its oil companies to spend billions of dollars laying pipelines through unstable regions, building drilling platforms in deep seas and defending foreign supplies.
Clearly, the nation relies more than ever on overseas oil. Imports account for a record 50 percent of consumption, up from 35 percent in 1973. Though a rising share comes from secure neighbors like Mexico and Venezuela, the United States still gets about 10 percent of its oil from the Persian Gulf, twice the level in 1973.
The rising use of fossil fuels has also raised the atmosphere's level of carbon dioxide. The Clinton Administration pledged at a conference in Kyoto, Japan, last December to cut these emissions. That is not a simple task, said Daniel Yergin, chairman of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. "Environmental concerns point one way and prices point the other way," he said.
President Clinton is now striving to put energy efficiency back on the nation's agenda. He asked Congress for $6.3 billion over five years, including $3.6 billion in tax incentives and $2.7 billion for research. Accelerating the introduction of electric cars and other technologies would make energy savings nearly painless, he argues. Administration officials note that improving technology has already allowed Americans to live better with far less energy than they would otherwise use. Since the mid-1980's, however, these advances have slowed.
Many corporate executives and members of Congress call global warming a distant peril with uncertain causes. They portray the Administration's plans as a costly threat to the nation's prosperity. They also discount the danger of rising imports, saying that free markets will relieve high prices or tight supplies by promoting increased output and efficiency. In a compromise, Congress allowed $202 million of the $473 million for research this year but nothing for tax incentives.
It was 25 years ago this month, and again in late 1978, that vengeful Middle Eastern oil exporters squeezed their supplies to the United States and raised prices worldwide. A nation that was virtually self-sufficient into the 1950's had become a petroleum captive. Gasoline prices soared, lines at the pump stretched beyond frustration and the economy fell into repeated recessions.
Americans turned down their thermostats and bought fuel-efficient Hondas, Datsuns and Toyotas. At work, they replaced millions of inefficient motors, lighting fixtures and generators. President Nixon called for a national effort on the scale of the making of the atomic bomb.
"Let us set as our national goal," he said, "with the determination of the Manhattan Project, that by the end of this decade we will have developed the potential to meet our own energy needs without depending on any foreign energy source."
President Carter, wearing a sweater in a televised speech to drive home his point, termed energy conservation the equivalent of fighting a war.
But traumatic memories of oil shocks have long been soothed by plentiful, low-cost supplies. At about $1 a gallon -- compared with $1.10, adjusting for inflation, in 1973 -- fuel is as cheap as ever. United States gasoline prices remain less than half those in Europe and Japan, where energy is heavily taxed. Americans consume more than twice as much energy per person as Europeans or the Japanese.
The Energy Information Administration predicts that, in the absence of efforts to curb growing energy use, carbon emissions from burning fuel will rise 33 percent from 1990 to 2010, while the President has pledged to lower them by 7 percent. The agency's experts scoff at the prospects of meeting that goal unless prices rise significantly.
"If you look at our actions rather than words, it's evident we don't care," said Dwight K. French, a specialist on consumption trends. "Only the next crisis will again make conservation a priority. End of discussion."
 
On the Home Front
More Square Feet And 'Vampires'
Here in Arvada, in the subdivisions carved into the sagebrush hills of Denver's suburbs, the McCrackens' new home will have far more efficient heating, air-conditioning and major appliances than the homes of 25 years ago. Modern weatherstripping and vinyl-sealed windows will help keep the Colorado cold out and the heat in. In energy consumption per square foot, the home of the late 1990's is the winner.
But not the overall champion. Since the early 1970's, the average size of a new home has risen to 2,100 square feet from 1,600, even as the average household has shrunk to 3 people from 3.6. "It's almost like the trend to sport utility vehicles," said Donn D. Eley, chief financial officer of Village Homes, the McCrackens' builder. "They can't build them big enough."
Home builders are also bringing to tract homes the expansive features once reserved for mansions. "Wow factors," they are called in the trade. In the $150,000-to-$300,000 range, the confined quarters of yesteryear just won't do.
Larger homes with fewer people but more things to plug in have pushed home energy consumption back to the levels of the 1970's. Residential energy consumption per person fell by a tenth from 1973 to 1983 but has since risen about as much.
Tighter Federal standards for homes and major appliances promise to save enough energy over the coming years to offset what goes to heat and cool larger homes. But then come the computers, videocassette recorders, dishwashers, clothes washers and dryers that have been using about 5 percent more energy a year since 1990. Early in the next decade, the Energy Department predicts, such appliances will consume even more energy than heating.
Many of these devices are always on, ready at the push of a button. Razors and electric toothbrushes have chargers, fax machines are poised to send and receive, televisions and videocassette recorders merely go dormant, not off.
Together, these items use more power than a refrigerator. "They're called vampires," said Arthur H. Rosenfeld, a senior adviser for efficiency at the Energy Department. "They suck electricity."
Central air-conditioning, in less than 40 percent of new homes in 1971, is now in more than 80 percent. Dishwashers have gone from luxuries, found in 19 percent of households in 1970, toward necessities, found in 57 percent as of 1996.
The standard ceiling height has risen to nine feet from eight, meaning more space to heat and cool. "Even though the efficiency of larger homes has improved," said Gopal Ahluwalia, research director for the National Association of Home Builders, "the total volume, the use of glass, the fireplaces and the appliances lead to higher energy consumption. They will not buy a home without these energy-inefficient features."
As Coloradans who believe weekends were made for hiking and cross-country skiing, the McCrackens, trim 31-year-olds, say they would like to live greener. To save water and energy, they plan to pay about $300 extra for a high-efficiency washer and dryer. Mr. McCracken has even joined the declining 5 percent of Americans who ride mass transit -- for him a bus -- to his job as a consultant and programmer for I.B.M.
But their new house, like many today, is another story. Join the McCrackens in the Wyndham Park subdivision as they open the door to a 2,600-square-foot model home like the one they are buying nearby for $270,000. A towering entryway and its clerestory windows tilt their gazes upward. The two-story, 21-foot spaces continue on into the living room and the family room.
"What I love about this is the high ceilings," Mrs. McCracken volunteered. "I know they are terribly inefficient. But it does make it seem so spacious."
Her husband was nodding as Jack Zelkin, a senior marketing executive with the builder, listed the features. Mr. McCracken was already making plans to take advantage of the upgraded phone, cable and data wiring, for internal video and computer networks, that became standard a year ago, even in homes costing less than $150,000.
Saving energy has become a dormant issue, said Mr. Zelkin, who was once an energy-efficiency expert for the local utility.
"I'm a tree-hugging, granola-eating, environmental zealot," he said. "But if you give these buyers a choice between a Jacuzzi tub or extra insulation, they'll take the Jacuzzi tub every time."
 
On the Road
Traveling Farther, And Less Efficiently
Americans are not only living in spacious new homes. They're also living in their cars.
From her home in Lakewood, another Denver suburb, Mrs. McCracken has driven her minivan about 20 minutes to Golden to drop off her daughter at day care. Then it is 10 minutes back to her office in Lakewood, at Harveys Wagon Wheel Hotel/Casino. Or, a couple of times a week, she drives 20 minutes to the casino itself in Central City.
After work, Mrs. McCracken reverses the pattern, often adding a stop at the King Soopers grocery store, the Blockbuster video store or the cleaner's.
From her new house, it will be 15 minutes more each way, meaning that she will spend up to two hours in the car every day.
Tens of millions of T. C. McCrackens who have entered the work force have become a prime factor pushing energy use for travel up 12 percent for each American since 1983, back to the previous peak in 1978. In 1975, only 47 percent of American women with children younger than 18 were working or looking for work. By 1997, it was 72 percent.
Many households have almost enough cars to create their own traffic jams. Nearly one in five households has three or more cars, up from about one in 25 in 1969.
Commuters of both sexes also live farther from work. The average commuting distance grew by more than a third from 1983 to 1995, to 11.6 miles, even as car-pooling and the use of mass transit declined.
While covering more miles, Americans are getting fewer miles per gallon now that they are buying nearly equal numbers of cars and light trucks. Back in 1975, light trucks accounted for only a fifth of sales.
Cars are meanwhile becoming more powerful. Auto makers that once concentrated on building leaner, more efficient models have instead been adding the muscle that customers crave. Average horsepower has risen to 156 in 1996 from 99 in 1982 -- and the time needed to zoom from zero to 60 has fallen to 10.7 seconds from 14.4. And as speed limits have increased, those cars are using still more energy.
As vice president for operations at A.A.A. Colorado, Vickie W. Stark's job is to encourage travel. But even she decided she was spending too much time behind the wheel.
Her husband, a computer network manager, had followed her in assignments from Washington to Florida to Cheyenne, Wyo., where they bought a home north of town. When Ms. Stark got a job in Denver in 1995, he refused to budge.
And so Ms. Stark began driving more than two hours each way, or 127 miles, not counting her monthly one-day round trips to each of six offices elsewhere around the state.
A few months after she began the long haul from Cheyenne, Ms. Stark made a habit of calling her husband and two children on her car phone just as she was passing the exit for Windsor, Colo., the halfway point. "If we lived here, I'd be home," she always said.
In September 1996, they moved again -- to Windsor. As a family, they did not save any driving, but they did redistribute it. Her husband now has a 52-mile trip north, and Ms. Stark a 63-mile trip south.
All Ms. Stark has sacrificed by moving are bragging rights to the longest trip to work. Her neighbors next door and just across the street also work in Denver.
 
In the Factory
Energy Conservation A Lower Priority
Three times a week, 100-car trains more than a mile long arrive brimming with coal at the Celanese Ltd. chemical plant near Pampa in the Texas Panhandle. The trains dump their contents into chutes that form a pile 10 stories high. Coal dust dances in the flatland winds.
The coal is burned to boil water, providing the heat for producing chemicals like acetic acid, which is used in clothing fibers and plastic parts. The plant also uses enough electricity to power a city of more than 50,000. In one of the most energy-hungry industries, Pampa makes chemicals that are twice as energy intensive per pound as the Celanese average.
The plant, which opened in 1952, initially treated energy as if it were as cheap and plentiful as the air. Steam and heat were simply vented.
The oil embargoes of the 1970's brought a new outlook. Steam used in one process was rerouted to other processes. As a result, Pampa and other Celanese plants raised their energy efficiency 2 percent to 3 percent a year through the 1980's.
But in the 1990's, with lower energy prices reducing the payoffs, they have improved at less than half those rates, if at all. "The emphasis is simply elsewhere these days," said Thomas Parker Jr., managing director for tax policy and energy at the Chemical Manufacturers Association.
Across all businesses, industrial and commercial energy use fell 18 percent from 1973 to 1983, then jumped 37 percent by 1997. The growing corporate appetite for energy comes despite the economy's shift from smokestack industries like steelmaking to software and entertainment.
Managers in many industries say they achieved the easiest savings long ago. "We picked the low-hanging fruit first, in the 70's and 80's," emphasized Edward E. Quick, the environmental manager for Celanese. "As we move into the 1990's, we're finding the available technology much more costly."
Amory B. Lovins, whose Rocky Mountain Institute promotes energy efficiency, will hear none of it. He rattles off a half-dozen technologies like computerized controls that he says the chemical plants have failed to adequately exploit. "When the Celanese guys say you're running out of low-hanging fruit, the only thing I can say, based on the experience of people in this industry, is that the fruit is bushing up around our ankles."
Riley R. Kothmann, who runs the Pampa plant, has some ready answers. His tour includes a room where walls of dials and meters have been succeeded by banks of computer screens and controls.
But at times, it seems, fruit from higher branches drops on plant supervisors' heads. Even without reaching for energy savings, they find, the savings often land on them.
Compelled by law to contain emissions, Pampa's technicians found that those emissions could go back through a turbine to raise the plant's electricity production by nearly 10 percent. Or there was the time three or four years ago when managers began wrapping insulation around the joints where pipes are bolted together. "Pampa just had a tradition of not doing it," Mr. Kothmann said. "It's so much easier to continue doing things the way you used to."
To meet the goals of the Kyoto treaty for reducing emissions, Celanese executives say they would have to improve their energy efficiency by 3 percent a year through 2010, or as rapidly as in the 70's and 80's. All the technology they know of cannot meet that goal unless they cut production, said R. David Damron, the company's director for Government affairs. If Washington insists, he said, "you're going to stifle growth."
Celanese is still hedging. In early June, a company energy committee was assigned to find ways of meeting the goals, whatever the costs. The next step will probably be to find ways of doing the suggested projects at manageable costs. Mr. Kothmann, a member of the committee, recalls that environmental controls expected to cost $800 million a few years ago were delivered for less than $300 million. "Our experience has shown that we can achieve much more for much less than we anticipated it costing us," he said.
Energy use is rising in corporate offices as well as plants. Like homes, they have far more efficient heating, lighting and cooling, but also far more electronics.
Electric utilities have cut their support for installing more efficient equipment to $1.9 billion in 1996 from $2.7 billion in 1994. They say they cannot afford these programs in the competitive new era of deregulation.
Consolidated Edison, which serves New York City and most of Westchester County, cut its efficiency program to $31 million last year from $125 million in 1993 and has now eliminated it. Customers had been rewarded for deeds like installing more efficient appliances and compact fluorescent light bulbs instead of standard incandescents.
In its place, Con Ed, with state backing, plans to spend $25 million to $30 million a year on programs including low-cost loans for companies to develop more efficient electrical products and incentives to help them sell these products more cheaply.
"For less of an incentive per light bulb, appliance or motor, you can get a lot more in energy savings," contended Stephen Pertusiello, the company's program manager for market transformation.
But Peter A. Bradford, the chairman of the New York State Public Service Commission from 1987 to 1995, said Con Ed's case was at best uncertain. "You are replacing a known and proven set of programs with speculation," he said.
 
In the Political Arena
Calls for Action Face Challenges
Presidents going back to Richard Nixon have tried to arrest the nation's growing energy use. In the face of the 1973 oil embargo, he urged the nation to turn down its thermostats, form car pools and more. He announced that December that the lights on the national Christmas tree would be kept off. The next month, he signed the Emergency Highway Conservation Act, setting a speed limit of 55 miles an hour.
The first fuel-efficiency standards for cars took effect in 1975, requiring the average to double, to 27.5 miles a gallon, over a decade. By 1977, Jimmy Carter was promoting the search for renewable sources of energy like sunlight, wind, wood and wastes. He called his conservation campaign "the moral equivalent of war."
Then, in 1978 and 1979, another round of production cuts by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, compounding shortages caused by American price controls and regional allocations, brought the gas lines back. More than half the nation's gas stations were closed during the first summer weekend in 1979.
As gasoline climbed by 1981 to $2.05 a gallon in today's dollars, the nation began its most successful peacetime conservation effort. Americans used 43 percent less energy for every dollar of gross domestic product in 1986 than at the peak in 1972. From 1987 through last year, energy use per dollar of output declined by only an additional 8 percent.
By the mid-1980's, OPEC was in disarray and energy prices had declined. President Ronald Reagan cut back conservation and renewable-energy programs. The rural speed limit was raised to 65 miles an hour.
This decade brought a reminder that foreign oilfields have their risks. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 provoked a stock market selloff and a run-up in energy costs that contributed to the decade's only recession, the third in a row that came after oil supplies were pinched.
President Clinton, taking office in 1993, asked Congress to raise taxes on all fuels, including coal, by the equivalent of a dime a gallon. He got 4.3 cents on motor fuels only. In 1995, Congress repealed the national speed limits, and most states set their own at 65, 70 or even 75.
Over the last year, President Clinton has sought to make energy efficiency a renewed national priority. But to keep down the costs of reducing emissions, the United States plans to achieve only about a quarter of the required reductions itself. The trading of emissions rights would allow America to pay other nations to achieve the rest.
At home, the White House wants to promote advances in electric cars, renewable energy and the like. "My gut is, we will see the introduction of these new technologies very quickly," said Ernest Moniz, the Under Secretary of Energy, whose responsibilities include the efficiency programs. With much of the technology already available, he said, "We're not waiting for some magic bullet."
Republicans in Congress have portrayed the Kyoto accord as a dangerous effort to shape energy policy by raising false environmental fears. It leaves out developing nations, they say, and by requiring drastic energy savings, it threatens the United States with job losses resulting from much higher costs than the Administration acknowledges. Chuck Hagel, the Nebraska Republican who led the Senate's delegation to Kyoto, says that for all the risks of growing dependence on imported oil, "The answer is not just to say we're going to lower everybody's standard of living."
In the face of such opposition, President Clinton has not yet sought Senate ratification, saying that he, too, wants to include developing nations. But Europe and Japan are clamoring for the United States to take action, and the Administration has promised to submit the treaty next year.
Conservation is now so unpopular that its advocates shun the label. "Use the term efficiency," said Mr. Lovins at his Rocky Mountain Institute headquarters in Old Snowmass, Colo. "Conservation to a third of Americans means doing less, worse or without. It means privation, discomfort and curtailment."
If the cause of energy conservation has a last, remote redoubt, it is his stone-and-glass compound 7,100 feet high on the western flanks of the Continental Divide. There, he shows off an indoor tropical forest, luxriant with pink and yellow bougainvillea and a banana tree that has yielded 26 crops. Despite temperatures as low as 47 degrees below zero, he has no heating bills and no furnace. Instead, he has triple weatherstripping and heat-trapping windows and walls.
Technological efficiencies, or what Mr. Lovins calls negawatts, can capture energy far more cheaply, in his view, than spending billions to build more power plants or produce more oil from remote or politically volatile regions.
With energy prices so low, however, some in Washington say that high demand is only a sign that free markets are working in everyone's best interests. "Those who have an energy fetish argue that saving energy is more important than saving money or time," said Fred L. Smith, president of the Competitive Enterprise Institute there. Low energy prices allow more people to afford air-conditioning and cars, he says. "If we raise the price of energy, we will push some people back onto the buses."
But just as open-heart surgery is far more traumatic than regular exercise and a low-fat diet, other experts say that an abrupt response to another oil shock or environmental crisis could make the earlier discipline of gradual energy savings seem mild.
For Joseph J. Romm, who until recently ran the Energy Department's efficiency programs, it is only a question of when the nation will return to conservation, not if. Contending that the world's oil supplies will eventually tighten and temperatures rise, he said, "Ten years or 15 years from now, people will be desperate to take action."

"Erasing the Gains"
An Arab oil embargo 25 years ago compelled the United States to make conservation a priority. Now, after several oil crises, energy is once again cheap. The average American uses about as much as before the first embargo.
 
1973 -- The Arab oil embargo, begun during the Yom Kippur War, demonstrates OPEC's power. A new era of scarcity, favoring oil producers, begins. Oil prices eventually quadruple.
 
1974-75 -- To conserve energy, Congress approves a speed limit of 55 miles an hour and enacts fuel-efficiency standards.
 
1979-80 -- Revolution in Iran and Iran's war with Iraq limits oil shipments, sending prices up.
 
1986 -- OPEC's production quotas fail in the face of weak demand. Oil exporters flood the market and prices collapse. The oil industry begins a sharp contraction. But lower prices encourage greater consumption.
 
1990-91 -- The Persian Gulf war begins with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, a threat to Saudi Arabia as well. Oil prices jump, contributing to a global recession.
 
1997-98 -- The world economic crisis reduces oil demand. Prices, adjusted for inflation, fall in the summer of 1998 to 25-year lows.
 
Energy use has risen close to the levels of the 1970's as oil has become cheaper. Graph tracks energy use per person, in millions of B.T.U.'s, from 1970 to 1997. "Different Places, Different Paces"
Energy costs in the United States are much lower than in Europe or Japan, which helps explain why Americans consume far more energy per person than the Japanese or Europeans. Even though the United States has made greater gains in efficiency, improvement has slowed in the 1990's and its economy uses energy much more inefficiently than other industrial nations.

"Living Larger"
In the 1990's, environmentalism has been a favored cause. But Americans are using almost as much energy as ever before. Homes are larger, requiring more energy to heat, cool and run more appliances. On the road, fuel consumption is rising even faster. Industry is also using more energy, but thanks to big efficiency gains in the 1980's, it is still consuming less than two decades ago after adjusting for growth in output.

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1091 words

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: NEW JERSEY;
Democrat in Lead as Interest in Scandal Cools

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

 BODY:
There were days, not long ago, when it looked as though United States Representative Steven R. Rothman's Congressional race in New Jersey's Ninth District might turn into a referendum on President Clinton's libido.
Mr. Rothman, a first-term Democrat, is a member of the House Judiciary Committee and was one of a handful of representatives selected as targets by the National Republican Congressional Committee, which hoped that the aftershocks of the Clinton scandal might topple vulnerable legislators. 
 After Kenneth W. Starr's report was released in August and President Clinton's videotaped grand jury testimony was released on Sept. 17, Mr. Rothman found himself besieged with constituents' questions about Mr. Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky and about the impeachment hearings.
"People would come up and ask me about it on the street, when I went to the supermarket, at my children's soccer games," said Mr. Rothman, 46, a divorced father of two.
But as the frenzy of summer faded into the fall, interest in the scandal has cooled. Polls of voters across the country have shown that Mr. Clinton's troubles are not considered an important issue in local elections.
In fact, some Democrats around the country are having success defending the President. Former Representative Jay Inslee, a Democrat running for a Congressional seat in Washington State, has been gaining ground since he began running a television commercial that links his opponent to the Republican leadership.
"Rick White and Newt Gingrich shouldn't be dragging us through this," Mr. Inslee says in the 30-second commercial. "Enough is enough."
Polls show that New Jersey's voters agree with the rest of the nation on Mr. Clinton. Mr. Rothman's challenger, Steven Lonegan, had been one of the first Republicans to run campaign commercials calling for Mr. Clinton to resign, but now he has dropped those advertisements.
Instead, Mr. Lonegan has shifted the focus of his campaign to social issues. Mr. Lonegan has called for abolishing affirmative action programs and cutting back foreign aid, and has criticized Mr. Rothman as a "big-spending liberal" because he has not supported bigger tax cuts.
As the campaign heads into its final two weeks, Speaker Newt Gingrich is scheduled to make his second fund-raising appearance on behalf of Mr. Lonegan, which could evoke the Contract With America, the platform that helped an army of conservative Republicans seize control of the House in the 1994 election.
"It looks like an odd strategy to run a campaign on conservative, very right-wing ideas in what is a very moderate district," said Cliff Zukin, chairman of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.
Voters' reactions to these themes are noteworthy because New Jersey, and the Ninth District in particular, is viewed by many political analysts as a barometer of working-class and suburban voters. The district, which stretches from Englewood Cliffs south through 37 towns in Bergen and Essex Counties, has a solid core of registered Democrats, and in 1996 its voters favored Mr. Clinton over Bob Dole by a 2-to-1 margin.
Mr. Lonegan, who was raised in Ridgefield, thinks that the district will respond to his platform of laissez-faire economic policies and a return to a more stable social order. He has promised to fight to restrict abortion, allow school prayer and "fight for the values that made this country great."
As the Mayor of Bogota (population 7,900), he cut the budget by combining several departments and angered the city's police union by rejecting a 5 percent pay raise he considered exorbitant.
Mr. Lonegan's beliefs about reining in government were shaped by his own experiences as a client of the New Jersey Commission for the Blind. A degenerative eye disease called retinitis pigmentosa rendered Mr. Lonegan legally blind in his early 20's. As he was learning to cope with the disability two decades ago, one counselor from the commission actually discouraged him from seeking a job, he said, and argued that it would be easier for him to remain on public assistance.
Mr. Lonegan shunned that advice, earned an M.B.A. in marketing, found a job at a cabinet manufacturing company, and eventually bought the company with a $3,000 loan from his mother. The business, Kitchens Plus of Maywood, now employs 35 workers.
"The government is full of a lot of liberals who think they are doing a lot of good, but what they're really doing is cutting your heart out, encouraging you to be dependent," said Mr. Lonegan, 43, who is married and a father of two. "The institutions of family, church and the small-business community will outproduce anything government can do."
Mr. Rothman portrays Mr. Lonegan as an ideologue, calling him a "right-wing radical who is out of step with the people of this district."
Mr. Rothman succeeded Democrat Robert G. Torricelli, who left the Ninth District seat in 1996 to run a successful campaign for the Senate. He has been has a steadfast defender of abortion rights and voted for bills that provided Federal financing for 100,000 additional police officers and 100,000 additional teachers.
Mr. Rothman has also aligned himself with many of Mr. Clinton's policies: voting for a White House plan to modernize schools with no-interest Federal loans, and supporting the President's promise to use the budget surplus to bolster the Social Security system rather than to use the money for large tax cuts.
Mr. Rothman said he is proudest of the work he did during the budget negotiations, and says he encouraged White House officials to include an education tax credit in the plan that produced the first Federal surplus in decades.
If re-elected, Mr. Rothman said, he would focus on pocketbook issues like H.M.O. reform and Federal aid to improve New Jersey's rail and transit lines.
But Mr. Rothman, a lawyer and former Bergen County Surrogate Court judge, still refuses to discuss how he might vote on Presidential impeachment. He said he disapproves of Mr. Clinton's conduct, but has not heard enough evidence to decide what punishment, if any, is appropriate.
Internal polls by both campaigns show that Mr. Rothman has a sizable lead in the race. But Mr. Lonegan, who has been campaigning door to door since August, and has visited more than 21,000 homes in the district, said the Clinton scandal may depress voter turnout among Democrats and allow him to prevail. "I think we can put together enough other voters to win this race," Mr. Lonegan said.

HEADLINE: Three Large Oil Companies in U.S. Report Weak Results

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The Exxon Corporation and Texaco Inc. reported double-digit drops in earnings for the third consecutive quarter yesterday, and the Amoco Corporation reported its fourth consecutive quarterly loss, a reflection of the slump in oil prices that began a year ago.
Earnings at Exxon, the biggest oil company in the United States, fell 23 percent. Earnings dropped 58 percent at Texaco, the third-largest company, and 54 percent at Amoco, the fifth largest. 
 "Everyone in the oil production game just got clobbered, and will continue to get clobbered until prices recover," said Rosario Ilacqua, a Rothschild Inc. analyst.
The Chevron Corporation and the Atlantic Richfield Company are expected to report today.
Crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange averaged $14.15 a barrel in the third quarter, 28 percent less than in the 1997 quarter, when the average was $19.79. It was the lowest quarterly average price since the third quarter of 1986.
The companies reporting yesterday had bigger declines in earnings in the third quarter than in the second because returns from sales of chemicals or fuels fell.
The Asian recession reduced chemical demand at the same time new plants began production, creating a glut that pushed down profit margins. Prices for ethylene and propylene, two of the most widely used petrochemicals, fell by 30 percent to 35 percent on the Gulf Coast during the quarter, according to ICIS-LOR, a pricing agency.
European and Asian refiners also sent more fuel to the United States when they could not sell it in Asia, raising supplies and lowering profit margins in North America, analysts said.
"There's plenty of gasoline around, and not much demand," said James Van Alen, an analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc.
Exxon, based in Irving, Tex., earned $1.4 billion, or 58 cents a diluted share, compared with $1.82 billion, or 73 cents, in the 1997 quarter. The company was expected to earn 56 cents, the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. Revenue fell 12 percent, to $28.78 billion from $32.75 billion.
Exxon's decline was much smaller than that of its rivals, including Texaco and Amoco. The company's success at cost-cutting lets it make as much as 25 percent higher returns on investors' capital than its competitors, analysts said.
Exxon shares fell $1, to $75.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Texaco, based in White Plains, said earnings before gains and a charge dropped to $208 million, or 37 cents a share, from earnings of $490 million, or 90 cents, a year earlier. The company had been expected to earn 41 cents a share. Revenue fell 31 percent, to $7.71 billion from $11.09 billion.
Texaco shares fell $2.75, to $58.625.
Amoco, based in Chicago, said earnings fell to $295 million, or 31 cents a share, from $635 million, or 64 cents a year earlier. Amoco was expected to earn 32 cents a share.
Revenue fell 17 percent, to $7.49 billion from $8.98 billion. Amoco, which gets a bigger percentage of its income from chemical sales than most of its rivals, also said chemical sales fell.
Amoco shares fell 56.25 cents, to $52.1875.

HEADLINE: Bell Atlantic Narrows Loss; U S West Earnings Are Flat

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the regional phone company serving the East Coast, posted a sharply narrower third-quarter loss of $8.1 million yesterday, surpassing Wall Street forecasts amid growth in high-speed data and mobile-phone services. And another regional Bell, U S West Inc., which is based in Denver, reported flat earnings despite a strike.
Bell Atlantic, based in New York, lost the equivalent of 1 cent a diluted share after $1.1 billion in one-time charges to cover an employee buyout program, expenses from its merger last year with the Nynex Corporation and the reduced value of investments in the slumping Asia region. The company disclosed the charges last week. 
 In the quarter a year earlier, the company recorded a larger deficit of $80.1 million, or 5 cents a diluted share, also because of one-time charges.
Without the charges this year, Bell Atlantic said, third-quarter profit would have been $1.09 billion, or 69 cents a diluted share.
The results slightly beat the expectations of analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation of 68 cents a diluted share in the quarter. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Bell Atlantic shares rose 68.75 cents, to $50.0625.
Revenue grew to $7.91 billion from $7.37 billion, buoyed by a 31 percent increase in sales of high-speed data services to businesses, a 28 percent rise in sales of mobile-phone services and a 16 percent increase in sales of optional phone services, like caller ID. Bell Atlantic also reported 4.5 percent growth in the number of new telephone access lines bought by customers.
Bell Atlantic said last week that it would write down the value of its stakes in an Indonesian wireless company and a Thai telecommunications venture. Both are in countries that have been hard hit by Asia's economic turmoil. The charges also reflect the cost of enticing 5,200 workers to retire early as a result of the company's merger with Nynex.
Earnings at U S West were nearly unchanged in the third quarter despite a crippling strike.
The company earned $379 million, or 75 cents a share, compared with $380 million, also 75 cents a share, for the similar quarter a year ago.
The earnings report was based on a comparison of comparable data in the third quarter a year earlier, to account for the spinoff of the Media One Group on June 12.
Solomon D. Trujillo, president and chief executive of U S West, acknowledged that the work stoppage, which lasted 15 days, hurt the company's ability to provide new service to customers, but he said the company had caught up with most of the backlog.
More than 34,000 workers in 13 Western states went on strike in August over a new bonus plan that set work standards and over complaints of excessive overtime.
Shares of U S West's rose 56.25 cents yesterday, to $56.625, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 24, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about the Bell Atlantic Corporation's third-quarter earnings referred incorrectly to its early retirement program. The program began in 1994 as part of a labor settlement, and the costs associated with it had no connection with the merger of Bell Atlantic and the Nynex Corporation last year.

HEADLINE: 3 Major Airlines Report Record Profit for the Quarter

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
Cashing in on strong passenger traffic, low fuel prices and a strike at Northwest Airlines, three of the country's largest airlines reported record third-quarter earnings yesterday, while a fourth -- Trans World Airlines -- posted a surprising loss.
The mostly strong results seemed to ignore recent investor worries that a weakening economy would result in a decline in air travel. But executives at several of the carriers also expressed concerns about the future and said they were considering scaling back their planned growth next year, when the number of new airline seats is expected to rise faster than economic growth for the first time since the early 90's. 
 "Nobody is singing the blues at the domestic carriers," said Kevin C. Murphy, who follows the airline industry at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York, "but everybody is cautious."
Earnings at American Airlines and US Airways, the second- and sixth-largest carriers in the country, easily surpassed the expectations of Wall Street, while earnings at United Airlines, the nation's largest, were slightly weaker than expected because of its large exposure in Asia. The three carriers' figures were in line with strong results reported in the last week by Delta Air Lines and Continental Airlines.
Indeed, of the country's major airlines, the only disappointments have been at Northwest, which suffered a worse-than-expected loss from the pilots' strike last month, and T.W.A., which has been struggling to regain its equilibrium.
Most airline stocks declined yesterday. United's parent company, UAL, was down $3.4375 to $62.9375; AMR, parent of American, closed at $57.875, down 6.25 cents; US Airways fell $1 to $54.8125, and T.W.A. was down 87.5 cents, closing at $4.5625.
AMR said its net income grew 34 percent in the quarter to $433 million, or $2.49 a diluted share, compared with $323 million, or $1.78 a share, in the similar period last year. Wall Street had expected $2.32 a share.
The company's revenue grew 7.2 percent, to $5 billion, compared with $4.7 billion in 1997.
Gerard J. Arpey, AMR's chief financial officer, said the quarter was the best in the company's history, and the sixth consecutive record. He added that the Northwest strike and another at Air Canada increased AMR revenue by $50 million in the quarter, $16 million of which was offset by the cancellation of about 1,000 American flights as a result of Hurricane Georges.
From July to September, AMR bought back $500 million worth of its stock, and the company's board recently authorized another $500 million buyback.
US Airways reported net income for the quarter of $142 million, or $1.51 a diluted share, compared with $187 million, or $1.82 a share last year. But on an operating basis, its earnings grew 20 percent to $140 million, or $1.49 a share, from $117 million, or $1.14 a share. Analysts polled by First Call had estimated $1.43 a share.
Revenue rose 4.4 percent, to $2.2 billion from $2.12 billion last year, as the carrier said its planes were filled to record levels in each of the quarter's three months.
UAL said earnings rose 3.4 percent to $516 million, or $3.71 a diluted share, compared with $499 million, or $3.75 a share in the period last year. Revenue rose 3 percent, to $4.78 billion, from $4.64 billion. Analysts had expected $4.07 a share.
United said it gained $75 million in revenue from the strike at Northwest, more than any other airline. But the gains were largely offset by weak sales in the Asia-Pacific region, which provides nearly 20 percent of its total revenue. The carrier was particularly hard hit by a rise in the value of the Japanese yen during the quarter.
"We are no longer certain of profitability for the Pacific for the full year," James Goodwin, UAL's president and chief operating officer, told reporters. But he hastened to add that barring any major changes in the industry or the economy, United was on track to surpass last year's record earnings.
Despite reports that companies are cutting travel budgets, American, United and US Airways said that advance bookings were strong.
After many years of growing more slowly than the industry as a whole, American is planning to take delivery of 49 new Boeing jets next year, increasing its total number of seats by 6 percent. But Mr. Arpey said the company was studying whether to reduce that growth rate by one-third by retiring some of its older DC-10 and 727 jets earlier than planned.
Executives at United and US Airways also said they were considering lowering their growth next year.
T.W.A. has more serious problems. The airline, the country's eighth largest, had an operating loss in the quarter of $923,000, or 11 cents a share, compared with a profit of $13.3 million, or 17 cents, last year. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call was for 33 cents a share.
Revenue fell 5 percent, to $863.2 million, from $908.4 million as T.W.A.'s efforts to attract lucrative business passengers failed to make up for an overall passenger decline.
The airline announced a fare sale on Tuesday to win back budget-minded leisure passengers, and yesterday it announced the purchase of five Boeing jets. But the poor quarter was a bad omen.
"If T.W.A. can't make profit in a quarter when traffic is strong, fuel is cheap and they got 14 cents a share from the strike at Northwest," said Brian D. Harris, the airline analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, "we wonder when they can make a profit."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 24, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about third-quarter financial results at major airlines misstated earnings at Trans World Airlines. The company reported operating income of $23.7 million and a net loss of $923,000 before extraordinary items -- not an operating loss of $923,000.

HEADLINE: Iowa's Quiet Voters

BYLINE: By Frank Conroy; Frank Conroy, director of the Writers' Workshop at the University of Iowa, is the author, most recently, of "Body and Soul."

DATELINE: IOWA CITY

 BODY:
Iowans have remained remarkably calm through the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal. Nobody seems to want to talk about it publicly, although a soccer mom might be overheard at the supermarket complaining about five 11-year-olds discussing oral sex, semen stains and cigars on the way to the game.
People are not in denial about what happened; they just aren't particularly eager to go on and on about it. I believe their reticence springs from shame. If any mood can be said to prevail in Iowa as we approach the elections, it is a sense of shame. 
 President Clinton is shameless, his remorse a sham. Kenneth Starr is shameless, digging in the dirt and shoving it in our faces. The House of Representatives is shameless, having instantly politicized the situation while talking of the need for bipartisanship. No, it is the people who are ashamed, and understandably so.
Our Governor, Terry E. Branstad, a moderate Republican and the nation's longest-serving governor, is retiring after four terms. Tom Vilsack, a Democrat and former State Senator, is running against Jim Lightfoot, a Republican and former member of the United States House of Representatives. Mr. Vilsack has not asked for Mr. Clinton's help on his campaign, and Mr. Lightfoot has kept entirely mum about the scandal, which suggests the two men, perhaps unconsciously, have agreed to keep the whole mess at arm's length.
In fact, the issue has not been raised in any of the races in Iowa. The people are sick of the Clinton-Lewinsky story, and the politicians know it.
The Iowa elections will not be a referendum on the President's behavior or Congress's response. For every Democrat voting Republican out of disgust with Slick Willie, there will probably be a Republican voting Democratic out of disgust with Mr. Starr's brutal brand of moral dandyism. Or in response to the threat from Republicans in Congress to keep the miserable spectacle running forever.
Iowans will vote on the issues: agriculture, education, drugs (a surprising methamphetamine problem has emerged around the state -- not big, but pesky) and the economics of health care. Some observers anticipate a lower voter turnout across the board, but that's all. Iowans will vote as if the scandal never occurred.
But, of course, it did occur.
Iowans are crazy about sports, and thus many bars and restaurants have banks of television sets that are left on all the time. When the image of Bill Clinton is on the screen -- speaking from the Rose Garden, or standing on a podium somewhere -- people tend to look away.
It's subtle. They don't groan or make faces; they rearrange the silverware, fold the napkins or generally fiddle. Supporters and critics alike, they don't look back at the television until his image is gone.

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Foot in the North, Heart in the South

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

 BODY:
The city began with the river.
As the broad and occasionally unruly Ohio flows southwest from Pittsburgh toward its rendezvous with the Mississippi, it is interrupted here by rapids. In 1778, that barrier prompted George Rogers Clark, a young frontiersman from Virginia, to pause on his trip west and establish a settlement that eventually grew into this, the first metropolis west of the Alleghenies. 
 Clark himself, a brother of Meriwether Lewis's partner, William Clark, pushed on into the wilderness with a meager little force of 175 men. Marching through primeval forest and across flooded prairies in a campaign of audacious brilliance, he fought and defeated the better equipped, more numerous British at isolated villages in the Northwest Territory -- Vincennes, Cahokia and Kaskaskia -- securing that vast domain for the fledgling United States.
In 1809, long retired, Clark returned to Louisville to live out his final years at his sister's house, Locust Grove. Built in 1790, meticulously restored in 1962, it stands today as a monument to Clark's exploits, which are detailed in a nearby visitors center. But with its Flemish bond brickwork, shellacked ash floors and original walnut paneling, its gardens and dependencies, Locust Grove also bears witness to the highly refined tastes of some of Kentucky's pioneer settlers.
Louisville has preserved other handsome mementos of its early years. Farmington, an exceptional little Federal plantation house with delicate fan lights and a pair of octagonal rooms, was built to plans by Thomas Jefferson in 1810. Depressed because he feared that his courtship of Mary Todd had failed, Kentucky-born Abraham Lincoln took refuge there for six weeks with his friend Joshua Speed, scion of the family that owned the plantation.
Downtown, the Jefferson County Courthouse, whose pediment is supported by monumental fluted Doric columns, was built just a little later, from 1835 to 1860. With a grand cast-iron stairway and balustrade inside a 68-foot rotunda, it is by Gideon Shryock, a student of the Philadelphia architect William Strickland, who designed the Second Bank of the United States. Shryock introduced the Greek Revival style to the states beyond the Alleghenies.
The county was named, of course, for Thomas Jefferson, whose statue stands in front of the courthouse.
The city, whose inhabitants call it LOO-uh-vul, all but swallowing the final two syllables, was named for Louis XVI, the French King who aided the colonies in their war for independence. (The Almanac of American Politics, Michael Barone's invaluable compendium, points out that only one other American city, St. Paul, Minn., was named for a man who was executed.) Other place names in Kentucky, including Bourbon County and the towns of Paris and Versailles, also reflect the new nation's gratitude to France in the postwar years.
 
Whisky, Women and Horses
But ask a native about Louisville and you are likely to hear about things other than history and architecture. The Kentucky writers who put together the city's entry in the Depression-era W.P.A. Guide said it was "noted for fine whisky, beautiful women and the Kentucky Derby," and it still is.
"Louisville is too busy making and selling things to have the languor of a town in the Deep South, but it does have its special graces," the guide adds. "Its people are friendly and hospitable. Bourbon and water or a cocktail after work is popular; amusement and relaxation are as important as work."
Almost 60 years, three wars and several economic upheavals later, that description rings as true as ever, down to the last semicolon.
The city proper has a population of only about 275,000, but its suburbs spread into three Kentucky counties and four across the river in Indiana. The metropolitan area has more than a million people and a big-city feel, with Interstates and freeways circling and bisecting it. Yet drivers gallantly yield to people in crosswalks and cars waiting to turn left.
Officially, this is a border city in a border state. Kentucky stayed in the Union during the Civil War, with Kentuckians fighting on both sides. But Louisville long ago lost its heart to the South. Before the war, explained James Holmberg, a curator at the Filson Club, a Louisville historical society, "we were a Western city, but Confederate veterans took over the city and state after the war. Kentucky was the only state to secede after Appomattox."
 
Charm and Tolerance
Daniel D. Maye, a Georgian who came to Louisville by way of Chicago, says it "combines Southern rural charm with Northern urban tolerance." It produced not only Louis D. Brandeis, the first Jewish Supreme Court justice, but also Muhammad Ali, in whose honor the city plans a 50,000-square-foot museum, and it was one of the first cities anywhere to comply with the 1954 desegregation ruling.
Come here during Derby Week, the seven days leading up to the annual Run for the Roses on the first Saturday in May, or the week before that, and the traffic might make you think you're in Manhattan or Los Angeles, even if the nonstop Southern belles and the lawn parties, with lethal mint juleps served in silver stirrup cups, might remind you rather more of Biloxi or New Orleans.
The city plays host to the world with costume balls, the Pegasus Parade down Broadway, the Great Balloon Race out at the Fairgrounds and the Great Steamboat Race on the Ohio, punctuated by calliope toots, between the local stern-wheeler, the Belle of Louisville, and the larger Delta Queen from New Orleans. Race day itself might come as an anticlimax if it were not so stirring: the sentimental strains of Stephen Foster's "My Old Kentucky Home," the clang of the starting bell and the hell-for-leather charge down the stretch, jockeys' silks flashing, crowd cheering, steeds straining.
It is indeed "the most exciting two minutes in sports" (except in 1973, when the great Secretariat won in one minute 59 and two-fifths seconds). It is a parimutuel money-spinner, with $8.3 million bet at the track on the 1998 Derby. It is the only horse race most Americans pay the slightest attention to.
It is also a hell of a party. A Kentucky judge once said of the julep that "he who has not tasted one has lived in vain." Not many of the 130,000 or so people at the Derby in a typical year are in danger of that.
Churchill Downs, where the race has been run since 1875, is open almost every day of the year. Tucked beneath the twin octagonal Edwardian spires, the track's trademark, is a museum celebrating the race, the owners, the trainers, the jockeys and the horses themselves, from Man O' War, Whirlaway and Citation to the present. An exciting audiovisual presentation of the most recent race is projected onto an oval overhead screen. Or maybe you'd like to gawk at doll houses depicting C. V. Whitney's estate near Lexington, Maple Hill, or collect trivia like this tidbit: women used to bet candy or gloves on the race.
Louisville has another sporting claim to fame: it is the home of the Hillerich & Bradsby Company, the maker of Louisville Slugger baseball bats. Lately the company has opened a museum, identified by a bat 120 feet tall leaning against the building. Here, too, there is a film, featuring Johnny Bench and Tony Gwynn talking about hitting in such a lively, understandable way that my wife, Betsey, a non-fan, was entranced. You can watch bats being made from ash blanks taken from 50-year-old trees in Pennsylvania and New York, and view Sluggers used by Babe Ruth and Roger Maris (but not Mark McGwire, who swings a Rawlings bat).
Down Third Street at the far end of the neighborhood known as Old Louisville stands the J. B. Speed Art Museum, one of the premier cultural institutions in a city that has a lot of them for its size.
Recently remodeled, the Speed has a tureen by Paul Storr, a beautiful second century A.D. Roman altar supported by two lions, a fine early Rembrandt portrait of a woman (the mate of a male portrait in the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, Calif.), a set of folding screens painted in 1911 by Everett Shinn for the interior designer Elsie de Wolfe, and the wooden paneling of an entire reception room, complete with spectacular carving, from a manor house in Broadhembury, Devon, England. Dating from 1619, it was removed when the house was pulled down, sold to William Randolph Hearst at the peak of his collecting mania, then resold to a Louisville patron who gave it to the museum.
Odd, the way places catch up to you: the manor house, called the Grange, belonged to a family named Drewe. For years, Betsey and I have been stopping for lunch at a pub in that same speck of a village, on our way from London to visit friends in Devon. The pub is called the Drewe Arms. Snap.
 
Calder and Dubuffet
Some of the city's best sculpture, including pieces by Calder, Dubuffet, Tony Smith, Louise Nevelson and John Chamberlain, is gathered in and around the Kentucky Center for the Arts, a big, glistening glass box. Its three stages provide homes for Louisville's resident opera, ballet and symphony orchestra, plus touring Broadway musicals and concerts from bop to bluegrass.
The Louisville Orchestra, which celebrated its 60th anniversary last year, has a reputation extending well beyond the region. Beginning in 1953, under its founding conductor, Robert Whitney, it has recorded several hundred previously unavailable works by more than 250 composers, including Ginastera, Ives, Villa-Lobos, Piston and Britten. Battered like many similar groups by drastic reductions in funds in the 1980's, the orchestra finally returned to the black in 1996 and named a new principal conductor, the Israeli Uriel Siegel, for this season. It opened in mid-September with Pinchas Zuckerman as violin soloist.
A Tony Award-winning regional theater company, the Actors Theater, occupies a Greek Revival bank building on Main Street, built in 1837 (and erroneously thought for a long time to have been designed by Gideon Shryock). Each winter the Actors Theater stages a highly regarded Festival of New American Plays.
The city's civic and artistic life has been blessed by a succession of innovative and capable mayors, including Wilson W. Wyatt, a founder of Americans for Democratic Action; Harvey Sloane, and the present incumbent, Jerry Abramson.
Much of Louisville's cultural life was underwritten for years by the Bingham family, as was the Falls Fountain, built in 1988. Best seen from the Riverfront Belvedere or the Riverwalk, it spews water to a height of 375 feet from the midst of the Ohio River. In theory, it forms a fleur-de-lis, the city's official symbol, but to be honest, you'd have to have a Rorshachian imagination to see much of anything except a lot of splashing water.
Robert Worth Bingham bought The Louisville Courier-Journal in 1917 from Henry Watterson, one of the greatest of 19th-century American editors. In 1933, he went to London to serve as United States Ambassador, and his son, Barry, took over the paper. Barry Bingham and his wife, Mary, rapidly became a dominant force in Louisville political, cultural and philanthropic circles; he and Wilson Wyatt, boyhood chums, worked in close partnership.
But the Bingham children squabbled over their inheritance, and the paper was sold in 1986. It has lost much of its zest under its less open-handed new owner, the Gannett chain, and many Louisville charities have felt the loss of the Binghams' leadership.
 
Contrasting Architecture
Happily for the city, however, others have stepped in, notably the family of David A. Jones, founder of Humana Inc., the health-care company. Humana's headquarters, a salmon-pink skyscraper, is one of Louisville's most distinctive buildings; its entrance is flanked by Busby Berkeley waterfalls refashioned in Michael Graves's post-modern idiom. Almost next door stands the American office of the Aegon Insurance Group, a good-looking 1992 tower by John Burgee and Philip Johnson whose openwork cap has led irreverent locals to christen it "the Ban roll-on building." The two contrast sharply with other contemporary structures downtown, a thoroughly mediocre group. Worst are the Waterfront Plaza Towers, with gaudy scarlet-and-white "lighthouses" on their roofs.
The waterfront itself has been redeveloped to great effect, making it possible to walk for miles along the Ohio. You can also follow the river upstream along River Road to some of Louisville's prettiest suburbs.
Humana and other companies in its field are among Louisville's biggest employers; there are no fewer than 15 hospitals in the city. The city is also the global hub for United Parcel Service, which provides 14,500 local jobs, more than any other single company. General Electric makes appliances here, Philip Morris and Brown & Williamson make tobacco products and Brown Forman and United Distillers make bourbon. Tricon Global, the new corporate tent for Taco Bell, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut, has its headquarters here, too.
 
Fried Chicken and Bourbon
But if you want to experience the definitive Kentucky fried chicken, and explore the bourbon belt, the best thing is to head south to Bardstown, one of the state's oldest communities. It was founded in 1775, the year of Paul Revere's ride in far-off Massachusetts, and its streets are lined with 18th- and early 19th-century houses. More to the point, it has Kurtz's, where Marilyn (Toogie) Dick serves her glorious fried chicken to hordes of hungry people each weekend, some of whom come all the way from Cincinnati.
Suitably fortified, you can use Bardstown as a base to learn more about bourbon, the corn-based whisky that made Kentucky famous (along with Daniel Boone and racehorses). This is the state, it has been said, "where the corn is full of kernels and the colonels are full of corn." So visit the Oscar Getz Museum of Whiskey History in Bardstown to soak up distilling lore.
Then move on to Maker's Mark in Loretto, a charming old distillery. Its whisky is much loved by Kentuckians, for its red wax seal and its distinctively mellow flavor. That results in part from using winter wheat, instead of rye, along with corn and malted barley. Near Versailles is Labrot & Graham, perhaps the most picturesque of the distilleries; Woodford Reserve, the company's small-batch bourbon, has the savor of a French Armagnac, with a typical "hot" finish.
If you have more time, spend a morning in the more abstemious atmosphere of the restored Shaker Village of Pleasant Hill, near Harrodsburg. The triumph of the place is not the 33 brick, frame and stone buildings, or the clever, handsome furniture or even the wonderful twin spiral staircases at the Trustees' House. The triumph is the sense of serenity -- or is it spirituality? -- that visitors feel, far from the roar of the interstate and the clamor of the city, surrounded by ponds and meadows where sheep may safely graze.
 
Here is information about visiting Louisville, Ky.:
 
Where to Stay
 
THE CAMBERLEY BROWN, 335 West Broadway, (502) 583-1234. Echoes of Derby frolics past resound through the magnificent marble halls of the 75-year-old Brown, Louisville's old-money hotel. Ornate chandeliers, collections of equine paintings and sculptures and a registration desk concealed behind gilded screens enrich the lobby. Guest rooms, some a trifle small, are nicely appointed. Double room: $189; special rates may be available.
 
SEELBACH HILTON, 500 Fourth Street, (502) 585-3200. Opened in 1905, the Seelbach served as a model for a scene in "The Great Gatsby." It was restored in the early 1980's, but some rooms and bathrooms have grown shabby since; another face lift is needed and planned soon, to the tune of $3.2 million. The lobby, with murals illustrating Kentucky history, begs for better lighting. Double rooms: $159 to $209; based on availability, special rates of $99 on weekends and $129 on weekdays, including Continental breakfast.
 
HYATT REGENCY, 320 West Jefferson Street, (502) 587-3434, offers the usual amenities of the chain hotels, but it, too, is starting to look a little tired. Nonetheless, the Hyatt's downtown location is convenient, and the tennis court, indoor pool and 18-story atrium are strong selling points. A revolving rooftop restaurant overlooks the river, if you like that sort of thing. Double rooms: $99 to $120 on weekends; $169 to $210 on weekdays.
 
OLD LOUISVILLE INN, 1359 South Third Street, (502) 635-1574. Third Street is lined with Gilded Age houses of every description from Richardsonian Romanesque to Eastlake Victorian, many of them carefully restored. One such is the Old Louisville Inn, a well-run, 10-room bed-and-breakfast with 12-foot ceilings that was built in 1901 as the baronial residence of a telephone tycoon. Double rooms: $95 to $135.
 
Where to Eat
 
CLUB GROTTO, 2116 Bardstown Road, (502) 459-5275. Big Jim McKinney says he knows 90 percent of the customers who visit his animated red-walled, low-ceilinged bistro. The menu reflects an aversion to shortcuts: mozzarella is made in the house, and barbecued shrimp are served in a sauce based on lobster stock. Try cornmeal-breaded fried walleye or the 11-vegetable "orgy."
 
J. GRAHAM'S CAFE, in the Camberley Brown (see above), is a glorified coffee shop that serves an authentic Hot Brown sandwich, an old Louisville favorite invented at the hotel. Toast triangles in an ovenproof dish are covered with shaved turkey breast, Mornay sauce, smoky Kentucky bacon, Parmesan and tomato wedges and finished under the broiler. Result: a cheese dream with a Ph.D. Open for breakfast and lunch only: Mondays through Saturdays, 6:30 A.M. to 3 P.M.; Sundays, 7 A.M. to 3 P.M.
 
KURTZ'S, 418 East Stephen Foster Avenue, Bardstown, (502) 348-8964. Don't look for furbelows in this old stone house. Kurtz's has been there since 1937, serving chewy, salty Kentucky ham; crisp, greaseless chicken fried in deep cast-iron skillets; blini-shaped fried cornbread, soufflelike corn pudding, home-pickled beets and mashed potatoes better than your grandmother's. Oh, my.
 
LILLY'S, 1147 Bardstown Road, (502) 451-0447. Lilly's served us the best meal of a recent visit to Louisville. "God bless our local farmers!" the menu said; I understood why after eating a stack of phyllo rounds and ripe tomato slices topped with warm goat cheese. Even better: juicy roast pork tenderloin with a spicy red-brown sauce, gossamer cornbread and wasabi slaw.
 
LYNN'S PARADISE CAFE, 984 Barret Avenue, (502) 583-3447. Who needs a barrel of monkeys? Nothing could be more fun than Lynn Winter's place, with an eight-foot-tall coffee pot out front, corncob murals and a zany array of hideous lamps. Four thousand people a week come for gotta-try-'em grits or French toast at breakfast, meatloaf at lunch and Lynn's warming smile all day long.
 
THE OAKROOM, in the Seelbach Hilton (see above), features Kentucky products, from smoked spoonfish and Newsom's hams to mangolike papaws, gathered by foragers in Appalachia. The gifted chef, Jim Gerhardt, also marinates pork, the local meat of choice, in bourbon and molasses and pairs it with a fruit compote. Fine wines and cheeses are chosen by Adam Seger, the maitre d'hotel. Open daily 5:30 to 10 P.M.
 
VINCE STATEN'S, 9219 U.S. Highway 42, Prospect, (502) 228-7427. A co-author of the standard guide to the nation's barbecue restaurants, Vince Staten runs a joint of his own in the suburbs. The decor is plastic, but not the food. Ribs and pulled pork sandwiches are succulent, as are the beans and coleslaw; Staten's offers six sauces, culminating in Legal Limit hot.
 
Attractions
 
LOCUST GROVE, 561 Blankenbaker Lane, (502) 897-9845. A 1790 Georgian mansion on 55 acres six miles up river from downtown, restored and furnished to its original appearance. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1:30 P.M. to 4:30 P.M.; last tour at 3:30 P.M. Admission: $4; $3 for the elderly; $2 for children 6 to 12; children 5 and under free.
 
FARMINGTON, 3033 Bardstown Road, (502) 452-9920. Built in 1810 after a plan by Thomas Jefferson and furnished with 19th-century pieces. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1:30 to 5 P.M; last guided tour at 3:45 P.M. Free parking. Admission: $4; $3 for visitors 60 and over; $2 for students 18 and under; children under 6 free.
 
CHURCHILL DOWNS AND THE KENTUCKY DERBY MUSEUM, 700 and 704 Central Avenue, (800) 273-3729. The three-floor museum has exhibitions, racing artifacts and memorabilia about thoroughbred racing and the Kentucky Derby. Off-season, a walking tour of the racetrack takes visitors to the paddock, under the grandstand via the same tunnel the horses use, and to trackside to see the finish line, the winners circle and the famous twin spires. Weather permitting, 30-minute tours are given hourly, with the first at 9:45 A.M. and the last at 3:45 P.M. Admission: $6; $5 for ages 55 and older; $2 for ages 5 to 12; children 4 and under, free.
 
LOUISVILLE SLUGGER MUSEUM, 800 West Main Street, (502) 588-7228. Look for what may be the world's tallest bat perched outside the door. After a short film, visitors walk through the full-size dugout and onto the museum's playing field. There are exhibitions, interactive displays (the sensation of a 90 m.p.h. pitch coming at you), baseball equipment and memorabilia. "Baseball's Revolutionary Louisville Slugger Remembers Babe Ruth," featuring original photographs, artifacts and memorabilia, is on view through October. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tours every 20 minutes, lasting about 90 minutes. Admission: $5; $4.50 for the elderly; $3 for children 6 to 12; under 6, free.
 
J. B. SPEED ART MUSEUM, 2035 South Third Street, (502) 634-2700. "Ansel Adams, a Legacy: Masterpieces From the Friends of Photography Collection" is on view through Nov. 15. Tickets: $7; $6 for the elderly; $4 for children. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Thursdays, to 8 P.M.; Saturdays, to 5 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.
 
KENTUCKY CENTER FOR THE ARTS, 501 Main Street, (502) 584-7777. Tomorrow at 8 P.M., the Louisville Orchestra, with the cellist Gustav Rivinius, plays Elgar's Cello Concerto; Uriel Segal, conductor. Tickets: $11 to $52. From Thursday to Nov. 1: "Bachiana," a premiere by David Parsons, with the Louisville Ballet. Tickets: $16 to $46.
 
THE ACTORS THEATER, 316 West Main Street, (502) 584-1205. In the Pamela Brown Auditorium, the musical "Peter Pan," with music by Jule Styne. Through tomorrow. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2:30 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets: $16 to $40. In the Bingham Theater, "Dracula," adapted from Bram Stoker by Hamilton Deane and John L. Balderston. Through Oct. 31. Tonight at 7:30; tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 2 and 7 P.M. Tickets: $10 to $22. Michael Frayn's "Noises Off" begins Wednesday and runs through Nov. 22. Tickets $16 to $40. "A Tuna Christmas" begins Nov. 5 and runs through Dec. 27. Tickets: $10 to $22.
 
OSCAR GETZ MUSEUM OF WHISKEY HISTORY, Bardstown Historical Museum, Spalding Hall, 114 North Fifth Street, Bardstown, (502) 348-2999. The museum focuses on the history of Kentucky and whisky. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Free.
 
SHAKER VILLAGE, 3501 Lexington Road, Pleasant Hill, (800) 734-5611. A self-guided walking tour includes 15 restored buildings with original and reproduced 19th-century Shaker furniture and household items. Artisans in costume work at 19th-century trades. Shaker music is performed four times daily from April through October. Hours through October: Daily, 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Admission: $9.50; $5 for children 12 to 17; $3 for children 6 to 11; under 6, free; family package, $25. A riverboat excursion along the Kentucky River Palisades is held daily through October at 10 A.M., noon, 2, 4 and 6 P.M.; tickets: $6; $4 for those 12 to 17; $3 for children 6 to 11; under 6, free.
 
Getting There
 
CONTINENTAL AIRLINES has two nonstop flights from Newark International Airport on weekdays. The round-trip fare is $533 if purchased one week in advance; $230 if purchased two weeks in advance and travel includes a Tuesday or Wednesday trip; $261 if purchased two weeks in advance, with a Saturday overnight stay. Unrestricted round-trip fare is $854. Information: (800) 525-0280.
 
U. S. AIRWAYS has a daily nonstop flight from La Guardia Airport. The cheapest fare, $244, requires a 21-day advance reservation and a Saturday overnight stay and has other restrictions. The fare with no restrictions is $867.90. Information: (800) 428-4322. R. W. APPLE Jr.
