HEADLINE: New Housing Based on a Colonial Tradition

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

DATELINE: RYE BROOK

 BODY:
TWO young lawyers, Marc and Dana Zimmerman, both 29, live in Riverdale and commute to their law practice in Manhattan. Mrs. Zimmerman, who grew up and went through school here, has many friends in the area, which she loves.
Eileen and Walter Sinnott raised four sons in the large house in Harrison where they have lived for 34 years. Mr. Sinnott, a retired environmental engineer, was born in Harrison and has lived there all his life, as his parents and grandparents did before him. 
 What the two couples -- one retired, empty nesters, the other starting out -- share is their enthusiasm for Belle Fair at Rye Brook. Without seeing actual model houses, they and 100 other buyers have signed contracts for new houses to be built on a 140-acre site, which the developer, Mitchell C. Hochberg, president of Spectrum Skanska of Valhalla, said is not only the largest new residential community in Westchester but also the first new old-fashioned town incorporating such turn-of-the-century neighborhood features as a village green with a meetinghouse and a wide range of housing for people of all ages: young married couples, families with children, professionals, empty nesters and retirees. In addition to the many housing choices, a three-story building for the elderly is planned.
"Belle Fair has been designed in the tradition of 'new urbanism,' a trend in residential development that begins with pedestrian-friendly streets, where the focus is on people, not cars," Mr. Hochberg said. "We call Bell Fair the new traditional hometown. Like the old town square, we have a village green, which is an open green space, the size of a football field, as the heart of the community, accessible to young and old alike by foot, bike or car. It will be bordered by landscaping and park benches framing a lawn where children can play and families picnic. Flanking it, will be a Meetinghouse, a bell tower, a general store and village homes. The environment is deliberately designed to foster interaction between people."
Although new urbanism communities exist in places like Florida and California, Mr. Hochberg said Bell Fair is the only such development in the Northeast.
"I spent two years traveling around the country looking at new urban developments such as Sea Side in Florida, which is in the front ranks of new urban design, "Mr. Hochberg said. "We then incorporated some of the elements that were applicable, such as streetscape landscaping, elevations, making houses open to the streets, sidewalks, winding roads and off-street, out-of-sight garages."
Amenities include the meetinghouse, which, Mr. Hochberg said, will have an indoor pool, spa, health club, catering kitchen, gymnasium, computer study room and library suitable for after-school study.
A full-size basketball court will encourage formation of basketball leagues for teen-agers and older players, he said, adding, "The idea being, that at Bell Fair, people have a chance to interact." An outdoor pool and a day-care center subsidized by the developer are also planned.
"There will also be a general store and an old-fashioned soda fountain on the village green, both subsidized by us," Mr. Hochberg said.
Prices of the Colonial-style houses range from $400,000 to about $600,000 and include a mix of 100 single-family, three- and four-bedroom houses, 73 luxury four-bedroom houses, 30 single-family, 3- and 4-bedroom maintenance-free Village houses around the village green and 46 maintenance-free villas suitable for empty nesters and retirees.
"We wanted a balanced community, one that spans generations," Mr. Hochberg said.
The Belle Fair concept has been received "beyond anything I could envision," Mr. Hochberg said. "On our opening day, late in June, traditionally not a good time to launch a new housing development, 400 people turned out. We expected to see 100."
He added that because of the unprecedented demand for homes at Belle Fair, the developers decided to hold a lottery. "We thought it was the most equitable way to sell the first phase of 30 houses, which 200 people were vying for," he said.
The buyers have yet to see a completed house. "They examined site maps, floor plans, saw a virtual reality video and toured the site where they saw 300,000 yards of fill being moved around," Mr. Hochberg said. "And they signed contracts. To date we've sold over 100 houses before our model house is built."
Most buyers are Westchester residents, and sales to members of different generations are not uncommon.
"We've had young couples with children buy, then their parents come and look and they end up buying," Mr. Hochberg said. "People who are absolutely delighted with the idea of living near their grandchildren."
The Sinnotts, who bought one of the town houses, said they liked the multigenerational aspect of Belle Fair. "I like to see kids around," Mr. Sinnott said. "We didn't want to be in a place where everyone is the same age. And we wanted to stay in Westchester. We have very strong ties to Harrison."
Mrs. Sinnott said: "We've been looking for a long time. Our house is actually four stories and too big for us, but we couldn't find anything we liked in the area. Then I saw an ad for Belle Fair, and it seemed right for us. The house we bought has everything we need on one floor, with two bedrooms and bath on the second floor, perfect for our visiting children. And the people were so friendly that I think we're going to enjoy living in this community."
As for the Zimmermans, Mrs. Zimmerman said that she heard about Belle Fair from a friend. "I'm a local girl, and I always wanted to move back to Rye Brook," she said. "But there was nothing to be had. My dad lives at the Arbors down the road, and I still have a lot of friends here. We immediately liked what we saw at Belle Fair and went to look at some other Spectrum developments to see the finished houses. We also heard great things about the developer, which made us feel O.K about buying from plans. We bought the smallest house, a three-bedroom, with a two-car garage."
Mrs. Zimmerman said two other young couples, friend of theirs, have also bought houses at Belle Fair. "Our next-door neighbors will be people we already know," she said. "The day-care center, the shuttle to Metro-North and the pool are added attractions for all of us. So is the school system. I started in the first grade at the Ridge Street School and went right through. Our move-in date is June 3, and we can't wait."
Mr. Hochberg said that when the development is completed it will generate approximately $3.4 million annually in taxes for the village of Rye Brook and the Rye Brook School district, which would be more than the expense generated by the additional students coming from Belle Fair.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
They're Tacky All Right, Deliriously So

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY 

 BODY:
DON'T be fooled by the family's tacky living quarters outside Dallas: a cramped, broken-down trailer home whose chief amenities are a fridge used mostly for beer, a large television set that seldom shuts up and plastic cutlery accumulated over years of eating takeout. The slobbish Ansel Smith, his tarty second wife, Sharla, his pot-smoking son, Chris, and his 20-year-old still-virginal daughter, Dottie, haven't abandoned -- nor have they been abandoned by -- the miraculous American economic juggernaut. They are part of the system and each, in his or her own way, contributes to the national weal and woe.
As much as Jeeter Lester and his "Tobacco Road" clan were symptomatic of the Great Depression of the 1930's, the Smith family reflects the values of the boom years of the 1980's and 1990's. It's just that the Smiths haven't participated to quite the degree that made billionaires of those who wheeled and dealed in savings-and-loan institutions, real estate development and computer technology. The Smiths are on the bottom rung of the ladder, but at least they're on it, or so they believe, possibly because television tells them so. 
 That is one of the unstated factors giving zest to "Killer Joe," Tracy Letts's violent, satiric and often dangerously funny family comedy, now at the SoHo Playhouse Off Broadway. The new production, a commercial venture starring Scott Glenn and Amanda Plummer, is being presented in association with the 29th Street Rep, which produced an earlier, equally effective production of the play in New York four years ago.
Ansel Smith (Marc A. Nelson) is an auto mechanic, Sharla (Ms. Plummer) waitresses at a Pizza Hut, Chris (Mike Shannon) sells dope whenever he pulls himself together, and Dottie (Sarah Paulson) once had a job with a chiropodist. Ansel's extended family would also include his alcoholic ex-wife, Adele, and her boyfriend, Rex. Adele and Rex are never seen but they become as vivid to the audience as any of the characters who are.
Presiding over the play, until the Smith family revels get lethally out of hand, is Killer Joe Cooper (Mr. Glenn), a cool, nattily dressed Dallas police detective who runs a little business on the side. Other cops might be in laundromats or vending machines; Joe is in contract murder.
It's Chris who first proposes the plan that propels the play, mostly because his mother stole the cocaine he was going to sell to pay off his $6,000 debt to some local hoods. Having learned that Adele has a $50,000 life insurance policy, of which Dottie is the sole beneficiary, Chris suggests to his father that they hire Killer Joe to carry out a contract on her. Ansel mulls over the idea for a minute or two before deciding that it might be just the ticket to provide the family with some much needed cash. Sharla thinks it's a swell idea, and even the quiet, almost beatific Dottie agrees. She remembers how, when she was 2, her mom once tried to suffocate her with a pillow.
Problems arise when, during the contract negotiations, Joe demands his $25,000 payment in advance. Since they scarcely have enough cash to pay for their Kentucky fried chicken, they are stymied until Joe proposes a compromise. He's been much taken by the childlike Dottie. He says that, instead of cash, he will accept Dottie as a retainer. This pleases everyone, including Dottie who, in her turn, has been much taken by the smooth-talking, well-scrubbed detective who hardly ever uses four-letter words.
"Killer Joe" begins like a white-trash cartoon in which middle-class behavior is turned inside out. The sodden Chris objects to his stepmother's opening the door to him when she is wearing nothing below the waist. Sharla points out that it is the middle of the night and she didn't know who was knocking. Dottie's virginity is a source of worry. The potbellied Ansel plods around in gray-tinged briefs in need of a new elastic. Whenever he tries to act like a father, his attention inevitably slides over to the more compelling images on the television set.
Though "Killer Joe" behaves like a cartoon, its firm dramatic structure builds to a furious climax that has the punch of reality. It is both dismaying in its physical and psychological brutality and horrendously comic. As written by Mr. Letts and as beautifully acted by Mr. Glenn and Ms. Paulson, the courtship of Joe and Dottie even succeeds in being moving. They are the only characters in the play who don't traffic in double-crosses.
The director is Wilson Milam, who staged the play's 1993 premiere in Chicago, the first New York production, and successful runs in London, initially at the Gate Theater and then at the Vaudeville in the West End. By this time, it is clear that he has complete control of the exotic material as well as the actors to realize it.
Ms. Plummer's Sharla is a delight, at the beginning a brassily self-assured trailer park Circe, then a bewildered wreck, while Mr. Shannon's Chris is a perfect, self-pitying lout. Mr. Nelson gives the production's most consistently realized performance as Ansel, but then he has been doing the role off and on from Chicago through the London runs.
The Smiths may seem outrageous but, as someone in the play observes: "A normal person is just someone you don't know very well." "Killer Joe" is an immensely entertaining pop artifact, written, directed and performed with neon-lit flamboyance. Lift your Styrofoam cups to toast a hit.

HEADLINE: WORKING;
Victory In Variety

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. I am a junior at the State University of New York at Buffalo. So far, I've completed internships in international business, public relations and city government. I am currently working as an intern with a political campaign, and I plan an internship in international relations or security before I graduate. How will prospective employers react to my involvement in such a wide range of apprenticeship programs? I don't want to look as though I'm "internship hopping" or can't commit myself to a single job.
 
A. Relax. Yes, a handful of preternaturally focused people know from Day One of kindergarten that they want to be doctors or lawyers or forest rangers -- and build their lives accordingly. Few employers will penalize you, however, for not being one of that rare (and somewhat disturbing) breed.
"Many people, even in their late 20's, don't know exactly where they want to work," said Mark Oldman, managing director of Vault Reports, a New York company that provides job seekers with detailed information on internships and employers. It would be unrealistic, he added, for companies to expect college students to know their exact career paths. 
 Besides, your internship choices hardly seem off the wall. On the contrary, all of them point in the general direction of public relations. And far from raising alarm bells, the accumulation of so much workplace experience in your college years is likely to please potential employers, whatever path you pursue.
"Most employers see internships, even in fields that are not directly relevant to the one you end up in, as a way of gaining the soft skills needed in an office," Mr. Oldman said. "There are things common to most businesses: gaining a professional demeanor, knowing how to fit within a hierarchical institution, not stepping on toes. These are things you learn only by being on the job."
Price Hicks, who directs the intern program for the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences in Los Angeles, agreed. "I don't think employers want to spend their time acclimating a person to the realities of everyday work life," she said.
Even more broadly, internships are a signal to employers that you are equipped to deal with life after college. Mr. Oldman said intern coordinators believe that "internships in general are a real sign of maturity and initiative -- that someone hasn't spent his summers flipping burgers or twirling the lifeguard whistle."
If eyebrows are raised about the diversity of your experience, pitch your background as a plus. "In addition to showing that you can work in a variety of environments, it suggests you might have something interesting to contribute to your new office," Mr. Oldman said.
What's more, having explored several options, you are now better qualified to choose the field that's right for you -- and to avoid job-hopping in your post-college years. "One of the great things about internships," Mr. Oldman said, "is that they help you decide where you don't want to go."
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she will respond to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: Step Aside Party Loyalty. Make Way for Incumbency.

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
AS Nov. 3 closes in, two statewide candidates in Connecticut are holding onto blowout-sized leads that pollsters and even the lucky campaigns had predicted for months would shrink in the fall frost. One is a Republican and one is a Democrat -- throwing into a cocked hat the many theories about Democratic disillusionment and, depending on the day, Republican rage or Republican backlash.
Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, and United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, each held 40-point edges on their challengers in recent polls, underscoring the decline of party affiliation as a decisive factor in elections, replacing it with personality and incumbency. Their challengers -- United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, a Democrat running for Governor, and Gary A. Franks, a Republican and former Representative running for the Senate -- were left with lonely runs in a booming economy and a season of apparent voter contentment. 
 So the drama this year will be lower on the ballot, and those who follow the state's campaigns and watch its politics say the length -- or lack -- of Mr. Rowland's coattails could produce some real surprises on Election Day. Voters choose the Senate candidates first, so Democratic strategists are calling Senator Dodd their firewall between Mr. Rowland's expected romp and a Democratic wipeout if voters follow his party all the way down their ballots. "Maybe fireball," Senator Dodd recently joked.
Mrs. Kennelly's campaign manager, Jonathan W. Pelto, said the tendency of voters to ignore or discount parties makes a challenger's job much more difficult. "You really start out much more from zero, as opposed to the days of yore when you started with 30 or 40 percent," he said. "These polls indicted that the long-touted realignment of voters has not been from Republican to Democrat, but a realignment from party partisanship to ticket-splitters and unaffiliated voters."
Voter-registration figures bear that out. Although more people are registered as Democrats than as Republicans, the largest group is unaffiliated voters. The most recent available figures show the state has 722,004 unaffiliated voters, 643,859 Democrats, 455,728 Republicans and 4,120 voters who are registered as members of minor parties.
Both major parties have strategies for using this landscape to their advantage. Edward L. Marcus, the state Democratic chairman, said the registration figures give his candidates farther down the ballot a strong shot. "If you get Democrats to vote Democrat, you pretty well have it made," Mr. Marcus said. "That's why I say that despite the polls, even Kennelly has an opportunity."
Republicans, however, are working on television commercials, mailings and telephone calls to try to spread Mr. Rowland's luster to candidates for Congress, the state's House and Senate, and for the other statewide offices -- Attorney General, Secretary of the State, Treasurer and Comptroller. "There has been a real effort to convince voters that it is not just giving the Governor another four years, but an entire Republican team to work toward the same goals," said Michael H. Broder, communications director for the state party.
State Republicans have figures indicating that historically, under-ticket candidates have run 5 to 7 percentage points behind the Governor. "If the Governor's polls hold up, there could be a really huge sweep," Mr. Broder said.
Douglas Schwartz, the director of the Quinnipiac College Poll, said history and his own surveys suggest that the coattail effect is minimal, however. "You can't transfer popularity," Mr. Schwartz said. "Voters think of each position as almost a separate election." He went on to say that the slump in party allegiance is a major factor in declining voter turnout. "Parties used to get people excited," he said. "But that doesn't happen automatically anymore."
Democrats are trying to buck that trend, however, by emphasizing issues that are likely to encourage their most loyal voters to go to the polls. This year, the Democratic turnout effort is called the Campaign for Connecticut Families. (Notice the lack of the "D" word.) Matt Miller, the group's communications director, said the issues emphasized at rallies and when contacting voters include health care reform, improvements in education and protecting the environment.
A recent poll indicates those efforts are succeeding. Despite Mr. Rowland's impending landslide, the two Democratic incumbents in under-ticket offices looked secure. The poll by Mason-Dixon Political/Media Research showed the Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, with a 27 percentage point lead over his Republican challenger, Santa Mendoza. The State Comptroller, Nancy Wyman, led her Republican challenger, State Representative Christopher Scalzo, by 17 percentage points.
The Republican incumbent among the constitutional officers, Treasurer Paul Silvester, led his Democratic challenger, Denise Nappier, by 16 percentage points. The closest race was between two non-incumbents. The Democratic nominee for Secretary of the State, State Representative Susan Bysiewicz, led the Republican candidate, Ben Andrews, by 13 percentage points.
Donald Ferree Jr., the director of political polling at the University of Connecticut, throws another ingredient into the stew. He said that despite the conflicting theories about the effect of President Clinton's woes on the state election, the issue has been too pervasive to avoid having some impact on voter mood or turnout. "If 1992 was the year of the woman, 1998 was the year of that woman," Dr. Ferree said.
All of this uncertainty exists only because of a change that was made in Connecticut just a dozen years ago -- long after most other states. In 1986, voters decided to abolish the party lever, which allowed voters to pick the top of the ticket, then automatically vote for the whole party slate -- legislators, constitutional officers and all. This year, the polls indicate that voters might try to split that lever in half.

HEADLINE: Teachers Try to Renew Interest in French

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: PLEASANTVILLE

 BODY:
SO much for studying French to read Moliere and Voltaire, Balzac and Sartre or to be able to order Filets de Dorade sur Lit d'Epinards a la Sauce Moutarde in Paris with elan (sea bream with spinach and mustard sauce).
In an effort to stem the decline in the number of students willing to pursue French at the high school and university level, language teachers spent a recent Saturday at a conference at Pace University here to learn how to make French more enticing. 
 "Ten years ago, there were 24 sections of French and 15 sections of Spanish at Horace Greeley High School," said Dr. Geraldine O'Neill, an adjunct professor at Pace University who had taught for 29 years at the high school in Chappaqua. "Now the school has 24 sections of Spanish and 14 of French." Until the 1980's, French was the first choice of most students for a foreign language. But since then, at Horace Greeley and many other schools in Westchester and and around the United States, the positions of French and Spanish have switched.
"There's a perception that Spanish is more practical," said Dr. Adelia Williams, chairwoman of the department of modern languages and cultures at Pace University. "And there is the reality that French has declined in the past 20 years. The idea behind this conference is to bring together a cross-section of teachers and educators in French to see how they can promote French outside the traditional curriculum and to give them hope. There are a lot of things going on now. We're at a turning point, and this meeting is part of the effort to combat the decline."
Such a reversal -- with the ascendancy of Spanish often coming at the expense of French -- has been attributed in part to the increase in the number of Hispanic immigrants to the United States, greater exposure of news organizations to Hispanic culture and a perception that Spanish is a more practical language.
"In the last 10 to 15 years, Spanish has developed a persona," Dr. O'Neill said. "The Hispanic population is more evident. They are more visible in politics and the media, and for any culture that type of publicity makes people aware. The fact that Spanish was becoming more obvious in the culture drew students."
The conference, which was attended by about 150 language teachers from the New York City area, was co-sponsored by Pace University's department of modern languages and cultures, the American Association of Teachers of French and the Cultural Services of the French Embassy in Manhattan.
Experts suggested using strategies and tools like the Internet and technology to attract students; exposing students to the Francophone world -- for example, the diverse French-speaking cultures of Canada, Africa, Asia and the Caribbean -- instead of focusing curriculum solely on France; showing students how French is important in the global economy, and introducing students to French and Francophone movies, music and other activities.
"It's a growing crisis," said Dr. Gladys Lipton, president of the American Association of Teachers of French. "There has been a 25 percent decline in French studies at the university level in the last five years. We have to market French in different ways. We need to stress the importance and practicality of learning French, with a special emphasis on beginning early."
Guilhene Maratier-Declety, director of the international division and deputy education director for the Chambre de Commerce et d'Industrie de Paris, said:
"Students need to see the importance of French as an economic language. It's a bridge between the world of business and the world of academics. International companies recruit people who speak another language. And French is the language for 250 million people in the Francophone world. English is not the only language of business."
Some teachers have already applied innovative methods to appeal to students. David Graham, foreign language chairman for the Plainview-Old Bethpage Central School District on Long Island, has been using Quebecois music and culture to teach French to his students.
"I use the music to teach just about everything: culture, language, grammar," Mr. Graham said. "Quebec music is really American music in French. The idea is to use anything that appeals to the kids on the kids' level, like music and movies. In the last few years, I've used sports. We've brought in three to four French-speaking hockey players to a French night. And we keep reminding the students and their parents that Canada is the United States' best trading partner. New York State alone does $8 billion in trade with the province of Quebec."
Experts at the conference observed that, while English may be the first global language, French remains the second. And with the increasing importance of the European Union, its importance for the business community remains significant.
"Students need to see how French is used in the business world," said Linda M. Jouas, a French and Latin teacher at the Bronxville middle school and high school. "It's also important for French teachers to talk to one another."
Dr. O'Neill said: "We need to make students aware that France is not just about perfume and wine, or Louis the XIV, that France is in fact a very modern, progressive and technologically advanced country. The idea behind studying French is that going to France is not the only thing you can do, that there are many exciting things happening elsewhere in the world of France and the Francophone world."

HEADLINE: An East End Transfer Tax? Realtors Say No Way.

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THE dead-heat contest between Alfonse M. D'Amato and Charles E. Schumer may be the highlight of the campaign season across the rest of New York State. But in Suffolk County, farm and environmental referendum issues are generating enough heat to compete with the Senate race as the hottest topic down at the coffee shop.
A proposition asking Suffolk voters whether the county should sell $62 million in bonds to preserve farms, buy open space and add playing fields to parks is the first item on the county ballot on Nov. 3. 
 In each of Suffolk's five East End towns, it will be followed by town propositions asking whether a 2 percent transfer tax should be imposed on the sale of expensive homes or when farmland is sold to developers. The proceeds, estimated at $100 million over 10 years, would go into town land banks for farm and open space protection.
And in the Town of Huntington, voters will decide on a $15 million bond that would include $10 million to buy open land and $5 million for park improvements.
Based on past performance, none of these propositions would appear to have much trouble winning approval. Suffolk voters have embraced every spending plan for farms, open space, groundwater and pine barrens placed before them by county and state government over nearly three decades.
In 1987 and again in 1988, about three-quarters of Suffolk voters approved a 0.25 percent rise in the county sales tax to buy pine barrens and protect groundwater. Two years ago, Gov. George E. Pataki's $1.75 billion environmental bond act passed in a walk in Suffolk -- and, for that matter, in Nassau County. Even Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's ill-fated $1.9 billion environmental bond act, rejected statewide in a less economically positive period in 1990, carried easily in both counties.
But the New York State Association of Realtors is trying to buck the recent trend and has spent about $100,000 on television and radio advertising to defeat one of the initiatives -- the East End transfer tax. The Long Island Board of Realtors also opposes the tax and by midweek had contributed $12,500 to defeat it.
The ads assert that $277 million is already available for preservation programs and question whether it is necessary to raise $100 million more.
Charles M. Staro, the association's executive vice president, said transfer taxes were "extremely unfair" because they placed "the entire financial burden on individuals choosing to buy and sell homes for a program that will benefit everyone on the East End, including tourists."
He said the association had opposed transfer taxes wherever they had been proposed. "It just so happens that this time it is occurring on the East End of Long Island," he said.
Elected officials, environmental and civic groups in Suffolk nearly unanimously agree that new infusions of money will be needed to protect Long Island's only remaining rural and agricultural area from development pressure, and many of them have reacted with vitriol to the real estate industry campaign.
"They are just a pack of lying Realtors with no community base and no options, trying to buy the East End referendums," said Richard L. Amper Jr., the executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society.
Backers of the transfer tax said the assertion that $277 million is already available for preservation programs was false.
"That is just a pernicious lie," said Kevin McDonald, vice president of the Group for the South Fork. "They are running an ambush campaign and they know it."
Mr. McDonald said the groups had calculated that $277 million in Federal, state, county and town funds would be needed, but was not yet secured.
The groups said that with the addition of $100 million from the transfer tax, which they said would be essential to attract matching funds from other programs, the hoped-for total of $377 million could be used to protect 24,000 acres of farmland and 9,000 acres of open space on the East End.
They said this would be the minimum acreage to assure that the rural character of the East End was not obliterated.
Donald F. Savage, the director of governmental affairs for the Realtors association, denied that the ads were deceitful. "Distilling complicated information into a 30-second ad is impossible," Mr. Savage said. "The point is, funds are available that haven't been used or haven't been applied for."
Mr. McDonald and others said that last year, real estate interests in Massachusetts used tactics similar to those being used by the New York association to defeat a transfer tax proposed on Cape Cod.
Transfer taxes have been approved by voters in Martha's Vineyard, Nantucket and Block Island. Proponents of the tax say revenues have aided in preservation and helped maintain real estate values.
The East End version would impose the 2 percent tax on that portion of a house purchase price above $250,000 in Southampton, East Hampton and Shelter Island and above $150,000 in Riverhead and Southold.
It would also apply to the portion of vacant land purchase prices above $100,000 in the three towns, and above $75,000 in the other two. Sales of farmland between farmers would be exempt, a feature that helped win support for the tax from the Long Island Farm Bureau.
The East End groups said they could not match the association's spending, which they predicted would be $250,000 by Election Day. By contrast, supporters of the transfer tax have raised between $50,000 and $60,000, according to Mr. Amper.
The anti-tax ads are paid for by New Options for Open Space Preservation, a political committee financed by the Realtors association. Mr. Savage said it plans to spend more between now and Election Day but would not confirm the $250,000 estimate or predict the final amount.
"I've been around a long time and there's never been this kind of money spent before," said Edwin M. Schwenk, a former Suffolk Republican leader and co-founder with Mr. Amper of a preservation group called East End Forever.
Mr. Schwenk, who lives in Southampton, said that the transfer tax, rather than unfairly targeting buyers and sellers of real estate, involved buyers attracted to the East End in joining in local preservation efforts.
"The East End is very unique in the fact that we have done our share to save our farmlands and open space," he said. "We have paid our dues and continue to pay our dues. The next step is for people coming in from the outside because they like it here to help out."
Mr. McDonald of the Group for the South Fork said approval of the transfer tax would be "the key that unlocks the door to county, state and possibly Federal funds."
"Without it we have nothing," Mr. McDonald said.
Many backers of the tax said they remained optimistic it would be approved in all or most of the towns. "Knowing the people out here, I think they are going to support this," said Joseph M. Gergela, the executive director of the Long Island Farm Bureau in Riverhead.
Others sounded more wary. "You can sell a lot of lies for a quarter of a million dollars," Mr. Amper said.
Mr. Gergela said the town where the outcome was most in doubt was Riverhead, where the largest chunk of Suffolk's remaining farmland is located.
The transfer tax is supported by a number of real estate brokers on the East End, who split from the association and the Long Island Board of Realtors on the issue.
"This is a home-rule issue," said Jack Hangen, owner and broker of Agawam Realty in Southampton. "It's another means to preserve open space, which is one of the reasons people come to the East End, and it will keep property values up."
In contrast to the battle over the transfer tax, the $62 million county bonding proposal has moved serenely forward. Called the Suffolk County Community Greenways Fund, it was devised by County Executive Robert J. Gaffney and members of the County Legislature.
In includes $20 million for county purchase of farm development rights and $20 million for the purchase of wetlands, woodlands and open space.
To seek support in western Suffolk, where about 90 percent of county residents reside, it also includes $20 million to expand and add playing fields and other recreational facilities to county parks, primarily in parks in the five western towns. The remaining $2 million would establish an environmental education center.
Mr. Gaffney had been criticized by Mr. Amper and other preservationists for the slow pace of county action under existing protection programs. But in recent months Mr. Gaffney has sought to speed the pace, making farmland preservation a priority. "He has done a lot for the farm community," said Mr. Gergela of the farm bureau.
In announcing the bond plan in July, Mr. Gaffney said it would "insure that future generations will continue to enjoy the working farmland and open spaces that make our county so special and that our residents have access to the active recreational facilities they need." He said the cost would be $11 a year for an average taxpayer.
County officials and groups appeared confident the bond would be approved. Rejection, they said, would signal a profound shift in attitudes toward public spending for environmental programs.
In Huntington, officials said they had heard no opposition to the town's proposed $15 million environmental bond. "Huntington residents are keenly interested in environmental matters," Town Supervisor Frank P. Petrone said. "We haven't received one letter in opposition."
Mr. Petrone said approval would allow the town to apply for matching funds from county, state and Federal programs.
The Huntington proposal marks one of the first major land-preservation votes by a western Suffolk town.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
Early Retirement: So Close, So Far

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years will appear the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
A FEW years ago, when my sister-in-law Lee was turning 40, she made this announcement: "I plan to retire on Dec. 31, 1999. I will not work in the next century."
It was a bold remark. 
 But ever since, much as a bird builds its nest one twig at a time, Lee has been methodically laying the foundations for her future life -- retirement that would begin long before 50.
She left the large firm where she was one of many in-house lawyers, started her own law firm in Washington, wrote a legal reference book that promises a long stream of income and taught her sharp young hires how to run the firm and land new clients. She got into stocks and mutual funds early in the bull market and stayed with them. She has been relentless, and I'm confident that when the millennium comes, there will indeed be one less person practicing law in Washington.
My sister-in-law, of course, is not alone. Plenty of people have subdued the economic monsters of living expenses, their children's college educations and retirement savings and realized that they don't have to wait until they are in their 60's to call it quits.
And they are all not chief executives or Wall Street whizzes. Many, like Lee, are smart people who had a plan and simply stuck with it.
ONE of the fantasies of middle age is having the chance to enjoy it. We have worked hard, and the thought that we will have to toil for 10 or 20 more years before claiming our reward can be depressing. I know that I would love to wrap up my career in about 10 years, when I'm 56, but I also know that I probably won't be able to afford to.
Katy Hollister, a partner with the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche in Cincinnati, says she hears talk of early retirement all the time, as more and more clients chase the dream. Recently, she had to give a lesson in economic reality to a group of workers at a factory in the Southwest after dozens of them, having seen the value of their 401(k) plans jump, began considering such a move.
The reality is this: You have to start planning early and saving early. And you have to understand that if you retire when you are, say, 50, you might need to finance a retirement that will last as many years as your working life.
Figuring out how to pay our children's college costs is scary enough, but as Ms. Hollister pointed out, "There are no scholarships for retirement."
That doesn't worry someone else who is planning an early retirement -- a 41-year-old consultant in Manhattan who is married with two children. He started making his retirement plans when he was 33 and wants to have about $5 million in assets by the time he's 50, when he plans to retire. And he says he will achieve his goal.
"It takes financial discipline," said the consultant, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "You have to approach saving like you would paying a mortgage."
He lives frugally, owning two older cars and a modest house, and pours much of his and his wife's salaries into a combination of stocks, bonds and real estate.
"It's all about financial independence," he said. "It just means that at 50, I want to have flexibility. I don't want to have to have a job to make ends meet."
Lee, who is married and has no children, also decided to forgo a grand house; instead, she invested the money she would have paid in higher mortgage payments into the stock market.
"I've been in Washington 16 years, and I still live in a condo," she said. "I haven't had huge housing expenses."
She also decided that she could earn a lot more by working for herself, in her own law practice.
"That took the cap off my income level," she said. "It also eliminated debt from my life."
I ASKED Ms. Hollister how much I would need to retire in 10 years and still put my four children through college. She ran my numbers through her computer. Her short answer: $2.1 million. Her somewhat longer answer: Forget it, you'll never make it.
But maybe some people can. Ms. Hollister offered a rough formula to find out. First, assume that your retirement will begin in 10 years and last for 30 years, that your investments will earn a 4 percent real, or inflation-adjusted, annual return and that inflation will be a steady 4 percent a year. To estimate how much you'll need in savings on the day you retire, multiply your current annual expenses by 26.6 -- a number she derived in complex calculations from the assumptions above, based on the present and future value of money.
If, for example, you have $100,000 a year in expenses, you will need to set aside $2.66 million to join my sister-in-law -- who, by the way, doesn't plan to just lie on the beach. To her, retiring early means having the freedom to make her next move without economic pressure.
 "I don't want to retire early so I can stop doing what I am doing," Lee said. "I want to retire early so I can start doing things I am not yet doing. I have the feeling that the ability to do new things will diminish if I wait."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 36; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 523 words

HEADLINE: Taking the Economy's Pulse?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
We rely on many statistics to measure the performance of the American economy, but we need to recognize that many of them are of uncertain accuracy and significance. 
 What happens when this frailty isn't acknowledged? An example is seen in "Muscleman, or 98-Pound Weakling? Taking the Measure of an Eight-Year Economic Expansion" (Oct. 18), which apparently intended to say that the United States economy has not been as strong as we might have thought.
The article said that real income of the median household increased only 3.5 percent over 24 years -- from $35,745 in 1973 to $37,005 in 1997, in constant dollars. This measurement was obtained by adjusting the actual dollar figures by increases in the Consumer Price Index.
But many well-qualified people believe that the C.P.I. overestimates inflation; indeed, a commission of experts headed by Michael J. Boskin, the Stanford Univeristy economist, put the overstatement at 1.1 percentage points a year. If that is true, real median income has risen by 35 percent since 1973, or 10 times as much as you stated.
Moreover, we really do not know how much poverty there is in the United States, and especially whether the poverty rate is rising. A chart with the article showed that the percentage of households in poverty was higher in 1997 than in 1970. But again, these figures are sensitive to the inflation measure. Mr. Boskin has estimated that if his C.P.I. calculation is correct, the poverty rate in 1995 was 9 percent, not the official figure of 13.8 percent.
But there are other uncertainties in gauging the poverty rate. For example, should poverty be measured by income or by expenditures? In contrast to the picture you paint -- of a poverty rate hovering in the 12 to 14 percent range for the past two decades -- one could plausibly draw a picture of the rate sharply declining, possibly to as low as 2 or 3 percent.
The article also made this observation: "A huge problem left unresolved as the expansion appears to wind down is a divisive inequality that has developed among income groups, a trend that took root in the 1980's and that the 1990's expansion has failed to interrupt." But income distribution is a subject in which the difficulties of definition, measurement and interpretation are especially great.
To say anything significant about this subject, we need to consider how age, family status and educational attainment are distributed among various groups and how income is defined and measured. For example, we know that the earnings of people who have not finished high school are lagging behind those of people with a college education. But we also know that far more people are now college graduates. Should we view this combination of facts as evidence of greater or less inequality?
I do not claim to know the truth about what has happened to real incomes, poverty or income distribution. My point is that you don't know, either, and should have acknowledged as much.
 
HERBERT STEIN
Washington, Oct. 21
 
The writer was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Nixon Administration.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SHEEPSHEAD BAY;
'Chief' Finds New Arena: Politics

BYLINE: By EDWARD LEWINE 

 BODY:
Robert Comas put down his half-eaten roast beef sandwich and explained how being a team mascot prepared him for politics. It was lunchtime Tuesday in the back of Brennan & Carr, a restaurant at Nostrand Avenue and Avenue U.
"During my years as the Chief, I learned a lot about shaking hands," said Mr. Comas, 54, the Conservative Party candidate for the State Senate in the 21st District, which includes Sheepshead Bay, Mill Basin and other parts of southern Brooklyn. 
 From 1971 to 1995, Mr. Comas was the Chief, the unofficial mascot of the New York Rangers hockey team. Without seeking approval from the team, Mr. Comas would don a feathered headdress and wander around Madison Square Garden shaking hands, whooping and doing a war dance. He retired as the Chief in 1995, one year after the Rangers had won their first championship since 1940.
This spring he was at a meeting of the local Republican club when it was looking for a Senate candidate. "I've always been a political junkie," he said. "There were no other nominees, so I raised my hand and said, 'I'll run.' "
In the end Mr. Comas failed to collect enough signatures and the Republicans have no candidate in the contest. But Mr. Comas is running, on the Conservative line.
Mr. Comas is a portly man with a pleasant lisp. He said he is all but unemployed and lives with his mother in the house where he grew up on East 28th Street. He also acknowledged that he has no campaign to speak of and little chance of defeating the incumbent, Carl Kruger.
"I know I'm a sacrificial lamb," Mr. Comas said. "My opponent is big in the community."
Mr. Kruger, a two-term Democrat, agrees. "I've never seen him in 25 years of public life," the Senator said. "I've only seen him at Rangers games."
But that doesn't mean that Mr. Comas is lacking in political ideas. He calls himself a moderate Republican and favors lowering subway and bus fares and either reducing or ending state sales taxes. "I want the nomination again in two years," he said. "This isn't the last Kruger will see of me."
But whatever the future brings, Mr. Comas has insured his legacy as the Chief, a character that just popped into his head one night during a game in 1971.
"He was one of the people who rallied the fans," said Sam Rosen, who announces Rangers games on television. "It was hard not to notice him. He was running around with a headdress on." EDWARD LEWINE

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
That Market Bottom Might Be A Trap Door

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
AS almost anyone with a market memory can attest, the month of October is not usually friendly for stocks. Since 1915, the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen an average 0.17 percent in the 10th month of the year, according to Birinyi & Associates. Only Septembers have been worse.
This year, September was a washout. But with one week to go, October has proved to be the best month since January 1987. The performance has been enough to induce hibernation in many bears. 
 Then there is James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer.
 
Q. Many people seem to think the stock market has seen its lows. You don't agree?

A. If this were the bottom, it would be the most remarkable one in history, one where the Standard & Poor's 500 index is trading at 25 times earnings. That is a valuation rarely achieved at the top of a market.
 I think that this is a bear market rally. I would suppose that if the market gods were designing a bear market rally, they would make it look as irresistible as possible and would want as many participants as possible before opening the trap door.
 
Q. But there are hundreds of stocks, especially small caps, that are down 25 percent or more this year. Are they overpriced?
 
A. Really cheap stocks are beginning to appear. The great, overarching question is whether you are well advised to seize values in the secondary and tertiary parts of the market when the primary market is selling at these multiples.
In my view, the answer is no, because when the G.E.'s, the Charles Schwabs and the other chosen fall, they will crush the smaller ones beneath them.
 
Q. Do you see value anywhere?
 
A. I have two favorite things: small-cap Japanese stocks and gold. There are opportunities in Japan to buy profitable companies at little more than the net cash on their balance sheets. You get the business for free. Gold, now at an 18-year low, has disappointed more people than the old Brooklyn Dodgers. But I think it will be the beneficiary of continued chaos in the credit markets and a worldwide economic slowdown.
 
Q. Do you see anything of value closer to home? Or a company that is a massive, screaming short?
 
A. I see both, actually.
In Canada, there is an outfit called Legacy Hotels, which is a real estate investment trust with a bunch of lovely properties spun out by the real estate division of Canadian Pacific. You can buy this stock for about half of book value, with a yield in the low teens, an outfit with good management that is priced in Canadian dollars, which are very cheap relative to the U.S. dollar. The risk is that there is a severe recession and the business travelers stay home.
 
Q. What about the screaming short?
 
A. The short sale is Charles Schwab, a stock that is trading at 38 to 40 times earnings, 10 times book value. Schwab is priced as if there were no doubt about the continued health and prosperity of the bull market.
 
Q. Now that the Fed has cut interest rates twice in a matter of weeks, fears of a credit crunch and recession have diminished. Is that an appropriate reaction?
 
A. The credit crisis may sound melodramatic, but over the last several months there has been a very severe bear market in credit of all kinds. And it should be seen in the context of the preceding bull market in credit, where it was freely, if not almost promiscuously, available.
There is no recession we know of right now, and yet we have had a credit crisis in this country, which in the postwar period is a rare if not unique occurrence. It makes you wonder what will happen to this institution of borrowing and lending if there is an actual deflation, or an actual recession.
 
Q. But isn't it the Fed's job to take steps to prevent a credit crunch?
 
A. It has been the suppression of cycles that paradoxically has created a lot of the volatility we have seen in the credit markets. By succeeding in perpetuating the expansion, the Fed has failed in the sense that it has changed the behavior of people with money.
By saving Mexico a couple of years ago, the authorities changed the way people view sovereign credit risk. Hence the surprise when the Russian Government defaulted. A visitor from Mars would not have been surprised that a country without money could not pay its bills. But many were surprised, because they had come to expect that the integrity of the system will be defended.
By suppressing the volatility of the credit and business cycle, by trying to head off price inflations and deflations, the Fed has thrown a boomerang in the air, which is the risk tolerance of people who invest money.
The Fed ought to be in the business of central banking, not central planning. Alan Greenspan ought to say that people who risk money stand to lose a lot of it. That is in the nature of cycles and markets.

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Grant

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Even Amida High-Tech Revolution, Evolution Is the Norm

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE New Economy is on trial here along with the Microsoft Corporation.
Sure, the company is the one in the dock. But the outcome of the case against Microsoft will establish the ground rules for how the doctrine of antitrust will apply to high-technology fields like computer software. And the software industry is seen as being at the forefront of new patterns of behavior by workers, companies and markets that define the New Economy. 
 In the New Economy, people live on Internet time and product cycles are measured in months, not years. It is the slice of the economy driven by entrepreneurs, stock options and network effects. Silicon Valley is its headquarters, with subsidiaries in Seattle, Austin and elsewhere. It is the future, its proponents insist, coming to your home soon.
If Microsoft wins, the digital age will unfold as a free-fire zone of let-'er-rip capitalism, for better or worse. If Microsoft loses, courts or the antitrust watchdogs may be getting their oars into such complex matters as product design, for better or worse.
Let the courts decide. But for an analytic examination of struggle and competition at the edge of the New Economy today, a new book, "Competing on Internet Time: Lessons from Netscape and Its Battle with Microsoft" (The Free Press), offers some intriguing insights. The book, written by Michael A. Cusumano, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management, and David B. Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard Business School, was placed in evidence at the Microsoft trial last week.
In its defense, Microsoft points to passages in the book in which executives of Netscape Communications are quoted speaking candidly about their missteps. Microsoft calls these statements proof that Netscape's travails in the Internet browser market were its own doing, not because Microsoft was acting like a nasty monopolist.
Yet the book as a whole reads as a coming-of-age account of the triumphs and setbacks of a fast-moving Internet pioneer daring or foolish enough to take on the dominant company in computing. Netscape's experience teaches as much about what hasn't changed as what has.
A fundamental lesson is that even revolutionary technologies take time to cause a revolution. No matter how great the tail wind of hype and venture capital, the Next Big Thing takes time to change the practices and habits of companies and people. "Netscape got too ambitious and too wedded to the belief that the Internet revolution would change everything tomorrow," Mr. Yoffie explained.
The threat Netscape posed to Microsoft was that its browser could serve as an alternative "platform" to Microsoft's Windows. In other words, the browser could take the place of Windows as the first thing users see when they start their computers and as the departure point from which applications could be started.
But it takes a long time for a new computing platform to catch hold, as thousands of software programmers gradually become converts and write applications that work with the new platform. By often and publicly declaring that it was going to challenge Microsoft head-on, Netscape aroused the software giant, which trailed in Internet software. "Netscape had the perfect Trojan horse," Mr. Yoffie said. "But it woke up the enemy before it was entrenched."
As it matured, Netscape also found that while the speed of product development was important, so was traditional product quality. Netscape's freewheeling "hacker culture" fostered flexibility and creativity -- one Netscape manager quoted in the book described its development style as "slightly out of control" -- but also led to buggy software, a nuisance that became problematic with more sales to quality-conscious corporations.
In the last year or so, the authors note, Netscape has made strides in quality, hiring testers and increasing its use of automated testing software. Netscape has increased its ratio of testers to developers from one-to-five to one-to-three, though it still trails Microsoft's one-to-one ratio. "You can be fast and flexible in software development, but you have to pay the price in testing," Mr. Cusumano said.
Netscape's future is by no means assured. But for all the talk at the trial about Microsoft trying to crush it, Netscape has done a good job of changing its strategy to avoid tackling Microsoft head-on whenever possible.
What Netscape, the Internet pioneer, has learned -- setting aside the legal issues -- is precisely what the pioneers of the personal-computer revolution learned. They declared that their technology would change the world, but the process works in the other direction, too. For a breakthrough technology to move into the mainstream, it must become more mainstream -- easier, more reliable and more useful for the workaday chores of the economy. It does not change everything overnight.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Pier Developers Look Toward Harlem

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
ON a recent Friday afternoon, a beam of sun cast a glow on Rover Green's face, as his fishing line tightened under an unseen weight in the Hudson River. Mr. Green has been fishing on the esplanade at the western edge of 125th Street for the past 20 years, arriving most days about 3 P.M., after he gets off work as a building manager, and heading home to 127th Street a few hours later.
Mr. Green, 55, is one of the few diehard Harlem residents who still visit the Harlem waterfront esplanade. Once a hub of maritime activity, the area has been in disrepair for at least two decades. Today, the boardwalk is broken in many places, the road is littered with broken bottles and rats roam at night. 
 Still, the area from 125th to 133d Streets -- known as the Harlem Piers, even though the piers are long gone -- is the last stretch of Manhattan shoreline between 72d Street and Fort Tryon Park that offers direct access to the Hudson River, said Maritta Dunn, chairwoman of Community Board 9. As such, she said, it has great value.
"Right now it is lying dormant," said Ms. Dunn, who took the Day Liner ferry from the Harlem Piers to Bear Mountain when she was a child. "But the community would be foolish to allow it to continue to lie dormant."
For many years the city, developers and residents have debated what should be done with the area, but no idea has yet achieved enough support to move beyond the planning stage.
But last November, Board 9 asked the Economic Development Corporation to seek proposals for the site, and on June 15, the agency did so.
Charles Millard, president of the Economic Development Corporation, said the waterfront area was attractive to developers because it is near the 125th Street business corridor, and added, "The Mayor wants to do everything he can to keep the development ball rolling in Harlem."
Moreover, he said, "There is significant untapped spending power in Harlem, and significant tourism."
By the Oct. 16 deadline, the agency had received several proposals, although Bernadette O'Leary, a spokeswoman, said she could not discuss their exact number or nature because of confidentiality agreements. A few of the developers, however, shared their ideas.
Destination Harlem Development, a Harlem-based group, offered an $83 million plan to build a 24-story, 450-room hotel, called the New Teresa, on 125th Street overlooking the water. The group is made up of two private developers, Full Spectrum Hotel Partners and Resource Planning and Development.
Inside the hotel, there would be a museum of Harlem history, a dinner theater run by Sylvia's Restaurant, a seafood restaurant, a retail pavilion, conference centers for up to 500 people and an entertainment center. Outside, the developers plan to rebuild the esplanade and to construct a concert band shell and a Hudson River environmental center, which would be open to the public.
Carlton Brown, vice president of marketing for Full Spectrum Hotel Partners, said the New Teresa would be the only hotel in Harlem. The average daily rate for rooms would be $160, which Mr. Brown said is significantly less than the typical midtown rate.
"We think it's a great location because it has access to a highway, sits on the 125th Street corridor and is easily accessible to a large university area," Mr. Brown said. Columbia University, Barnard College and St. Luke's Hospital are some of the educational and other institutions in Harlem, he said.
Another idea, offered by Pier 63 Maritime Inc., which owns a pier at 23d Street, is to dock three large barges off 125th Street to serve as floating piers. They would be arranged to create an L-shaped marina off the esplanade, where people could dock boats, take sailing lessons, fish or enjoy the view. The rooms inside the barges would be community spaces, available for public meetings and private parties.
John R. Krevey, president of Pier 63 Maritime, owns a historic lighthouse boat, and he plans to dock that boat, or one like it, at the end of one of the barges as a tourist attraction.
David Avital, a private investor, and Vilkas, Peles Architects put forth another barge plan. Their proposal, called the Harlem River Center, would create an entertainment and sports complex on two parallel barges. One of the barges would be equipped with a golf driving range, a restaurant and a parking lot; the other would be a combined museum and sanctuary for the bald eagle.
The center would also include a volleyball court on the esplanade, a ramp for launching boats south of the piers and, during the summer, a floating stage. Mr. Avital said he would encourage New York Waterway, which runs the Ferry of New York, to use one barge as a terminal for the ferry, to transport people from the World Trade Center and New Jersey to and from Harlem.
The advantage of Pier 63's plan, called Harlem on the Hudson, is that it is relatively inexpensive, said Huntley Gill, a design consultant to the project. He said the whole endeavor would cost less than $1 million and would generate about $1.2 million in revenues each year.
"It's eminently feasible," Mr. Gill said. "It's not expensive, it's not complicated and it doesn't require a lot of capital to get started. So it could actually happen."
The Harlem River Center would cost more, $4 million, and employ about 70 people. Its advantages? "The elements we have are environmental and community oriented," Mr. Avital said.
The New Teresa Hotel proposal has been touted at community board meetings as a major revitalization plan. The developers say the project would bring in 573 jobs and generate $50 million in gross revenue annually.
The Economic Development Corporation will not complete its consideration of these and other proposals until next year. "Typically, it takes at least three months, but it can really depend on the specific site," Ms. O'Leary said.
In the meantime, a coalition of Harlem organizations, led by West Harlem Environmental Action and Community Board 9, is developing its own proposal. The group has received a grant from the Department of Energy to begin considering ideas to redesign the area from St. Clair Place to 133d Street, and east from the esplanade to Broadway. They are leaning toward creating a waterfront park, similar to that planned for the Hudson below 59th Street.
The coalition has asked the agency to postpone making a decision until the plan is complete.
"We don't feel this was the right way to go about doing a request for proposals," said Petty M. Shepard, executive director of West Harlem Environmental Action. "They should never have moved ahead on the process without coming to the community first."
Ms. O'Leary responded, "The community will be involved in the process. The request for proposals is an opportunity to see what possibilities the marketplace may offer for the site."
Those who fish on the pier, like Mr. Green, say they would like to be consulted, too.
"A fishing pier would be nice, benches, lighting at night, and maybe some pesticides to deal with the rats," said Juan Nunez, 35, who visits the piers three times a week. When asked if he would like to see commercial development at the shoreline, he said, "No way."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A floating swimming pool (top) and a 24-story, 450-room New Teresa hotel are among the possibilities for an area that now features cars in varying states of disrepair. Chart: "Timeline: The Piers Through the Years"
 
Early 1900's -- Development of several piers in Harlem begins, along with extensions to Harlem of the IRT and IND subway lines.
 
Late 1920's -- West 125th Street pier is used as a terminal for regular ferry service to Fort Lee, N.J.

1928 -- A recreation pier is built at St. Clair Place, with an esplanade, fishing area and seating to watch the traffic on the Hudson.
 
1930's - 1940's -- Ferry and rail service at the Harlem piers is ended.
 
Late 1940's -- West 125th Street pier is demolished.
 
Late 1950's -- St. Clair Place recreational pier is demolished.
 
Mid-1980's -- The Harlem Urban Development Corporation proposes to build luxury housing, a marina, hotel, nightclubs and a cultural center on the piers, called "Harlem on the Hudson."
 
1988 -- Community Board 9 passes a resolution against the Harlem Urban Development Corporation plan.
 
June 1988 -- The Economic Development Corporation issues a request for proposals to develop the Harlem Piers.
 
(Source: New York City Economic Development Corporation.)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Russian Oil: So Much, Yet So Little

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
HIDDEN beneath the vast Russian land mass and the Arctic waters around it could lie more oil than enriches the Middle East, many experts believe. Yet despite decades of effort, the Russian oil industry has tapped only a small fraction of it.
For a brief time, that seemed about to change. The fall of the Soviet Union brought a flood of Western oil executives, offering to spend tens of billions of dollars and provide much-needed expertise. 
 Agreements were signed, wells were drilled, expertise and technology began to arrive and, most important, capital -- lots of it -- was on the verge of being spent.
But even before the latest Russian crisis, the winds began to shift. Political turmoil, combined with a growing concern that Russia would lose control of a vast natural resource, stalled the legislation and the changes demanded by Western companies before they would loosen the purse strings.
So, again, the world's oil executives must wait out a crisis. They could give up, of course, but most are convinced that they cannot afford to -- the potential is too great.
Still, it could be a long wait, because there is a growing suspicion in the industry that nothing can be accomplished in Russia until a new generation comes to power.
"The country is very reluctant to allow others to exploit their natural resources," said John J. O'Connor, a senior vice president at Texaco Inc.
Some analysts worry that unless investment begins to flow soon, Russian oil exports could slip. That could make it even harder for Russia to come out of its economic crisis and provide the money that Russian oil companies need to keep up production.
"Everybody is in a wait-and-see mode and will not give the cash," said John D. Hervey, an oil analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "If the major oil companies don't invest, then Russia won't be able to maintain its infrastructure even at its currently poor level."
Through it all, Russia has managed to keep some dollars flowing. "Even when their domestic consumption went down, they have been able to maintain their exports in the last few years," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, a research group based in New York.
Last year, Russian exports averaged 2.51 million barrels a day, and for the first half of this year they were up slightly. But because of lower prices for crude oil on the world market, revenue plunged to about $5.6 billion in the first half of the year from $7.3 billion in the comparable period last year.
Russian oil companies, meanwhile, are facing new obstacles as their country stumbles. Russian Customs officials have begun demanding prepayment of various charges, according to Georgi Bedineishvili, an analyst at Salomon Brothers.
At a time when Russian oil companies need capital desperately, it is drying up. Until recently, Western oil companies, often stymied in getting their own projects off the ground in Russia, invested in native companies as the only way to get into the game.
Atlantic Richfield bought an 8 percent stake in Lukoil, Russia's largest private oil concern, a couple of years ago for $344 million, and formed a joint venture that was planning to invest about $5 billion in Russia and neighboring countries. And British Petroleum bought a 10 percent stake in Sidanko in the spring for about $500 million.
The eagerness to invest, however, evaporated by June. The attempt to sell a 75 percent stake in Rosneft, the last big energy company on the Government's privatization list, did not attract any buyers, even when the price fell from $1.6 billion to $470 million.
Another blow was a decision earlier this month by Elf Aquitaine, the French oil company, to abandon an effort to buy a stake in Sibneft for about $570 million because of worries about lower oil prices.
In addition, the Government has been going after the oil companies for huge amounts of taxes that they owe, adding to the pressure to obtain capital.
Russian banks, which came into big stakes in most of the oil companies when the companies defaulted on loans, are largely unable to help.
Mr. Bedineishvili said the fate of the industry now rests largely on how the new Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, and the Parliament respond to the country's overall financial crisis. "You cannot isolate the oil companies from what will happen in the country in general," he said.
For now, most Russian oil companies are trying to muddle through.
Rosneft -- in partnership with Exxon and Sodeco, a Japanese oil company -- has spent close to $400 million exploring an oilfield off Sakhalin Island in eastern Siberia, an area believed to contain about 2.9 billion barrels of oil. But the Russian company had trouble paying its share of the exploration costs.
Sergey Bogdanchikov, Rosneft's new president, said in a recent interview in the Russian newspaper Kommersant Daily that his company, unable to collect much of what customers owe it, , was in a critical situation. The sale of Rosneft was not feasible now, he said, adding, "To my mind, we shall need one and a half to two years to bring the company into the shape where it will be worth $2 billion to $3 billion."
Others have decided to divest. Yukos, Russia's second-largest private oil producer, is trying to rid itself of 53 oilfields and about 3,000 workers by transferring them to new companies partly owned by local governments.
Some Western executives are hopeful that the Kremlin can eventually work its way out of the crisis.
"The new Government offers pragmatic partnership potential," said Mr. O'Connor of Texaco, which is seeking to develop the Timon Pechora Basin in northern Siberia. It has also teamed up with Mobil Oil to develop some of the reserves in the Kirinsky field off Sakhalin Island.
"When we make multibillion-dollar decisions, you have to have the confidence that the system is predictable and stable," he said. "All these things are absent."

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Barreling Downhill"
Russia is the world's second-largest exporter of oil, after Saudi Arabia. But low global energy prices have aggravated its economic crisis and hampered investment. Production has fallen sharply from its 1988 peak of 11.4 million barrels a day, and exports have stagnated at a time when world consumption is rising.
