HEADLINE: Market Puts Price Tags on the Priceless

SERIES: IN SEARCH OF A CHILD: The Baby Bazaar -- Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

 BODY:
The first commandment for couples wanting to adopt babies is: Put yourselves across. And they do, in spunky performances on videotapes, in lush scrapbooks and in professional portraiture smiling on the Internet.
Many speak on the Web pages that crowd electronic registries of "waiting families." Gloyd and Penny, for example, say, "We pray daily for our birth mother and baby -- whoever and wherever they are." David and Paula promise, "This child will be overwhelmed by love and affection." Rex and Carol wait, after 14 years of marriage, with a spaniel named Brittney and a vacation home four miles from Disney World. 
 This is the essence of demand -- unhappily infertile couples -- competing for a smaller and smaller supply of white American-born infants. It is an imbalance that professionals in the adoption world are calling a crisis, allowing money to play a defining role in determining who will succeed in this desperate quest for that which cannot be legally bought or sold.
"In this marketplace, it's a sad reality," said Graham Wright, president of the California Association of Adoption Agencies. "Luck enters into it, but it's like anything else in life: If you have enough money, you'll get what you think you want."
Many couples in search of a child are already depleted, emotionally and financially, by drawn-out fertility treatments. Still, they will pay $15,000 to $20,000 on average, even if they have to mortgage their futures, to find their babies. Some will spend much more before the day they appear in court to take legal custody of their children. And a few, people who have the money for intermediaries to do the work, pay up to $100,000 to bring home a newborn.
Adoption is, in a rough analogy to organ transplants, a legal transfer not subject to purchase or bidding. Nowhere in the United States is it legal to sell a child, and few say it should be. Nor can anyone sell the right to be an adoptive parent: that is conferred by the state, based on home studies conducted by social workers.
But scarcity has created a cast of thousands of intermediaries, who can and do sell access to the young women who might relinquish babies.
Access can be sold indirectly, by an Internet service that sells advertising space to couples, for example, or directly, by lawyers or unlicensed brokers known as "facilitators," who will either shop couples to pregnant women or recruit those who agree to let adoptive families be chosen for them.
This has left only the thinnest line between buying a child and buying adoption services that lead to a child. "The effect is the same," said Mr. Wright, whose agency, Future Families of Monterey Bay, places older children for adoption and foster care.
"Everywhere the baby boomers set their feet, a cottage industry springs up," said Bernie Riff, an adoptive father. Mr. Riff and his wife, Vicki Young, adopted their daughter, Jessi, 2, with the help of a facilitator after waiting a long time with an agency that gave them, in Ms. Young's words, "nothing but a binder."
"There are consultants and facilitators," Mr. Riff said. "There are photographers, there are all these little marketing things. People do videos. There's no limit to what you can spend on these things if you're inclined to and have the resources."
State-licensed adoption agencies, once strictly controlled charitable and paternalistic institutions, may be pained by the intrusion of commerce, but now they, too, advertise on bus shelters and billboards, and collect scrapbooks and videos from would-be parents to show to birth mothers. They mine connections with foreign orphanages. They do what they can do to increase their supply of children. It is just one measure of growth within this fragmented industry that the number of licensed child placement agencies has increased by several hundred in just three years, to 1,764, according to the National Adoption Information Clearinghouse.
The states impose standards on child-placement agencies requiring certified social workers to evaluate prospective parents, counsel birth mothers and get relinquishment papers signed. They limit payments that can go to birth mothers, who, above all, are not supposed to profit from adoption, and they require reports to the courts of all payments made by the adopting family.
But the laws differ from state to state, creating a tangle that itself keeps lawyers busy and would-be parents confounded. A few states, like Massachusetts and Connecticut, prohibit independent adoptions altogether; some that do allow it, like New York, hew to the traditional model and limit lawyers' roles; California, the most hospitable to the new entrepreneurialism, allows lawyers and facilitators to recruit prospective birth mothers on clients' behalf. Louisiana, known for its laxity, allows nonresidents to adopt and to pay extensive living expenses for pregnant women.
The process, while hardly simple, is basically the same everywhere. Every adopting couple typically begins with a home study. If parents adopt independently, they will probably advertise, although about a dozen states prohibit it. Pregnant women who respond or are referred to them are screened, and adoptive and biological parents exchange basic biographies. If all goes well, the adoptive parents pay modest pregnancy-related expenses for the birth mother and, shortly after birth, she legally relinquishes the child. (If the biological mother decides not to place the child, or, worse, tries to revoke her consent later, the adoptive parents have gambled and lost.) Six months to a year later, a court finalizes the adoption.
The costs for domestic infant adoptions range widely. Some people adopt infants, joyously and quickly, for $5,000 or $10,000 by locating a woman in their own state who has minimal expenses and is certain she wants to place her child. Placements by state agencies often cost nothing.
Then there are couples who pay sums approaching $100,000 for a closed adoption of a white newborn. These gray-market placements, which usually involve questionable payments to birth mothers and the brokers who find them, have prompted much legislation and public attention; still, they are a tiny percentage of adoptions.
Finally, the stamp of the marketplace is apparent in one troubling fact: In the baby bazaar, with children of varying colors, cultures and conditions, something resembling a price schedule has emerged.
At many agencies, race determines fees, said William Pierce, president of the National Council for Adoption, an advocacy group for agencies. "If you have 40 white couples chasing every white newborn, you don't need a lesson in economics," Mr. Pierce said.
 
The Product
Not Enough Babies To Meet the Demand
If adoption is a growth industry, it is not because of a major increase in adoptions.
No one keeps nationwide statistics on adoptions. The most reliable and recent data come from 1992, when researchers gathered statistics from state agencies for a report on adoptions published by the National Center for State Courts. The number of adoptions reported was 127,441, a figure that demographers believe has not changed appreciably. The authors of the report estimated that two-thirds were adopted by stepparents or relatives, or were older children placed from foster-care programs.
The other third, or about 43,000, constitute the heart of the industry: children, domestic and foreign, placed with nonrelatives. The National Council for Adoption estimates that infants, which it defines as children under age 2, account for 48 percent of all unrelated domestic adoptions or about 24,000 a year. At the same time, according to a rough estimate by the adoption council, about 1 million families are seeking to adopt.
"Adoption from a domestic standpoint is in a period of crisis," said Paige McCoy Smith, marketing coordinator for the Gladney Center in Fort Worth, one of the nation's biggest and oldest adoption agencies. Because less than 2 percent of unmarried pregnant women are placing their babies for adoption, they now have "the option to be very, very selective," she said.
Elizabeth Bartholet, a Harvard University law professor and adoption specialist with two adopted children, agrees. Among young pregnant women, she said, "most of the pressure they are subjected to is to either abort or keep."
A generation ago, unmarried, pregnant women did not have many options. Some went to places like Gladney or the Salvation Army's Booth homes, where they awaited birth while social workers chose adoptive parents.
Before 1973, the year that abortion was legalized, about 9 percent of births to unmarried women in the United States resulted in adoptions. By 1981 that percentage dropped to 4 percent, and by 1988 to 2 percent. While the number of unmarried women giving birth has risen each year at least since 1965, the net result is a slight decline in the number of American-born infants available for adoption.
The old-line agencies tried to adapt by letting birth mothers choose adoptive parents. But in the late 1970's, would-be parents began defecting to lawyers who could help them adopt independently if they -- or the lawyers -- could find a birth mother directly. The scramble also invited a new type of adoption agency, promising some edge.
American Adoptions of Overland Park, Kan., for example, has a "traditional program" in which pregnant women choose from an array of profiles of families, but it advises many clients to sign up instead for another program in which parents pay directly for advertisements, and young women who respond are shown the profile of that family first. In its letter to applicants, the agency says: "Most traditional adoption programs provide the birth parents with the opportunity to select their 'ideal' family. Where does that leave you?"
 
The Marketing
Advertising on Buses, Benches and Beyond
Marketing came naturally to Arty Elgart, who started a facilitation service after he adopted his son (from Gladney) 20 years ago. It was a matter of enthusiasm and altruism: Working out of his auto-parts warehouse in Philadelphia, he made matches as a favor for couples he knew, or friends of friends. By most accounts, including his own, no one had seen anything quite like it before. Mr. Elgart placed a small newspaper ad that asked, "PREGNANT? Young couple wishes to adopt baby. Call Mary, 289-2229."
In the view of the sedate nonprofit agencies that dominated the adoption community, this crossed a line of propriety. Mr. Elgart's matchmaking was legal, since he charged no fee and advertising was not prohibited in Pennsylvania. But his marketing, which progressed to benches, buses and Burger King tray liners, was called everything from unusual to appalling.
Mr. Elgart has long since turned his mission into a full-service licensed adoption agency, named Golden Cradle, now in Cherry Hill, N.J. But Mr. Elgart no longer has the field to himself.
"Golden Cradle started something," said Maxine Chalker, a social worker by training who is executive director of Adoptions from the Heart, said during an interview in her office in Wynnewood, Pa. When she started her agency in 1984, she said, "in the phone book there were maybe three ads under Adoption Services. Now there must be 40."
A modest display ad for Adoptions From the Heart is among them. The agency also advertises on bus shelters and in malls, and has tried radio and television, though the response was disappointing. "We're always trying to find new things," Ms. Chalker said. "It gets harder every year because of the competition."
Some of the competition comes from lawyers who handle independent adoptions: "Now everybody thinks adoption is easy money, especially the attorneys," Ms. Chalker said. "Now they're hiring counselors to work in their offices, and setting up as agencies without being licensed."
Adoptions From the Heart has 33 staff members and seven offices in five states. The agency has an advertising budget of $371,000 this year, accounting for 16 percent of its total expenses.
"The ad budget," Ms. Chalker mused. "It's so embarrassing. It's so much money, and that's just to stay in business."
To stay in business, Adoptions From the Heart has also extended its connections in China and Vietnam; it has placed 114 babies from China and 16 from Vietnam this year, compared with 47 American-born infants. The agency charges a fee of $14,700 for placement of a white American infant or toddler; legal fees are an additional $2,000 to $3,000, and parents pay any medical costs not covered by insurance. The cost of adopting from China is $17,235 and adopting from Vietnam is $22,100.
"Our facilitator in Vietnam charges $10,000 per baby," Ms. Chalker said. "Can you imagine how rich she must be?"
 
The Sales Agents
Matchmakers Make Money in the Process
The frontier state for the adoption business is California. The state has long permitted lawyers to recruit pregnant women. Now, facilitation services, which are unlicensed, are also recruiting and screening birth parents, as well as coaching prospective parents and finding them professional help.
Facilitators operate in many states. While their activities often come close to legal definitions of child placement, they are too new or too few to prompt regulation.
But in California, legislation enacted last year to clarify their role ended up legitimizing a whole new class of entrepreneurs. Lil Snee, a facilitator in Los Gatos who co-founded an informal trade organization, estimates that 40 to 50 are operating in the state.
"California decided that the market will dictate costs and the market will dictate who stays in business," said Diane Michelsen, an adoption lawyer in Lafayette, Calif. The competition from facilitators, Ms. Michelsen said, simply means that pregnant women can shop around more.
"It's the same pool of birth mothers that's being divided differently," she said.
For Ellen Roseman, a facilitator in San Anselmo, the main job is coaching prospective parents. "I make them read everything," she said. "It's like taking a college course." Then she helps them piece together deals with pregnant women, lawyers and agencies, often in other states. She charges a flat fee of $3,450.
At a recent support-group meeting at Ms. Roseman's house on a winding lane in Marin County, casually dressed current and former clients, many with babies in hand, exchanged stories of false starts and disappointments.
"I think it will get easier with time as people know what to expect, but for now, it's a free-for-all," Mr. Riff, of Berkeley, said over the potluck dinner that followed.
For Ms. Roseman, a former flight attendant and representative in union negotiations, the enterprise is more like putting together a business deal. "You sit down and move around the pieces to do two things," she said, "to make sure it's legal and to save money."
She does not recruit pregnant women, but she gets referrals and interviews candidates. "To really get the birth parents ready," she said, "you do what's called shaking them out of the trees. You say, 'If you have a little feeling down here telling you to keep your baby, we've got to talk about that.' "
Ms. Roseman hounds prospective parents, too. With one, she said, "I insisted that she hit a therapist's office two or three times a week, get into meditation and get a massage to relieve her anxieties."
Lil Snee, the Los Gatos facilitator, also does what she calls "hand-holding," charging $2,900 for an 18-month contract. Occasionally, clients pay her $95 a hour to interview a birth mother.
"It just feels wrong" for prospective parents to ask questions "about sexual partners, about how many men might be the father of this baby," Ms. Snee said, so she asks the questions instead.
"I bring the clients and the birth parents the kinds of families they're looking for," she said.
That, Ms. Snee said, is her metier. "Let's say you have a Hispanic-black baby and you have 20 waiting families," she said. "This birth mother is committed, intelligent, clean, but every single waiting family wants an Anglo baby with blond hair. Or I probably have about six cases where the babies are white, but maybe the mother wanted a certain religion, or a home with no children in the family. Maybe she did a little drugs and people are afraid of that."
In some states, matchmaking for a fee is illegal except by licensed agencies. Among them is New York, where lawyers can handle independent adoptions and advise their clients on finding pregnant women, but not make such an introduction themselves. In New Jersey, an individual -- say, a lawyer or social worker -- may make a match, but may not charge for it.
California's new law does restrict facilitators' practices. They must identify themselves as such in their advertising and must tell prospective parents that they are not licensed adoption agencies. They must obtain a $10,000 insurance bond to cover claims. But the state does not register nor license them, and it does not limit their fees.
Randall B. Hicks, an adoption lawyer in Riverside, Calif., and the author of "Adopting in America" (Wordslinger Press, 1995) calls facilitators "a garage industry." Mr. Hicks said they are "not licensed nor trained to do anything."
He also finds their fees, which can exceed $12,000, out of line. "They find a baby for you," Mr. Hicks said, "then they have to turn it over to a lawyer or an agency."
Ms. Snee, who lobbied for a licensing system to give facilitators credibility, accepts that that only lawyers can transact the actual adoption. But she argues: "We get so bashed. We provide a service, and just because it involves adoption doesn't mean we should be the saviors of the world and do everything for free."
Ms. Roseman contends that California's competitive marketplace keeps fees down and that expenses for birth mothers are fairly limited by the state courts. In the adoptions she handles, she said, "very little money changes hands."
Louisiana, on the other hand, "is wide open," Ms. Roseman said. "I always joke, when I want to make a million dollars, I'm going to open an agency in Louisiana and I'll be charging $30,000, $40,000, $50,000. I'm going to get fat eating bonbons in Louisiana."
 
The Factory
The Draw of a State With Lax Regulations
Louisiana is where Misty and Donnie Smoot ended up two years ago, when an agency installed them in a slightly down-at-the-heels apartment complex in Baton Rouge. "I was down there the second weekend after I found out I was pregnant," said Mrs. Smoot, who lives in Nashville. Her husband added: "They try to get you down there and get you stuck."
It is possible to find a birth mother anywhere in the country, send her to live in Louisiana, pay her expenses and fees to intermediaries, have her relinquish the child in Louisiana and finalize the adoption there, all while living elsewhere. And some couples who can afford it, most of them in the Northeast, do just that.
Most states limit payments to medical, legal and strictly defined living expenses. Louisiana does not, though all expenses must be reported to the court that finalizes the adoption. The state does not prohibit payments to intermediaries, and its Department of Social Services, which regulates adoption, receives no information on agencies' fees.
The Smoots were recruited as birth parents for a couple whose names they never knew. They were living in Tennessee and having marital problems, Mrs. Smoot said, when she became pregnant. Responding to a newspaper classified ad, they said, they spoke to a man named Richard in Florida who explained that he had clients interesting in adopting, and who referred them to an agency outside Baton Rouge.
They were given first-class plane tickets for themselves and their two young sons and moved into an apartment rented by the agency, Beacon House. The agency paid rent and utilities, gave them $150 a week for groceries and ferried Mrs. Smoot to doctor's appointments and group meetings. Mrs. Smoot estimated that Beacon House had 12 to 20 birth mothers in Baton Rouge while she was there.
The Smoots were never told much about the adoptive parents assigned to them; they said they were given a copy of the couple's home study and brief profile, without pictures. They spoke to the couple once, by telephone. "The father was the C.E.O. of his company, and their net worth was some ungodly number," Mr. Smoot said. "The whole home study was about money, money, money."
The arrangement unraveled when Mrs. Smoot was found to be carrying twins. Beacon House assured them that both babies would be adopted by the chosen parents, but the Smoots heard through the birth-mother grapevine that, in the past, the agency had separated twins without telling the birth parents.
The Smoots switched agencies and went through with a semi-open adoption, then returned to Tennessee. A month later, Beacon House sued them for breach of a contract that obligated them to pay back expenses if they placed their child through an agency or lawyer other than Beacon House.
The lawsuit, which sought $24,774, was dropped. Beacon House and its director, Anne R. Hughes, who also acts as the agency's lawyer, declined to be interviewed.
As the Smoots explained it, some women they met were drug users who sought a means of support. Some never had any intention of placing their children, Mr. Smoot said, "but there was one girl there who was giving up her sixth baby to Beacon House. There's several who do that. It's like an employer-employee relationship."
"This is something the adopting parents need to know," he continued. He said he and his wife were barely screened, either by Beacon House or by the intermediary named Richard. "They should investigate the birth parents a whole lot more than they do," he said.
One source of referrals to Louisiana, according to lawyers and investigators, was Richard Gitelman, whose facilitation service in Florida was investigated in the 1980's after complaints were made. The Smoots said that the "Richard" they talked to never gave his last name, but several adoption professionals, who asked not to be named, said he has referred birth parents to Beacon House.
Mr. Gitelman is said to be favored by older, moneyed couples who want quick, closed adoptions. Investigators have placed his fees at $50,000 and up; Mr. Pierce at the National Council for Adoption said he had seen a photocopy of a check written to Mr. Gitelman, with endorsement, "in the range of $75,000 to $90,000."
Mr. Gitelman, reached at his office number in Coral Springs, Fla., refused to discuss his fees or even to say whether he is still in business. (His National Adoption Counseling Service was declared inactive by the State of Florida in 1996 for failing to file its annual report with the state.)
Mr. Gitelman has never been convicted of anything, though he was indicted and he agreed to a $7,500 fine and a year's probation in Pennsylvania for interfering with the custody of a minor, a pregnant Pennsylvania teen-ager he briefly moved to Louisiana in 1987.
Fees paid in Louisiana are difficult to track. Adoption proceedings are sealed and courts do not submit records to state regulators. But James Best, a district court judge in West Baton Rouge Parish, where Beacon House is situated, said most infant adoptions he had reviewed were smooth and unremarkable. When asked if he had ever seen a $50,000 fee to a facilitator, Judge Best said, "If I ever did, I'd probably roll out of my chair and say I'm in the wrong business."
But Lucy McGough, a law professor at Louisiana State University and head of the legislature's advisory committee on adoption laws, said a few judges had told her that they had seen $50,000 fees and had not known how to handle them.
"One was infuriated," Ms. McGough said, "because they were reporting high charges and saying, 'So what's it to you, Mac? All the code says is we have to report it, and that's what we're doing.' "
Ms. McGough's committee is drawing up amendments to the adoption laws; in a memo to the committee, Ms. McGough voiced concern over "prime baby adoptions that can bring $75,000 to $100,000."
Meanwhile, she said, none of the parties are complaining: "The adoptive parents are happy as clams."
 
The Market Price
Children Are Children, But Some Cost More
For the old-line agencies in this marketplace, "there are Catch-22's everywhere," said Mr. Pierce of the National Council for Adoption. They are torn between the principle that children should not be discounted by race or disability and the reality that that is how one creates a larger pool of parents. They are torn between the principle that parenthood should not be charged for and the reality that social services are expensive.
The agencies, many of which receive donations or government subsidies, say that parents' fees could not cover their costs. Mr. Wright in California notes that when licensed agencies work with pregnant women, about 80 percent end up keeping their babies. And for most agencies, he said, "the cost of serving the 80 percent can't be paid for by the fees of the other 20 percent."
At the Gladney Center, fees do not come close to covering costs. Thanks to its endowment and its large campus, where about half its birth mothers live, Gladney can offer an array of services: three dormitories, a health clinic, chapel, dining hall, swimming pool and greenhouse, as well as high school and community college courses, vocational training, legal representation and counseling to be available for the rest of the birth mothers' lives.
All of this costs the agency, on average, $32,000 per resident. But Gladney's sliding scale adoption fees only go up to $30,000 and Ms. Smith, the marketing coordinator, said the average placement fee is $20,000.
Many agencies, including Gladney, use sliding scales to accommodate lower-income families. Still, Mr. Pierce said, "the economics of adoption is going to cause you to prefer the people who pay the higher fee."
High fees help subsidize the work necessary to find homes for hard-to-place children, at least in the agencies that undertake the job, he said, adding that, in some states, agencies receive "bounties" to recruit adoptive families for children in foster care or for disabled children who are costly to the state.
"Say you have a kid who's H.I.V.-positive in the hospital costing $1,000 a day," Mr. Pierce said. "To pay someone to find adoptive parents is entirely reasonable, but what does that look like to the public?"
It may also look terrible to charge less to place minority or special-needs children, but many agencies say they have little choice.
Gladney, for one, has a lower-cost program for African-American and biracial children. "Unfortunately, we had to create a separate program because adoptive parents were simply not coming forward," Ms. Smith said. Under that program, the agency charges $8,000.
Whoever handles them, adoptions in the over-$50,000 range almost always involve American-born white infants. While most are independent placements handled by lawyers, a few agencies market themselves by at least hinting at results. Easter House, a Chicago agency, notes in a letter to prospective parents that those approved this year have waited an average of 34 days to be offered a baby. The agency charges $45,000, "plus some incidentals."
But high-priced agencies, whether blue-ribbon or gray-market, have no shortage of customers. "I hate to say this, because it's going to sound crass," said Debra Harder, network director for Adoptive Families of America, a Minneapolis-based support organization. "But there are people who have the basic philosophy that the more I pay for something, the better it will be, not just in terms of the product but in terms of appearances. It says a lot about me if I drive a Lexus."
 
The Imports
Abroad, an Abundant Supply for Adoption
In international adoption, the scramble is entirely different: it is for parents. The Adoptive Families of America's current "Guide to Adoption" contains ads for 35 agencies, 33 of which advertise foreign programs.
"Your child is waiting for you," the headline on one announces. "We go with you to China!" Another says, "When you wish upon our stars, dreams do come true."
Most of the long-established agencies involved in international adoptions have "an altruistic, mission-driven sense that every child deserves a family," Ms. Harder said. "Now, with additional programs opening up in Russia and China in particular, folks are seeing it as an entrepreneurial venture."
Adoption experts say international adoptions have generated many new businesses, from charitable, church-affiliated agencies to walkup offices run by people who make money change hands in Bulgaria. Fees to foreign expediters, translators, lawyers and orphanages are usually beyond control of the U.S. agencies that make the placements.
Still, many prospective parents, not wanting the uncertainty of dealing with birth mothers, never even consider domestic adoption seriously. Adoptions from foreign countries are expected to approach 15,000 this year.
Even so, the supply in foreign countries now exceeds the demand here. Susan Soon-Keum Cox, director of public policy at Holt International Children's Services in Eugene, Ore., said the increase came largely from Eastern Europe and China. Russia, which had no program five years ago, placed more children last year than any other country, Ms. Cox said.
"As recently as five or ten years ago, there were many more parents waiting to adopt than there were children," said Ms. Cox, whose agency has placed more than 100,000 children. "Now that's entirely turned around. We're searching for families."
Barbara Irvin, state director of Family Adoption Consultants in Macedonia, Ohio, is uneasy about having more children than families waiting for placement. "There are some real tensions now between the child focus and the consumer orientation, the human services model and the market forces," she said. "Some families start looking for the cheapest, the fastest, the 'we promise you a child that meets your quote-unquote specifications in so many months.' Some of us who have been in the field for 20 years get worried about this shift."
 
In Search of a Child

A tangle of state laws has made adoption all but impossible to navigate without professional help. Disparate provisions govern, among other things, lawyers' roles, residency requirements and birth mothers' consent. Many state statutes do not directly address those issues; some leave them open to varying interpretations. Here is a sampling of state laws:

California
Advertising by lawyers for birth mothers: Permitted
Payment of living expenses by adoptive parents: Permitted
Independent adoption by nonresidents: Not Permitted
When birth mother may sign consent: Upon her discharge from hospital
Time allowed to withdraw consent: 90 days in independent adoption; with agencies, usually irrevocable
 
Connecticut
Advertising by lawyers for birth mothers: Not Permitted
Payment of living expenses by adoptive parents: Up to $1,500
Independent adoption by nonresidents: Independent adoptions not permitted
When birth mother may sign consent: 48 hours after birth
Time allowed to withdraw consent: Until court hearing, about one month after birth
 
Florida
Advertising by lawyers for birth mothers: Permitted
Payment of living expenses by adoptive parents: Permitted
Independent adoption by nonresidents: Six months of residency
When birth mother may sign consent: Any time after birth
Time allowed to withdraw consent: Irrevocable
 
Louisiana
Advertising by lawyers for birth mothers: Permitted
Payment of living expenses by adoptive parents: Permitted
Independent adoption by nonresidents: If consent is signed in state
When birth mother may sign consent: 5 days after birth
Time allowed to withdraw consent: Irrevocable
 
New Jersey
Advertising by lawyers for birth mothers: Not Permitted
Payment of living expenses by adoptive parents: Permitted
Independent adoption by nonresidents: If child is born in state
When birth mother may sign consent: 72 hours after birth
Time allowed to withdraw consent: Irrevocable
 
New York
Advertising by lawyers for birth mothers: Not Permitted
Payment of living expenses by adoptive parents: Permitted
Independent adoption by nonresidents: If child or birth parent is resident
When birth mother may sign consent: Any time after birth
Time allowed to withdraw consent: Irrevocable if witnessed by judge; 45 days by petition to court
 
Texas
Advertising by lawyers for birth mothers: Not Permitted
Payment of living expenses by adoptive parents: Not in independent adoption; an agency may pay limited expenses
Independent adoption by nonresidents: If child isbornor residesin state
When birth mother may sign consent: 48 hours after birth
Time allowed to withdraw consent: Irrevocable

HEADLINE: 1998 NEW YORK MARATHON;
Around the World in 26.2 Miles: The International Brigade

BYLINE: By RON DICKER 

 BODY:
When the New York City Marathon sprouted from a modest event sequestered in Central Park to a celebration coursing through the streets, the word got out to the world.
And the world has kept coming. About 10,000 runners, roughly a third of Sunday's field, will be foreign visitors, with various reasons for traveling such a long way to run such a long distance. 
 Jose Canales, a 35-year-old civil engineer from the Dominican Republic, is hoping to break three hours. He has friends from the Santo Domingo Running Club to push him. "It is tough and it is world-famous," he said of the race. "Also, of course, I like New York City."
Jorg Grunhagen, a 29-year-old unemployed printer from Celle, Germany, also has breaking three hours in mind, with a grueling twist: He is attempting to finish his 10th marathon of the year in that time. He has missed his goal several times; the heat and humidity of a marathon in Siberia forced him to stop, and he missed his limit by 53 seconds in Stockholm. "My parents think I'm a nut, a big nut," he said.
Alfredo Aran of Madrid ran with his wife in the marathon two years ago, clocking 4 hours 53 minutes. "This marathon I run alone and hopefully more quickly," said Aran, a 38-year-old insurance executive who has a personal best of 3:22 and hopes to finish in 3:15.
Sue Hanscombe, 22, a recent graduate of Swansea University in Swansea, Wales, is running to raise money for diabetes. Hanscombe, who discovered she was diabetic five years ago, had been a competitive swimmer. "I just wanted something else, and I found that running didn't take so much time," she said. "With my finals and everything, I could just go out for a run." RON DICKER

HEADLINE: Make Way for Moose;
As Their Predators Decline and Forests Grow, Herds Head South

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, Me.

 BODY:
Wolves in the wild are mostly phantoms that shy away from humans as if they were poison. Pronghorn antelopes are so nervous that if one looks at them the wrong way they are off like a shot. And short of tracking down a mountain lion with dogs, it is all but impossible to see one.
But a moose will often just stand there and let people look at it. 
 Not long ago, for instance, three people set out by canoe onto a small pond northeast of here. As paddles bit into the water's dead-calm surface, rings rippled across a mirror image of the reds, russets, oranges and yellows spangling the autumn mountains. In the middle of this panorama, up to his hocks in water, stood a creature that Ed Mathieu, a northwoods guide in the canoe's stern, has nicknamed the Goat Moose.
There are moose and then there are moose. Some stand tall and magnificent, proudly showing off six-foot-wide racks of antlers. Others are like the scrawny specimen that wandered through the streets of a small Alaskan town every week in the television show "Northern Exposure." This one, too young to sport full antlers, displayed only two small, curved spikes that together with his characteristic moose "beard," or bell, made him look, somewhat foolishly, like a big, stocky goat.
Far from spooking when the canoe approached to within about 25 feet, this moose regarded his visitors placidly. "Oh, O.K.," he seemed to say, "you're not wolves." Then he resumed chomping vegetation from the pond bottom, as weeds streamed from his adolescent antlers and water poured off his head, neck and sad-sack face.
Moose and people in North America have become bound together in a new ecological dynamic, a relationship unknown since both species migrated to the continent from Siberia some time in the last ice age, which ended about 10,000 years ago.
At the turn of this century, moose had been all but wiped out in much of their range by hunting and by conversion of their forest habitat to farms. Now hunting is tightly controlled and many of the farms have reverted to forest.
Natural predators like wolves have been eliminated from much of the north woods. And perhaps most important, especially hereabouts, industrial-scale logging has converted great stretches of the woods to young second-growth forest, whose abundance of tender leaves and twigs at just the right height for a moose to eat has created a vast smorgasbord. Almost within sight of the Goat Moose, for instance, recovering cookie-cutter clear-cuts had set a bounteous table.
The result has been a population explosion among moose. Today probably a million of the big hoofed animals inhabit the northern tier of North America, roughly triple the population at the end of World War II. In the northeastern United States, the population has radiated out from its epicenter in northern Maine, where moose numbers have risen to an estimated 30,000 from about 2,000 a century ago, into central and southern New England. A lone bull has even been sighted near the Delaware Water Gap in Eastern Pennsylvania. Earlier this year, a moose was struck and killed by a vehicle on Interstate 95 near New Haven.
In fact, accidents involving cars and moose have become common in areas, like Maine, where lots of people live in and around the woods. The accidents are frequently catastrophic, more so than in a typical deer-car encounter. Because a moose is so tall and heavy, its body can easily crush a car when the legs are knocked from under it.
On the other hand, moose have become a major tourist attraction and economic asset. Like the Goat Moose, many moose are "incredibly cooperative about letting people watch them," said Karen Morris, a wildlife biologist for the state of Maine. Moose "safaris" have become highly popular in Maine, and Mr. Mathieu this year has guided more than a hundred parties of people eager to see this majestic yet ungainly creature.
"How could you not love an animal that looks like a moose?" said Dr. Charles C. Schwartz, a wildlife biologist who until recently studied moose in Alaska. Now director of the grizzly bear program at Yellowstone National Park, he is an editor of "Ecology and Management of the North American Moose," published last year by Smithsonian Institution Press.
The look of the moose derives from its evolutionary adaptation to its environment -- the cold boreal forests of the Northern Hemisphere.
Its long legs enable it to fairly glide through the woods, stepping easily over downed trees while predators pursuing it must leap or go around.
Its long, bulbous nose, lined on the inside with a wealth of small blood vessels, is designed to warm sub-freezing air so that it will not damage the lungs.
Its coat is one of nature's most superb insulators. It has two layers: one a sort of underwool, the other made up of very long, hollow guard hairs. Like a thermal pane in a window, the hollow hairs block out cold air and conserve body heat. They also help the animal swim (it can do so at a clip of about 5 miles an hour and over distances of up to 9 miles).
Moose take to the water largely because they cannot stand heat (but also because aquatic vegetation is rich in minerals they require). Winter temperatures of 40 degrees below zero Fahrenheit seem to suit them just fine. Even in their lighter summer coats, though, they cannot abide temperatures above about 60 degrees. In their heavy winter coats they become heat-stressed, panting with discomfort, when the thermometer rises above about 23 degrees, and seek the shade of evergreens.
What a moose does for most of its life is eat -- a lot. A thousand-pound adult consumes 25 pounds or even 50 pounds of vegetation a day in the summer and 10 or 12 pounds of evergreen branches or twigs in the winter. (Moose are partial to Christmas trees, i.e., balsam fir.) One year, Dr. Schwartz said, it took a crew of 10 people all summer to collect enough vegetation to feed four moose for two weeks in a research project on moose digestion.
In its constant search for food and security from predators, a moose is served by only so-so eyesight. But its senses of smell and hearing are acute. Its long ears move in an almost 360-degree arc, helping the animal detect sounds far off. Moose "are capable of hearing sounds humans would be oblivious to," Dr. Schwartz said. He has seen them perk up their ears and turn in a common direction, he said, while he has heard nothing. "Five minutes later, a vehicle comes driving in."
Yet moose do not always flee at the approach of danger. One reason, experts say, is that -- at up to six feet at the shoulder and 1,500 pounds -- they are just bigger than most other objects in their world. They have few natural enemies, and even against predators like wolves they frequently stand their ground; moving might prompt the predator to attack, and in any case moose are formidable fighters. Unfortunately, they also sometimes stand their ground against oncoming cars.
In general, moose are considered the most docile of the deer family, and the most tolerant of people's presence. But there are exceptions. Douglas Kane, the state's regional biologist here, says, for instance, that mature bull moose hereabouts have become more skittish and harder to see. "When they smell a human, they're gone," he said. It may be, he speculates, that bulls are shyer because they are the primary quarry in Maine's short, one-week moose hunting season in October.
Moreover, any given moose can be dangerous, and all should be approached cautiously and in some cases not at all, experts say. Two situations are especially perilous: When a human comes between a cow and its calf, during the rut, or mating season, from about mid-September to mid-October. That is when bulls establish dominance, with intimidating displays and sometimes clashes of antlers, and cows signal with moans and wails that they are in the mood, a condition that normally lasts less than a day.
Anything or anyone invading a moose's turf then risks injury or even death. More people are killed by moose, in fact, than by grizzly bears, said Dr. Joel Berger, a biologist at the University of Nevada at Reno.
Otherwise, though, moose have become so comfortable with people that, like deer, they have started raiding gardens and crops. "A few of them in northern Maine are beginning to understand the concept of broccoli," Ms. Morris said.
When a moose calf is a year old, its mother drives it away (to make way for the next year's calf) and it must find a new territory of its own. Moose are now so numerous in northern New England that the youngsters are being forced southward.
Two years ago, a young moose cow apparently got lost while searching out new territory and wound up in Boston. She led police and state biologists on a frantic chase, at one point crashing through the yards of row houses near Boston College. "You could hear the chain-link fences going down," said Dr. John McDonald, a wildlife biologist for the state. Eventually the moose was tranquilized and taken to a zoo, where she died; although moose have sometimes been used as draft animals, they generally do not do well in captivity.
With a breeding population estimated at 200, moose are no longer a novelty in Massachusetts. "As they become more common," Dr. McDonald said, "people report them less frequently. Once you've seen your third or fourth moose, it's not a big deal any more."
In northern New England, and especially in Maine, moose-car accidents have become epidemic. Besides being unintimidated by vehicles, some moose are drawn to roads because they love to lick up the salt left over from deposits made by snow-clearance crews. Sometimes they lie down in the roadway to do this, presenting an unexpected traffic hazard. Another problem is that moose are dark, sometimes almost black, and they are so tall that their eyes do not shine in car lights. So at night, motorists often do not see them until it is too late.
Ms. Morris, the state biologist, said Maine averages more than 600 moose-car accidents a year. About 15 percent of the motorists involved require medical treatment. And while Ms. Morris could not cite human death statistics for Maine, she said the state's mortality rate in moose-car accidents was probably about the same as the rate measured in Sweden: about 1 in 400 accidents.
The moose dies much more often.
Some wildlife specialists in Maine favor loosening restrictions on hunting to reduce the numbers of both moose and accidents. Permits for the one-week October hunt are rationed; this year's cap was 2,000. But other interests, mainly the tourist industry, want to keep the number of moose high.
New logging practices that rely less on clear-cutting and more on selective removal of trees may well shrink the area of prime moose habitat in future years, and as today's second-growth forests grow out of the reach of moose their population may decline, Mr. Kane said. "It may be close to a stable herd now," he said, "stable or low growth."
But for the foreseeable future, the evolving new relationship between people and moose seems likely to continue.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Movado Group hires an outside agency to reset the luxury face of its Concord watch.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A LEADING maker, distributor and retailer of watches is naming an outside agency to handle one of its top brands.
Movado Group Inc., which sells watches under such names as Movado, ESQ, Corum, Piaget and Coach, has selected Arnell Group Brand Consulting in New York as the agency for its Concord line of luxury watches. Since 1972, that brand had been handled primarily by an in-house creative team. 
 The Swiss-made Concord watches, priced at $2,000 to $15,000 each, compete against the likes of Baume & Mercier, Cartier and Rolex. Arnell Group will advise Movado Group on tasks that include establishing a position for the Concord brand in the luxury watch market; developing advertising, with billings estimated at $8 million; creating a logo and devising packaging.
Arnell Group is known for campaigns for such fashion brands as Tommy Hilfiger and Donna Karan as well as imparting more stylish images to such products as Casio G-Shock watches, Hanes hosiery, Ray-Ban sunglasses and Samsung appliances. The choice of Arnell Group as the Concord agency, to be formally announced today, is an example of how marketers of premium-priced products are stepping up efforts to peddle their wares to consumers.
"There's an opportunity in the luxury segment and the watch category in general," said Scott Woodward, senior vice president for global marketing and chief marketing officer at Movado Group in Lyndhurst, N.J., "a huge opportunity to expand what we were doing with Concord." Mr. Woodward, who also has an office in New York, joined the company in early September after working for a year at Calvin Klein Inc. as vice president for marketing.
When asked whether the recent gyrations of the global equity markets would adversely affect the demand for higher-priced watches, Mr. Woodward replied: "In the luxury category, you do have to look at what's going on externally, such as the shift from the flashy 80's to the conservative 90's. We want to explore what a timepiece means to, and does for, an individual both rationally and emotionally."
"Watch advertising is pretty much standard across the board, very product focused and very rational," Mr. Woodward said. "We're looking at something above and beyond traditional advertising, an integrated marketing program that is more emotional."
Peter Arnell, chairman at Arnell Group, said he thought that concerns about the direction of the economy might even stimulate demand for jewelry and other luxury products that many consumers consider long-term investments. His agency has gained experience in the luxury market by working on such pricey brands as Bergdorf Goodman, Chanel, Christian Dior, Christian Lacroix and Loewe.
"The real opportunity is to bring a new cachet, a new emotion to a category where there hasn't been very much," said Mr. Arnell, who described himself as "an avid watch collector for the last 10 years."
Most watch pitches, he added, take predictable approaches like "up-close still life, sports and dancers flying in the air to symbolize performance and movement."
"There's a chance to get people to look at watches differently," Mr. Arnell said, "as I've done with Samsung, the boy with the chest." His reference was to the Arnell Group's print and outdoor campaign for Samsung appliances, which features the striking image of a fit, bare-chested young man toting a microwave oven under his muscular arm.
Mr. Woodward said: "For Samsung, Peter took what was traditionally a very dry category and did something interesting. And he knows how to integrate a message across every level in a creative way. You walk into Kmart to buy a Samsung microwave and the ad is on the box."
Arnell Group was chosen for Concord after a review conducted by AAR North America in New York.
"AAR identified a host of agencies, large and small," Mr. Woodward said. "We looked closely at 10 of them and came to the conclusion that Arnell Group was the appropriate selection." He declined to identify the contenders, saying Movado had met only with Arnell Group and none of the other agencies.
Mr. Woodward and Mr. Arnell have worked together before, when Mr. Woodward was a top advertising executive at Ray-Ban, a unit of Bausch & Lomb. Did that preordain the selection of Arnell Group?
"It wasn't exclusively his decision by any means," said Dana Glazer Gers, vice president at Movado Group, referring to Mr. Woodward. "It was a senior management decision." The first Concord campaign from Arnell Group is due next spring.
Movado Group reported net sales for the fiscal year that ended last Jan. 31 at a record $237 million, up 10.2 percent from $215.1 million in the previous fiscal year. The company's annual report described the Concord brand, along with Movado, as "standout performers" that "generated strong sales growth in both our North American and international markets."
Concord will be one of only two Movado Group watch brands handled by an outside agency. The other is Coach, which was introduced in April under an agreement with the Coach leather goods company owned by the Sara Lee Corporation. Those ads are created by Toth Brand Imaging in New York and Concord, Mass.
That's right, the Coach agency is in Concord but not vice versa.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Big Spending Can Make Fiscal Sense

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
THE headline writer's job is to capture the essence of the story, and such was the case for the author of yesterday's Mets press release. "Mets sign Mike Piazza to a record seven-year $91 million contract," the enlarged, bold print announced, with organizational pride and unrestrained glee.
The Mets, in fact, broke from team policy to shout, look at us, we're big spenders. "We've never done that," admitted Steve Phillips, the general manager. "But everyone seemed to know the figure already, and it also showed a commitment to winning and a willingness to invest. That image hasn't been there in a while." 
 When you add negotiated amenities such as the mandatory hotel suite and use of a Shea Stadium luxury box to the $91 million in bonuses and salary, what Piazza is getting, roughly, is a $100 million value pack. And, as the Mets chirped in the first paragraph of their press release, "the most lucrative player-contract in the history of major-league baseball."
This is what happens when the system works in a way that is more prudent than panicked -- sports economics as it oughta be -- and a 30-year-old future Hall of Famer cashes in on production, not potential. Are you locked-out pro basketball rank-and-filers paying attention? The Mets drew up the paperwork, didn't blink, and no one booed. No one responded to the magnitude of the deal by questioning Piazza's worth or by forecasting financial Armageddon. Able to quantify what Piazza meant to them at the gate and in the standing, the Mets locked up their franchise-defining player for the coming years when they will be competing with Mayor Steinbrenner's team for civic bragging rights and taxpayer dollars to build new ball parks.
Yes, Phillips indicated, those ticket price increases are undoubtedly coming but the telephones in the office, he said, were "ringing off the hook." In other words, the overnight consensus is that Piazza is worth every penny the Mets and their fans will have to pay.
A year ago at this time, the radio talk lines were filled with demands for the Mets to produce someone, anyone, to improve the profile of what Phillips called "good little players on a good little team." Phillips would never admit to this but he probably had one good at-bat to win himself an extended term running the Mets. Fair or not, mistakes in excess of $10 million a year are not easily explained to one's boss. Had Phillips succumbed to last year's public pressure and sold Nelson Doubleday and Fred Wilpon on say, Gary Sheffield, the Mets would be spent as playoff contenders, stumbling on in the forgettable tradition of George Foster and Bobby Bonilla.
"People say the toughest thing to do is pull the trigger," Phillips said. "But the toughest thing is to walk away when people are clamoring for you to do it."
In the Piazza deal last summer, the Mets surrendered prospects, no phenoms, but ran the risk of a public relations fiasco. When Piazza was greeted by the fans like the unproductive stranger he was, there was too much concern of how the rude reception would play on his long-term decision, not enough attention given to Piazza having to prove he could thrive in a city where some very talented players have not dealt with the money and the accompanying pressure to perform.
"I saw the growing pains," Phillips said. By the end of the season, Piazza was the hottest hitter in baseball, Howard Stern knew his phone number and Piazza went home to California to realize he missed the tumult and the tabloids. "I knew," he said, "the page had turned."
It was apparent yesterday that neither party had jumped into this seven-year marriage. The Mets' long-awaited splash was not into an ocean with scary undertow. Instead of water wings, they are wearing Piazza's record and, Phillips said, Piazza has even "guaranteed that he wouldn't get hurt."
Everyone laughed, including Doubleday and Wilpon. If only sports owners could take out performance insurance. David Stern says this dirty little basketball war is over "cost certainty" for owners. What he really needs -- and what I suspect he will end up with -- is some system that prevents inflationary contracts for players who have done little, or nothing. When the veteran star and a proven commodity makes out, critics and fans do not start pondering his relative contribution to the betterment of mankind. Owners do not feel as if they have held up at gunpoint.
They happily consider it what Phillips called this Piazza deal, "a smart investment." A $91 million-plus badge of honor.

HEADLINE: Net Income Declines 58% At Carbide

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Union Carbide Corporation reported today that earnings plunged 58 percent in the third quarter mainly because of weak Asian markets. The company warned that its troubles would continue in the fourth quarter.
The chemical maker earned $76 million in the quarter, or 55 cents a diluted share, compared with $181 million, or $1.18 a share, in the period a year ago. Revenue fell nearly 20 percent, to $1.35 billion from $1.66 billion. 
 The earnings fell short of Wall Street estimates, which had already been diminished by a warning from Union Carbide that lower prices for its products would hurt third-quarter results.
Shares of Union Carbide fell 62.5 cents today, to $39.1875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company's earnings were affected by about $24 million of additional costs related to delays at a factory in Taft, La., that is undergoing expansion. The figures also reflect a $6 million charge related to disruption of the company's joint venture in Kuwait caused by transformer breakdowns at the Government-owned electric utility.
Union Carbide's chairman, William H. Joyce, blamed the economic turmoil in Japan and other Asian nations for the earnings decline. Continued weak demand in Asia and related cuts in selling prices, slightly higher raw materials costs and normal seasonal weaknesses in several businesses all point to lower fourth-quarter earnings, Mr. Joyce said.

HEADLINE: Death Rate on U.S. Roads Reported at a Record Low

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The death rate on the nation's roads fell to a record low last year, the Government said today after re-calculating travel statistics. The total number of deaths changed hardly at all, but the death rate fell because of the relentless increase in traffic.
But transportation experts said the traffic-death rate for the elderly was rising rapidly. A person older than 74 is more than twice as likely to die in a motor vehicle crash than a younger person, according to the National Safety Council, a nonprofit group sponsored mostly by the insurance industry. 
 For most people, though, the risk of death or serious injury is falling.
"There's a downward trend in all the categories," said Charles A. Hurley, a spokesman for the safety council. "Fatal injuries become nonfatal, serious injuries become nonserious."
Mr. Hurley said that accident rates usually rose during periods of economic expansion because prosperity stimulated more driving but that the death rate per 100,000 people had been falling for the last three years because other factors were moving faster: an increase in seat belt use, a decline in drunken driving and an improvement in cars.
Dr. Ricardo Martinez, the administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said the improvement came despite an increase in elderly drivers, who are more likely to be frail and to have trouble coping with traffic, and in teen-age drivers, who have high accident rates.
Dr. Martinez's agency, part of the Department of Transportation, said there were 1.6 deaths per 100 million miles traveled, based on a higher estimate of total miles driven in 1997 than the agency had used this summer, when it said the death rate had not changed. The rate was 1.7 deaths per 100 million miles traveled the year before. The 1997 figure is the lowest since the agency began keeping records 30 years ago. And the National Safety Council said today that 16.1 traffic fatalities per 100,000 people was also at a historic low, tying a record set in 1991.
Even so, 41,967 people were killed by motor vehicles last year, including 5,700 pedestrians and 700 bicycle riders. An additional 3.4 million people were injured in 2.2 million crashes. There were no injuries in 4.6 million crashes reported to police.
The decline in deaths comes despite the loosening of the 55-mile-per-hour national speed limit 11 years ago, and its elimination in 1995.
Traffic congestion and total miles driven have gone up too, but that helps. Mr. Hurley said, "Congestion has a positive effect on highway safety, because it drives speeds down."
He said, though, that there would be more highway repair in the next few years, leading to new safety problems.
According to the safety council, the number of motor-vehicle deaths per 100,000 people is declining for all age groups except the elderly. The death rate for the elderly last year, measured against miles traveled, was just over double the rate for the population as a whole, 32.7 per 100,000 population vs. 16.1 for all age groups. The rate for people 75 and older is the highest since 1973.
Dr. Martinez said elderly people were more mobile than they used to be but were much more fragile than other drivers.
"A side impact, with forces straight to pelvis and chest, can be devastating," said Dr. Martinez, a former emergency room physician. "In a younger person wearing restraints in a serious crash, they may have some broken ribs, but with an elderly person, the chest being much more delicate, those same rib fractures can lead to problems with lungs, and eventually, a fatality."
Rodney E. Slater, the Transportation Secretary, said in a telephone interview that his department was looking into a number of remedies, including signs that are easier for older people to see.
Asked whether states should be encouraged to retest older drivers, Mr. Slater said, "There is probably the need for all of us to have refresher courses in some way."
"If that occurs, I think it would be much better to do it across the board rather than to single out older drivers," he said.
Mr. Slater added that the budget Congress passed last week had a 10 percent increase for highway safety programs.
Dr. Martinez said that the issue of screening older drivers to test their road competence was extremely sensitive but that safety officials should frame the question differently.
"Screening for fit-to-drive is no different from screening for cancers or heart disease," he said. "We have to make sure it's safe."

HEADLINE: Back Peace, U.S. Urges Arab Allies

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: ASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Now that the Wye conference has broken the deadlock between the Israelis and the Palestinians after 19 months, the Clinton Administration is urging moderate Arab nations to recommit themselves to actively aiding the peace effort.
In particular, Administration officials are saying that moderate Arab states like Egypt, Morocco, Tunisia, Qatar and Saudi Arabia should move quickly to support the Palestinian Authority. They suggest building projects and job creation, as well as new efforts to bring Israel into the region and involvement in groups looking into regional problems like the water supply. 
 Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat signed a deal on Friday that would return another 13 percent of the West Bank to at least partial Palestinian control in exchange for specific Palestinian steps to fight terrorism.
James P. Rubin, spokesman for Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, said today, "Secretary Albright does believe that with the Middle East peace process now invigorated, Arab states should do more to normalize relations with Israel, assist the Palestinians economically where possible and participate in the multilateral tracks of the peace process."
The United States is annoyed that Arab leaders are now reluctant to fully endorse the deal squeezed out of the parties in nine long days at Wye. The annoyance is particularly acute given that Arab countries earlier criticized Washington for not pressing Mr. Netanyahu enough, and dropped out of regional economic initiatives like a conference last year in Doha, Qatar.
"They want to wait and see if the deal is implemented," a senior Administration official said.
Official reaction from these nations has been cautious, and the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, has repeated the wait-and-see stance directly to Ms. Albright, officials said. There was a similar response today when the Assistant Secretary of State for Near East Affairs, Martin Indyk, met with some 20 Arab envoys, officials said.
Referring to Arab states, one official said, "Prime Minister Netanyahu made some hard decisions in the last week, and they have to stop blaming him and start thinking about what their responsibilities are."
Both ordinary Palestinians and ordinary Israelis need to see the benefits of peace, the official emphasized, and that means jobs in the first case and normalization and security in the second.
Ms. Albright has also been concerned about the deterioration of American influence on moderate Arab states stemming from their anger over the peace stalemate. Specifically, the United States has had a hard time getting these states to support its policies toward Iran and Iraq. Now that Washington has unblocked the peace process, officials say, it is time for a bit of payback.
Also today, officials from the Central Intelligence Agency, including the station chief in Israel, briefed the House and Senate intelligence committees on the role the C.I.A. will play under the accord. Some lawmakers had expressed alarm at reports coming out of the Wye negotiations on C.I.A. involvement.
Under the pact, the C.I.A.'s tasks will include refereeing disputes on the handling of terrorist suspects, and monitoring those arrested by Israeli and Palestinian authorities.
In a series of closed briefings before the House and Senate panels, C.I.A. officials played down any new responsibilities, and emphasized that the agreement outlines a continuation of peacekeeping duties performed by the agency over the last three years.
 In an Op-Ed page article in Tuesday's New York Times, the Director of Central Intelligence, George J. Tenet, writes that the duties of the C.I.A. in Israeli and Palestinian areas have not changed, but have merely been made public.
After the briefings, aides expressed relief. "There was very, very little new here," said one Congressional participant. "What's new is all the publicity surrounding it."

HEADLINE: Home Resales Fell Last Month

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Home resales fell in September for a second straight month, suggesting that low mortgage rates are not enough to overcome an overall slowing of the United States economy.
Resales unexpectedly fell 1.1 percent last month, to an annual rate of 4.68 million, the National Association of Realtors said. Analysts had forecast a rise of four-tenths of a percent, to a 4.75 million rate. Sales fell in the Midwest and the South, were flat in the Northeast and rose in the West. 
 In August, resales fell 3.7 percent, to an annual rate of 4.73 million, down from a record 4.91 million pace in July.
The median price of a home fell 1.2 percent, to $131,300 in September from $132,900 in August.
The real estate statistics, based on closing contracts, are considered an important gauge of growth because sales of previously owned homes account for 85 percent of all homes on the market and home buyers are big consumers of furniture, appliances and other household goods.
Low mortgage rates, along with low unemployment and strong consumer confidence, have provided support for the housing industry. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 6.73 percent last week, close to the 6.49 percent figure for the week ended on Oct. 9, which was the lowest since January 1968.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: RACIAL ISSUES;
Black Loyalty to Clinton Hinders G.O.P. Outreach

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 24

 BODY:
At this point in her race for the House two years ago, polls showed Anne Northup with the support of about 8 percent of her district's African-American vote. And though she squeaked out a victory, Ms. Northup, a Republican, fared so poorly in Louisville's black neighborhoods that in one precinct she received only 5 out of 600 votes.
"In cases like that you figure that five people must have voted for me by mistake," she says now with a rueful laugh. "It was devastating." 
 Despite the poor showing among black voters, Ms. Northup, who is white and has adopted two black children, worked to build bridges to the city's black residents. She formed a close association with two of the city's most powerful black ministers and directed nearly $3 million in Federal money to self-help projects they operated.
Her work seemed to be paying off. Recent polls show that her support among blacks who are considered likely to vote in this year's election has grown to 20 percent.
But having voted with the rest of the House Republicans to authorize an open-ended impeachment investigation of President Clinton, Ms. Northup is one of several lawmakers identified as targets of a new Democratic get-out-the-vote campaign in black areas.
She is facing the prospect that her efforts to woo black voters may be short-circuited by the continuing Washington inquiry and strong black support for the President.
"I've heard many people say that they like Anne Northup," said the Rev. Kevin Cosby, pastor of St. Stephen Baptist Church, the largest black church in the state, and an unabashed fan of Ms. Northup. "They're only concerned about the President and how she would vote with regards to the impeachment of the President."
Ms. Northup's problem is but one example of what Democratic strategists are hoping will be the pivotal role played by black voters in this year's election. The Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a nonpartisan research organization, has identified 9 Senate races -- in Arkansas, California, Georgia, Illinois, Kentucky, New York, North Carolina, Ohio and South Carolina -- and 19 House contests where the black vote could be crucial.
Democratic strategists are hoping that the anger expressed by blacks toward Republicans that has been showing up in sizable numbers in public opinion surveys will translate into strong turnout at the polls. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has pinpointed at least 10 close House races with large numbers of black voters for special get-out-the-vote efforts.
On Thursday, the Congressional Black Caucus will begin a five-city bus tour to encourage blacks to go to the polls on Nov. 3. The first stop will be in this city along the Ohio River to urge blacks to come to vote for Chris Gorman, the former Kentucky Attorney General who is in a tight race with Ms. Northup.
"We intend to energize the black vote, which generally is just as low, if not lower, than others in an off-year election," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, a New York Democrat who organized the bus tour. "There is no question that the African-American community strongly supports the President and strongly opposes anything that could be perceived as an effort to drive him out of office."
Kentucky's Third Congressional district, which encompasses Louisville and parts of its suburbs, is a classic swing district. It has shifted from Republican to Democrat to Republican in the last three elections. In 1996, Ms. Northup won by barely 1,299 votes, less than 1 percent of the nearly 251,000 cast. Mr. Clinton carried the district overwhelmingly.
With blacks making up 16.3 percent of its population that has reached voting age, strategists hope that a significant turnout will lead to an upset victory for Mr. Gorman.
Unlike other Democratic candidates in Kentucky, Mr. Gorman is not shy about trumpeting his support for Mr. Clinton and castigating the Republicans for the impeachment investigation. This week he will start broadcasting a commercial on black radio stations in which the Rev. Jesse Jackson criticizes Ms. Northup on several issues, including her vote in favor of the inquiry.
"They support President Clinton and they support candidates like myself who have indicated that while what the President did was wrong and he should be punished, he should not be impeached," Mr. Gorman said of black voters. "I've read the Starr report and there is nothing impeachable in there. So he needs to be punished very quickly, and we need to move on with it and talk about other issues. I can guarantee you that's the feeling of well over 95 percent of the black community in this area."
For her part, Ms. Northup has tried to walk a fine line on the impeachment matter. She voted with the Republican majority for an open-ended inquiry, fearing that if an investigation was limited in scope and time, Mr. Clinton would "run out the clock." But she has not, in her words, "gotten out and railed against" the President on the campaign trail.
"To be honest, when it comes to the impeachment question, that's one area where I feel a tremendous responsibility to at least understand how they feel about it and be very sensitive to it," Ms. Northup said of black voters in her district.
The open question is how much her party's stand on impeachment has undercut her efforts to forge relationships with blacks. Those efforts began shortly after her election when she met first with the Rev. Walter Malone, of New Canaan Baptist Church, and with Mr. Cosby. Both ministers represent a new breed of black clergy and black leadership. They emphasize a self-help philosophy and are not shy to embrace Republican help.
Mr. Cosby, whose church attracted 1,500 people to Bible study last Wednesday evening, said, "African-Americans have a lot of local concerns and Anne Northup has been very accessible to the community."
And while he declines to say that he endorses her re-election, Mr. Cosby makes clear that he would not be dismayed if she is returned to the House. "I heard Jesse Jackson say something I agree with -- good political works result in good political consequences," Mr. Cosby said. "In my opinion, Anne Northup has produced for our community some good political works."

HEADLINE: Panel Studying Iraq Missiles Is of 2 Minds on Nerve Gas

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: NITED NATIONS, Oct. 26

 BODY:
An international panel of arms experts announced today that they had accepted American scientific evidence indicating that Iraq had loaded some of its missiles with a deadly nerve gas known as VX.
But their report, which was given to the Security Council, was inconclusive because it also left unchallenged French and Swiss tests that had far different conclusions. The Swiss, who examined samples of Iraqi weapons in the summer, said they had found no evidence of poison gas. French scientists asserted that their tests of other samples showed only the possibility that poison gas was present in some Iraqi missiles. 
 What the three countries agreed on was that at some point the Iraqis used detergents to wash missile fragments retrieved from Iraqi desert dumps, leading to the suspicion that Baghdad had something to hide.
Because the report is indecisive, it is doubtful that it will determine policy decisions on Iraq, particularly considering the heavily political atmosphere at the United Nations surrounding Iraqi sanctions.
The document highlights the dispute between French and American scientists on the methods and interpretation of the findings. French scientists said they had found what could be traces of VX or two other deadly gases, Sarin and Soman. But they said those traces could also have come from detergents used to clean the missiles.
The United States said its scientists proved beyond any doubt the existence of traces of the VX nerve gas in the first samples, which were examined in May. The United States also conducted a second set of tests later, but they did not find VX. The second tests were ordered after Iraq challenged the first opne, conducted in a military laboratory in Aberdeen, Md.
Iraq charged that the United States -- which led the gulf war to evict Iraqi troops from Kuwait in 1991 -- was biased. That charge led to the tests in France and Switzerland.
The 21 scientists drawn from 7 countries who met here last Thursday and Friday sidestepped the issue of which tests were to be taken into account, asserting in today's report that "all analytical data provided by the three laboratories were again considered as conclusive and valid."
The report was commissioned by the United Nations Special Commission, which is charged with insuring the destruction of Baghdad's weapons.
Iraq has admitted making a variety of chemical and biological weapons, but says it did not fire them during the gulf war and continues to insist that it did not load the odorless VX nerve gas onto missiles. Unscom is interested to know whether Iraq has hidden any missiles that may be loaded with VX, stressing that Iraq has still a great of explaining to do before it can be given a clean bill of health.
One remaining question is why detergents were used at all in the missiles, which were then dismantled and buried by Iraq until they were unearthed by inspectors.
"The existence of VX degradation products conflicts with Iraq's declarations that the unilaterally destroyed special warheads had never been filled with any Chemical Weapons agents," the report said.
Although most members of the organization doubt that Iraq has ever told the truth about its weapons of mass destruction, many here believe that it has gone a long way toward destroying them and that some of the sanctions against Iraq should be lifted or eased in recognition of this effort.
In a vote highlighting opposition to the United States and its frequent use of sanctions against countries like Iraq, Cuba and Libya, the United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution calling for the repeal of unilateral laws affecting the economies and businesses of individual countries.
The resolution is nonbinding, but it echoes a similar vote that called for an end to sanctions against Cuba two weeks ago. Today's appeal was endorsed by 80 nations. Only the United States and Israel voted against it outright.
Some Western diplomats here who spoke on condition of anonymity have suggested that France may have held back on some of its findings in order not to fan the flames for continued sanctions against Iraq, although French officials categorically deny doing so.
Diplomats here said it was not in dispute that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, nor that it lied about this to the world community. Iraq suspended armed inspections by United Nations inspectors in August.

HEADLINE: Earnings Rise 9.5% at American Express

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The American Express Company reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 9.5 percent as strength in its travel and financial advisory operations offset Asia-related weakness in its banking and traveler's check businesses.
American Express said it had earned $574 million, or $1.25 a diluted share, for the quarter, up from $524 million, or $1.10 a diluted share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. 
 The earnings were a penny higher than analysts' expectations, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks such estimates.
Revenue increased 6.4 percent, to $4.79 billion from $4.50 billion.
Shares of American Express rose 50 cents, to $88.125, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Earnings from travel-related services rose 17 percent, to $362 million. The gains came despite a slowdown in corporate travel spending, American Express said.
Earnings from the company's financial advisory unit climbed 15 percent, to $211 million.
The increased earnings from the company's two major businesses offset a decline in its banking and traveler's check operations, where earnings fell 36 percent, to $43 million, as a result of Asia's economic problems.
