HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: KENTUCKY;
Fierce Opponents Go Down to the Wire

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: PAINTSVILLE, Ky., Oct. 28

 BODY:
Here in the hills of eastern Kentucky, where Loretta Lynn grew up as a coal miner's daughter, the politicians are talking this fall about "a turnout election." You hear the same phrase in Louisville and Paducah, and in Wisconsin, New York and North Carolina -- everywhere there is a close race for state or Federal office.
It is the cliche of the year, like "Year of the Woman" in 1992. "Tell me who's going to show up at the polls next Tuesday," said Representative Jim Bunning, the Republican nominee in this state's nasty, down-to-the-wire Senate contest, "and I'll tell you who's going to win." 
 Predicting the turnout in midterm elections is never easy, but the professionals find it harder than ever this time. The impeachment proceedings against President Clinton provide the added imponderable. Will Democrats stay home, or will they turn out to register their anger against Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, and the Republicans in Congress?
The importance of those questions was vividly illustrated in a poll published in today's Courier-Journal in Louisville. It showed Mr. Bunning trailing his Democratic rival, Representative Scotty Baesler, by a statistically insignificant 44-to-43 margin among registered voters who said they were likely to go to the polls but leading him once the sample was corrected to reflect recent turnout patterns.
Kentucky's Senate race is one of the half-dozen or so close contests that will collectively determine whether the Republicans have the 60 votes they will need in the next two years to cut off debate.
In addition, the House seats Mr. Bunning and Mr. Baesler are giving up are among the most hotly disputed in the nation. Ken Lucas, a Democrat, leads in the race for Mr. Bunning's seat, although Mr. Bunning's name atop the ticket may help the Republican, Gex Williams, to pull through. Ernest Fletcher, a Republican, is favored in the contest for Mr. Baesler's seat, but turnout is a major question in that race, too.
At a get-out-the-vote rally on Tuesday night in Louisville's old Union Station, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat, accused the Republicans of plotting to keep people at home on Election Day.
"They're running a negative campaign," Mr. Biden said, "because the more negative, the more visceral the campaign, the more people turn off, especially women. If only the most motivated voters show up, the Republicans win."
The Republicans, of course, deny an effort to suppress turnout. Indeed, they blame Mr. Baesler for slinging the first mud in a campaign that has more than lived up to this state's tradition of political brawling. But when Mr. Bunning's campaign coordinator, Kyle Simmons, heard the results of the Courier poll, he reacted by saying, "Hope it rains."
Although a Democratic House candidate in the Louisville area has run advertisements criticizing Republicans for authorizing an open-ended investigation of Mr. Clinton, neither Senate candidate has tackled the impeachment issue on television. One top strategist said it was "too hot, too volatile and too unpredictable to touch with a 50-foot pole."
Ron McCloud, the state Democratic chairman, said he thought "the way the Republicans in Washington beat up on Clinton has energized some of my people, got them stirred up to work and vote, which is often a problem for us." Overwhelmingly Democratic in registration, Kentucky regularly elects Republicans to top offices because Democrats break ranks or stay home.
"It's turnout, it's turnout, it's turnout," Mr. McCloud said. "I hope we've learned from 1994. If a few more Democrats in key places had voted, we might have had Dick Gephardt instead of Newt Gingrich as Speaker."
Mark Mellman, a pollster for Mr. Baesler and other Democrats, said he expected a continuation of the steady decline in national turnout this year, "with more than likely an equal decline for both parties."
Curtis Gans, who heads a committee that studies voter participation, said he expected fewer than 4 registered voters in 10 to cast ballots, a new low.
Why? One big reason, Mr. Mellman said, is that "this is not an issue election, not a referendum on Clinton or the economy or anything else."
As befits a border state, Kentucky developed a two-party system earlier than states in the Deep South. John Sherman Cooper and Thruston B. Morton held Senate seats here as early as the 1950's, taking their places alongside Democratic icons like A. B. (Happy) Chandler and Alben W. Barkley, who was Harry S. Truman's Vice President.
Even in the one-party days, the state had a reputation for quarrelsome politics. Fred Vinson, a Kentucky politician who became Chief Justice of the United States, used to tell about asking a local officeholder whom he planned to support in a primary election. "I don't know yet," the officeholder replied, saying he was waiting to see what the opposition did, so he could take the other side.
Mr. Bunning and Mr. Baesler are both fiercely competitive people, with backgrounds in sports. Mr. Bunning, still lean and fit at 67, spent 17 seasons as a right-handed fireballer in the big leagues. He wears a Hall of Fame ring on his left hand. Mr. Baesler was captain in 1962 and 1963 of one of Adolph Rupp's legendary University of Kentucky basketball teams. Given basketball's status in this state as a kind of secular religion, he is even better known than his rival.
Their personalities could hardly be more different. Mr. Baesler is soft-spoken and seemingly reluctant to work a crowd. Mr. Bunning is an in-your-face sort of campaigner.
"We get along well enough," Mr. Baesler said in an interview. "We see each other on the Hill almost every day and we don't growl at each other. But he's always been a little strident. In his playing days, I guess, you knocked the other guy down with a baseball if you didn't like him. In basketball, you can't do that; you have to find a way to work around him."
Early in the campaign, Mr. Bunning ran a commercial showing Mr. Baesler making an uncharacteristically vehement speech, accompanied by Wagner's "Ride of the Valkyries." The Democrats denounced the spot as an effort to suggest subliminally that their man was a Nazi, and newspapers and civic leaders joined them in issuing condemnations.
"Bugs Bunny and Elmer Fudd used that music, and people think it's funny," Mr. Bunning replied.
The two men have spent weeks accusing each other of lying on subjects like Social Security, health care and education, often seizing upon narrow differences and magnifying them. Mr. Baesler for example wanted to save 100 percent of the Federal surplus for Social Security, while Mr. Bunning settled for saving only 90 percent. The 10 percent difference is a big issue.
Mr. Bunning has played down issues he has used in the past like abortion and flag-burning. But his slide toward the center has been uneven. While he was portraying himself this week as the defender of Social Security and Medicare, his campaign brought Oliver L. North, a symbol of the far right, to Paintsville to campaign for him amid the Technicolor hillsides of autumn.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL TO CUT ITS BUSINESS BY 30%

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The United Companies Financial Corporation, a home mortgage and home equity lender that put itself up for sale in July, said yesterday it had failed to find a buyer and would shrink its business by 30 percent to cut costs. The company, based in Baton Rouge, La., said its board approved a plan to dismiss 1,070 employees, or more than 30 percent of its staff, and close all businesses that could not be sold except the unit that lends directly to borrowers. The plan will cost between $4 million and $6 million. The company also reported that third-quarter income from continuing operations fell 3 percent, to $25.8 million, from $26.7 million in the period a year earlier.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Strike Is Authorized By Jersey City Teachers

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
The 2,500 teachers in New Jersey's second largest school district voted yesterday to authorize a strike, the union said.
The 2,500 teachers who are members of the Jersey City Education Association have been working under terms of a contract that expired on Aug. 31, and negotiations have failed to produce agreements on raises, prescription drug co-payments and the lengths of the school day and year, Thomas J. Favia, the union president, said. Mr. Favia said about 1,800 teachers who attended a union meeting yesterday unanimously authorized the strike. 
 Mr. Favia said 25 teachers have resigned since September because of anxiety over job evaluations being conducted throughout the district, which was seized by the state in 1989 because of poor performance among its 33,000 students.
Joanne Kenny, a spokeswoman for the district, said the union is demanding raises of more than 5 percent a year, well ahead of inflation and increases granted in surrounding districts. She said Jersey City teachers without advanced degrees are paid $67,900 after 13 years, $8,000 a year more than their counterparts in Newark, the state's largest district. Ms. Kenny said that substitute teachers, aides and administrators would teach in the event of a strike.

HEADLINE: METRO BUSINESS;
Business Optimism Lags

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Business activity in the New York City region slowed this month and the outlook for the next six months dimmed, a survey of services and manufacturing executives showed.
The New York purchasing managers' index for October fell to 53.8 percent from 58.8 percent in September. In August, the index registered 53.5 percent. An index reading of 50 percent or more suggests the economy is expanding. The figures are adjusted for seasonal variations. 
 "The longer-term growth rate of the local economy has moderated," the report said.
Moreover, the outlook for business activity in the New York region over the next six months was less upbeat with a forward-looking index falling to 53 percent this month -- the lowest reading since the survey was started in May 1993 -- from 59.7 percent in September. An index tracking prices paid by businesses in the New York City area showed inflation is not a problem.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: ILLINOIS;
Governor's Race Lacks Fire, Hurting Democrat

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 28

 BODY:
In the vast megalopolis known here as Chicagoland, which stretches 50 miles from the high-rises along Lake Michigan to suburban cul-de-sacs, it has often been difficult to get voters interested in the political action in the Illinois Statehouse.
The capital, Springfield, in the view of many Chicagoans and suburbanites, is a place to visit Lincoln's tomb or to milk cows at the state fair. 
 The race for governor this year has done little to change that. George Ryan, the Republican, and Glenn Poshard, the Democrat -- men who have never been accused of skating on charisma -- have not managed to fan the political passions.
Lethargy bodes well for Mr. Ryan, the Secretary of State, whose Republican Party has held the governor's office for 22 years. Most surveys of likely voters give Mr. Ryan a double-digit lead, except for an anomalous poll published by The Chicago Sun-Times last week that showed the race nearly a dead heat.
Mr. Poshard, a socially conservative Congressman from Southern Illinois, has often been at odds with liberals in his party. But his problems, at least among residents of Northern Illinois, run much deeper .
"Most people had never heard of him," said Peter Nardulli, the head of the political science department at the University of Illinois.
Mr. Ryan, 64, a former pharmacist from Kankakee, an old railroad town about 45 miles south of Chicago, could walk down most Illinois streets without being widely recognized.
But his name is known everywhere. One of the perquisites of the secretary of state's office, it seems, is the right to have your signature on everything from driver's licenses to mailings on organ donation.
Mr. Ryan has also used his office to call for stricter laws on drunken driving. He takes much of the credit for the state's reducing its blood-alcohol content maximum for drivers to 0.08 percent, from 0.10 percent.
Strategists for Republicans have said they expect the race to tighten. But John Torre, a spokesman for Mr. Ryan, said the voter surveys "reflect the contentment and satisfaction that people in Illinois have with Republican leadership."
Democratic officials note that polls did not predict Mr. Poshard's victory in the primary.
The governor's job has long been regarded as political second banana to that of the mayor of Chicago, at least from the view here, where City Hall looms as the real locus of power.
The city has lost plenty of its influence to the suburbs, which now cast 40 percent of the state's vote. And Mr. Ryan has been able to portray himself as the sort of moderate who plays well in the suburbs, running television advertisements that emphasize his support for gun control.
Democrats, who have been out of the governor's office since 1976, had high hopes this political season. They saw Mr. Ryan, who won the Republican primary without serious opposition, as a much weaker opponent than Gov. Jim Edgar, a popular moderate who is retiring from politics, partly for health reasons.
Mr. Ryan was seen as vulnerable for his opposition to abortion, as well as his crucial role as speaker of the Illinois House in 1976 in defeating the Equal Rights Amendment.
But when Democrats nominated Mr. Poshard, who has a more conservative record on social issues than Mr. Ryan has, the Republican was able to cast himself as the more enlightened candidate. Mr. Ryan, for example, sent representatives of his campaign to appear at the gay pride parade in Chicago, while Mr. Poshard skipped the event.
The campaign of Mr. Poshard, who has said he will not accept money from political action committees, has appeared star-crossed. A scandal tied to Mr. Ryan's state office, involving workers accused of taking bribes has failed to help him.
Scott Lassar, the United States Attorney in Chicago, has said workers in a driver license office took $150,000 in bribes to give trucker licenses. Federal agents also say that some of that money ended up in a campaign fund for Mr. Ryan. The prosecutor has said Mr. Ryan is not a target of the investigation.
Even among blacks, the most loyal part of the Democratic constituency, the view of Mr. Poshard has often been lukewarm. Some hard feelings might remain among blacks who supported Roland Burris, a former state attorney general, who is black, in the Democratic primary.
Mr. Ryan's big lead in the polls, together with the apparent lead of the Republican candidate for the Senate, Peter Fitzgerald, over Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, has caused Democrats to worry that trouble may be in store for Democrats running for the State Legislature.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 30, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Picture captions yesterday with an article about the race for governor in Illinois were reversed in some copies, and the pictures were credited incorrectly. The upper picture showed George Ryan, the Illinois Secretary of State who is the Republican candidate for governor; the lower one showed Glenn Poshard, the Democratic candidate. The pictures were from The Chicago Tribune, not The State-Journal Register in Springfield.

SECTION: Section F;Page 1;Column 2;House & Home/Style Desk

LENGTH: 2105 words

HEADLINE: Muscling In on Martha Stewart

BYLINE: By JAMES RYAN

 BODY:
ARMED with little more than a sheaf of recipes, a glue gun, some dried flowers and a puritanical zeal for modern home-keeping, Martha Stewart has built a multimedia empire worth $200 million, by one conservative estimate. Thus, it comes as no surprise that pretenders are cropping up thicker than sprouts on a Chia Pet.
Haunted by Ms. Stewart's success and eager to promote their own domains, seven gurus of the homely arts gathered last week in New York for a Halloween photo shoot. These arbiters of design and entertaining, cooking and crafts were armed with enough moss, glitter, candles, dry ice, scarecrows and baled straw to raise Mrs. Beeton from the dead, and were escorted by assistants, publicity agents and stylists. Most have already written books and landed half-hour slots in the rapidly expanding souffle of life-style television. But they're just treading water compared to Ms. Stewart, a polar-ice-breaking juggernaut who has churned out 22 books and by January will fill five hours of television programming a week. 
 Why the audience? Home-decorating shows are soothing -- like those devoted to golf or bass fishing. Burton Jablin, the programming chief for the fledgling Home and Garden network (HGTV), said his company had predicted a downturn in morning ratings the day President Clinton's grand jury testimony was shown. Instead, there was an increase. "People want something safe and apart from what's out there," Mr. Jablin said. "We call it 'informational escapism.' "
Caroline Goldstein, the author of "Do It Yourself: Home Improvement in the 20th Century," said shelter advice is, and has always been, about "wanting to be upper middle class."
Then again, some people just don't aspire to Ms. Stewart's "casual country buffet for 40" or $750 German glass tree ornaments. Annabelle Gurwitch, a host of TBS's life-style parody show, "Dinner and a Movie," said Ms. Stewart and her ilk were depressing: "Watching some of those life-style shows is like watching porn. There are some very tantalizing things happening in front of me that I know that I'm never going to do in my lifetime." But for those who have the time, cash and inclination to gild their pumpkins, homemaking is back.
"Domesticity for a long time got a dour, matronly rap," said Katie Brown, 35, the anti-Martha who is the host of Lifetime's "Next Door With Katie Brown." "It was embarrassing to say, 'I baked these.' Women of my generation are embracing nesting again." What does this Gen X'er bring to the table? She uses a shower curtain as a tablecloth.
A healthy economy helped spark the explosion of decorating shows, which range from impressive to infuriating. "There are a lot of wannabes out there," said Chris Casson Madden, 50, the author of two coffee-table books, "Kitchens" and its sequel, "Bathrooms." "There are businessmen thinking, 'Let's create the next one,' like Milli Vanilli. But this isn't as easy as lip-synching a song."
Then again, maybe it is. Ms. Madden has a program called "Interiors by Design" on HGTV whose slim content includes house tours and discussions of barrel chairs and passementerie. Now, she is planning her home-decorating empire. "I'll probably do a fragrance at some point, but it doesn't have to be tomorrow," she said.
The number of imitators grows weekly as HGTV, Lifetime, Discovery, TBS, Romance Classics and E! scramble to fill time slots. Many will be chosen. Few, if any, will succeed. But here are some helpful tips, including a few from Martha Stewart herself, who says, "I'm not usually in the business of giving free consultations to competitors."

 CHOOSE A NICHE -- Barbara Smith, a New York restaurateur and former model, is the host of "B. Smith With Style," a syndicated show. She has emerged as the African-American Martha Stewart. "My show has more rhythm," said Ms. Smith, 49. Her glossy 1995 tome, "B. Smith's Entertaining and Cooking for Friends," features Southern recipes, no-frills party tips and beaming children in red and yellow Kwanzaa outfits.
Then there is Mary Emmerling, 56, the Country Martha Stewart. Ms. Emmerling is the host of an HGTV show called "Country at Home." (Though she glorifies the American West, Ms. Emmerling has lived in Georgetown in Washington, D.C., Bridgehampton and, for 30 years, Manhattan.
Ms. Brown, an actress/waitress turned cool camp-crafts counselor, landed "Next Door With Katie Brown" last year. She's a Sunnier Martha, in the Katie Couric mold, who never stops acting casual, even when sewing fabric butterflies for an indoor picnic or making handmade paper in a blender from boiled newspaper pulp and rose petals.
Colin Cowie, a celebrity party planner, is kind of a Rococo Martha. "I'm on a mission to reinforce and reinstate our social graces," said Mr. Cowie, 36. He is the author of the voyeuristic paperweights "Weddings" and "Effortless Elegance." Not always hands-on, Mr. Cowie believes that effortless elegance is achieved by having a chef assist him during cooking segments of "Everyday Elegance With Colin Cowie" on Romance Classics. If the going gets tough, he's not above plunking a waiter in a cab to fetch Indian takeout.
A glance around the cable spectrum reveals slots open for a Latina Martha, a Sporty Martha and a Rock 'n' Roll Martha.
Martha says: "I never wanted to go after a niche. I want to teach as many people as possible."

 OUT-MARTHA MARTHA -- Ms. Madden and Bari Lynn, the former home correspondent for "Good Morning America," have taken on Martha hand to hand, down to the casual attire and the straw-basket-blond hair. "The dream is to turn me into a brand name and license products: crystal, china, window treatments, bedding," said Ms. Lynn, 35, who is looking for her own television show.
 Martha says, "Why anybody would want to copy me or replicate me is kind of crazy."

 TAPE A SEGMENT ON "OPRAH" -- "Appearing on 'Oprah' was a turning point," said Ms. Madden, who landed her own show after making herself invaluable to the busy Ms. Winfrey, redesigning her private office to include watercolors of Ms. Winfrey's dogs.
Mr. Cowie says he is now recognized at airports, thanks to his annual "Oprah" appearance. "I get a whole hour with her," he boasted. Other Stewart wannabes have appeared on "Entertainment Tonight" (Mr. Cowie), "Good Morning America" (Ms. Madden, Ms. Lynn) and the "Today" show (Lynette Jennings). The telegenic Ms. Smith has appeared on "Oprah," the "Today" show and "Good Morning America."
Martha says, "If you're an expert in something very specific, you may be invited on my show."

 NAME DROP -- Mr. Cowie, who is doing an all-Prada Halloween wedding this weekend in Beverly Hills, Calif., has been a nuptial coordinator for such taste mavens as Hugh Hefner, Kenny G., Paula Abdul and Charlie Sheen. "Because of the celebrity angle," he said, "I have been inundated with offers to do licensing agreements."
Ms. Brown's press kit mentions that she has catered for Quentin Tarantino, Mira Sorvino and Diane Keaton. Ms. Madden trumpets that she is Ms. Winfrey's favorite designer. One of the most popular names to drop is that of the poet Maya Angelou. She was touted as a guest, client or book subject by at least four of the seven interviewed.
Not to be outdone, Martha says, "Even Oprah has said to me, 'Where do you get your ideas?' "

 EXPLOIT A COLORFUL PAST -- Ms. Stewart, 57, was variously a model, a stockbroker and a caterer before she turned to life-style management. Ms. Jennings, 50, studied architecture and owned a company that actually built homes. Ms. Smith's career as a model has given her poise, and 12 years of running her own restaurants in New York, Washington and Sag Harbor have made her comfortable with a wooden spoon.
Ms. Brown said she learned cooking tips by pestering chefs during her years in New York as a waitress. A childhood in Kitwe, Zambia, and studies in pharmacy provided Mr. Cowie with inspiration to become, as his biography states, an "international arbiter of taste." And Ms. Madden's success suggests that a background in public relations works, too. She spent time in the publicity departments of Random House, G. P. Putnam's Sons and Simon & Schuster before becoming a design writer. "I know a trend when I see one," she said.
Martha would like to own up to a more colorful past, but says, "I don't remember the last time I made a mistake."

 FIND A NEW GIMMICK -- So far, no one has come up with a trademark to match Ms. Stewart's signature phrase, "It's a good thing." But that's not for want of trying. Ms. Emmerling is the doyenne of five-minute decorating and promotes decor that might best be termed rack 'n' stack. Check her book "Quick Decorating" for details, but it involves piles of books, things hanging from coat racks and folded blankets. "Folding just comes naturally to me," she said.
Ms. Madden so believes women need personal spaces that she wrote a book, which includes an exegesis on a nun's adobe cell in Santa Fe, N.M. Mr. Cowie, who employs the word "fabulous" as generously as a truckstop waitress doles out ketchup, has elevated table-top decor (seafood topiary anyone?) to an art worthy of a Hallmark card.
Martha says: "I look for what isn't out there. My next book is about hors d'oeuvres. There's a need out there for a good handbook on hors d'oeuvres."

 GET INTO PRINT -- Ms. Lynn shot her own photos for "Eclectic Living," while Ms. Smith hired Andrea Gentl and Martin Hyers, a husband-and-wife team who have worked for Martha Stewart Living. Ms. Madden has one-upped them all: her editor at Clarkson Potter, Annetta Hannah, used to be Ms. Stewart's editor.
Mr. Cowie and Ms. Madden say they will start their own magazines within a year. Ms. Brown, the new spokeswoman for Arm & Hammer baking soda, said she currently has book offers from 21 publishers.
Martha says: "Whether it's as simple as roasting a chicken or as complicated as making Jean-Georges's chocolate delight dessert, readers want to know the real way and no short cuts. People never put the real way in their books."

GET YOUR OWN SHOW -- Without a weekly show, you're just another guest stylist. Ms. Brown has managed to leapfrog her competition. Come January, her show will expand to five half-hour segments a week.
Ms. Jennings, a pioneer in the genre, has spent 10 years on the Discovery Channel. Her highly professional series, "Lynette Jennings Design," combines instructional home tours with practical decorating tips. "I consider myself more of a teacher than a celebrity, a hostess or a star," said Ms. Jennings, the Ted Koppel of life style.
Martha says: "I surf the networks at night, seeing how other people are doing. People are not being offered quality programming except for mine."

 RESTORE, RECYCLE, RE-USE -- Even Ms. Stewart in recent weeks has recycled standbys like "How to Load a Dishwasher" and "How to Hang a Backyard Clothesline." How can any mere mortal consistently come up with new ideas? "Everything's recycled these days," Ms. Emmerling said. "I don't care who you are -- you can't do it all yourself. You get it from magazines, from books, from store windows. Why did I see 'Out of Africa' 20 times? I wanted to see that living room again."
Martha says, "I come up with 25 ideas a day."

 THINK FRAGRANCE -- Create a brand, and market it shamelessly. Not everyone will have the longevity of Ms. Stewart, whose line of Everyday sheets and towels for Kmart is expected to top $1 billion in sales this fiscal year. "Except for Martha, it comes and goes for everyone," said Ms. Emmerling, who lost her line of sheets for J. C. Penny and is now down to wallpaper and American Country West furnishings.

 While most empire builders want to expand quickly, Ms. Jennings held off until this year, when she became the spokeswoman for Home Depot and signed deals with Delta (for crafts products), Crown Craft (for bedding and throw rugs) and Time-Life (for books and videos). "We wanted to wait until we could work with the top people in each field," she said.
Martha says: "I must have turned down 44 perfumes. I've never licensed my name. That is not something that is going to be fabulous."

 SPAWN A PARODY -- Ms. Stewart is a target because of her perfectionism and apparent lack of humor, as anyone who watched her flock a Christmas tree with cotton candy on the David Letterman show can attest. So far, none of the seven pretenders to Martha's throw rug have proved worthy of parody. But what pleasures lie ahead?
Martha says: "Love the late-night jokes. But the parodies are so stupid. I could do those better myself."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 11, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the House & Home section on Oct. 29 about home improvement experts who are seeking to emulate the success of Martha Stewart in publishing and on television misidentified one who plans to start a magazine within a year. She is Barbara Smith, not Chris Casson Madden.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 45; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1029 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
In Liberty We Trust: An Ethos Evolves

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

THE STORY OF AMERICAN FREEDOM
By Eric Foner
Illustrated. 422 pages. W. W. Norton. $27.95.
In 1792, fearing the emergence of a monarchical Presidency, Congress directed that the new American nation's first coins display not the head of the President but "an impression emblematic of liberty, with an inscription of the word Liberty" stamped upon them. A decade later, when Thomas Jefferson effected the Louisiana Purchase, he referred to the enlarged country as "the Empire of Liberty." And three generations after that, at the height of the Civil War, Abraham Lincoln said of both sides: "We all declare for Liberty, but in using the same word we do not all mean the same thing."
Freedom has always been the American religion, but, as Lincoln said, the concept has meant different things at different times to different groups. The competing definitions are closely described in this new book by Eric Foner, a Columbia University historian. "The Story of American Freedom" is a retelling of American history, from the Revolutionary War to the Reagan revolution, organized around the concept of freedom, its meaning and how that meaning has been manipulated, argued and transformed. 
 The history of freedom, Mr. Foner writes, is "a tale of debates, disagreements and struggles rather than a set of timeless categories or an evolutionary narrative toward a preordained goal."
That statement is no doubt true and also worth remembering as one reads Mr. Foner's well-informed and scrupulously balanced book. And yet, there is something dutiful rather than inspired about Mr. Foner's writing and his approach, which, despite the author's claim to have taken a fresh look at American history, comes across as a bit familiar. It seems rather obvious, for example, that a history including the Civil War, Reconstruction, Jim Crow and the denial, until after World War I, of the vote to women, never reflected liberty as an immutable principle. Despite that, and despite a certain blandness in the writing -- freedom as a matter of "divergent connotations and applications," for example -- and despite the abstractness of his approach, Mr. Foner has written an instructive book on the spirit of American political life.
Mr. Foner examines each major period of American history, isolating the concept of freedom that prevailed at the time, demonstrating how the concept was either challenged or reinforced. He treats the Revolutionary War, for example, as a seminal episode that did far more than simply win independence for the colonies and create a nonmonarchical republic. The roots of American freedom lay in the former mother country, but "its emergence as a new and distinct ideology grew out of the struggle for independence and the creation of a nation-state that defined itself, in James Madison's words, as the 'workshop of liberty to the Civilized World.' "
The great national hypocrisy was slavery and, after slavery, the institutionalized racism that persisted until after the first half of the 20th century. Mr. Foner shows what seems extraordinary now, that the debate over slavery was to a degree a contest between alternate concepts of freedom, one stressing the rights of all to be free and the other the supposed normal hierarchy of human society in which some were naturally subordinate to others.
Mr. Foner's examples of the effect that slavery had on American practices and vocabulary are among the book's most fascinating passages. "The contrast between liberty and slavery provided a rhetoric through which those outside the boundaries of American freedom could challenge their exclusion and, in so doing, transform the meaning of freedom itself." Just as, in Mr. Foner's interpretation, the Revolution established freedom as the national ideology, the Union's victory in the Civil War "consolidated the northern understanding of freedom as the national norm."
The Civil War also fostered the image of a powerful Government as the ultimate guarantor of freedom, and this suggests a tension in American history as old as the nation, the tension between governmental power as a threat and as the guardian of the oppressed. Subsequent national debates over the concentration of capital, for example, echoed the earlier competing conceptions of freedom, whether it meant unrestricted economic activity or something close to its opposite, controls on private property to prevent the economic enslavement of labor.
Mr. Foner traces the development of the concept of civil liberties to court cases involving free speech early in this century. He argues that the New Deal finally recognized economic security as "a political condition of personal freedom." In the postwar world, Mr. Foner argues, freedom became associated with material prosperity, an association made clear in Richard Nixon's famous "kitchen debate" with the Soviet leader, Nikita S. Khrushchev. "In the 1950's," Mr. Foner writes, "freedom became fully identified with consumer capitalism, or, as it was now universally known, 'free enterprise.' "
Mr. Foner ends on a note of description rather than analysis. He shows how freedom was, in his view, expanded by the cultural revolution of the 1960's, but also how a different concept of freedom -- based, again, on economic freedom and the fear of big Government -- came to prevail when Ronald Reagan become President. The two final chapters, in which Mr. Foner covers this ground, are rapid-fire summaries of recent American history, from the 60's notion of freedom as an erotically charged challenge to authority to the Reagan-era concept of freedom based on smaller government and free enterprise.
Mr. Foner is nothing if not comprehensive here, as in the rest of his book, but these final chapters, which involve violently contested visions of American freedom, seem strangely bloodless as well as familiar. Reading "The Story of American Freedom," one is grateful for Mr. Foner's clarity and knowledgeability, even while wishing that he had been conceptually bolder and more outspoken about his passions and less dutifully respectful of so many points of view, including those he clearly does not agree with.
